comment.text: Okay, bare with me. But this is my theory on what happened to these two poor young ladies. I believe something happened between 13:20 and 13:54. The contrast between the photos taken at this time show Kris pulling a silly face, sticking her tongue out and posing without care, to her displaying an awkward stance, with a serious expression, perhaps concerned. It looks like it went from having fun to not enjoying themselves at this point, between these 34 minutes. Could be that they were fed up of the walk, having gone further than planned and realised they were lost. They hadn’t planned on a long hike, as they didn’t have a large supply of drinking water, nor spare clothing if the weather changed. They seemed like smart girls with travelling experience, so I don’t think they would have simply taken these chances without planning. Someone encountered them after the photos at 13:20. They took possession of the camera and led them deeper into the rain forest, snapping shots of Kris, forcing her to pose, and keeping Lisa out of view, either to create the illusion that Lisa was taking them as they continued their walk, or this was a strange form of torture. Maybe the stranger had offered to take photos but the girls became uncomfortable, the person became agitated. Because, following the photos at 13:54 when Kris doesn’t seem to be smiling like she is in all the previous photos, and it being further past the trail than they had planned or been advised to go, that’s when the photo which was deleted occurred. Perhaps the person taking the photo accidentally captured one of themselves, maybe even just their own finger which could have given away the evidence that the girls were not alone. Or somehow the girls had taken the camera back and taken a snap of this person. Maybe they were arguing with them, stating that they didn’t want to be followed or joined any more by this person. Could be they didn’t mind the company to begin with, not expecting the person to want to tag along for longer than a couple of minutes, or could be they felt obliged to be friendly to a local person but felt awkward. The stranger becomes offended, and with agitation he threatens them. One of the girls takes a photo of them. This aggravates the stranger, and they snatch the camera back and delete the pic. Maybe the girls tried to take the camera back and this person attacks them. It escalates. He hits Kris or uses a weapon. Maybe she is knocked unconscious. Or she is killed. He then does the same to Lisa. Maybe they were bound, sexually assaulted - no evidence of this, but it’s a possibility - and killed. Perhaps, during the time in which they are being followed or led away, the girls tried calling the emergency services to no avail. By the time the person caught up with them, or realised they had been making calls, these calls stopped, the phones being taken from them. Or they were faked by the third party themselves. After the girls were killed, I believe their bodies were taken away. This leads to the theory that there would have been more than one attacker to carry the bodies and belongings away. Whatever the reason, whether needing to get rid of evidence following an opportunist murder, or for some satanic ritual including potential cannibalism, or an act of organ trade, the bodies were then disposed of: skinned (perhaps consumed by human or animal assistance), dismembered, bones shattered into smaller pieces. The bones were bleached, perhaps to remove evidence, perhaps out of some psychopathic act of cherishing their “trophy kill”. This explains the severed foot (by machete, common use in the Panamanian jungle), the rolled up skin, the bleached pelvis bone, the other thirty or so bone particles discovered over a stretch of land. These were all saved and deliberately placed further from where the girls were killed, including the backpack which was dry and in perfect condition, bras neatly stacked inside, having been removed when the women were possibly assaulted, and in any case when killed, neither of which would have occurred if the backpack was left in the rain forest for as many weeks as it was suggested - since the time of the girls coming into trouble and making calls; nor would the body parts have naturally decomposed in a natural environment the way they did if left in the jungle - they were preserved, and saved for a later moment to be discovered to confuse the officials and public. The perpetrator used the camera to take the confusing nighttime photos in sporadic succession days after the girls were killed, to suggest the girls were alive and had taken the themselves. I fail to believe these photos were taken by either girl - so many days had passed since the hike and emergency calls, and they had no water source, nor food, not to mention suffering with the heat and the heaving rain. Perhaps the hair was always saved and used in this pic to appear as though she is still in the jungle at this point. Hair doesn’t die with the rest of the body when decomposing. Kris’s phone was plugged in by whoever had possession of this in the following days after their kidnap/murder, desperately attempting to access the phone, either to delete photos in fear of there being any evidence, or for sheer curiosity, wanting to invade the girl’s private life more than they already had. Maybe someone knew they were heading into the forest and followed them, or let slip to another stranger of their whereabouts, such as the tour guide or taxi driver. Their items in the backpack such as the knife and compass which were missing were simply stolen by whomever took their belongings. It could be that the items were left when the girls were taken away and were later found/stolen by someone else, only to realise who it belonged to and returned them to the forest in fear of being accused of having involvement. Police did a poor job with solving the case either because: a) they were confused with all the events and lazily failed at tying it together, b) they don’t want it solved due to the knowledge that a third party involvement of their nationality would create negative media coverage, affecting tourism which the community heavily relies on as a main source for income, or c) perhaps the police were even involved/aware of the specifics of the crime, if such a thing as organ trade or human trafficking were prevalent in the area. Terrible story, horrifies me and makes me so sad to know they were out there enjoying a holiday with their best friend, to end up the way they did. True horror story material. Awful. I just hope the girls had each other for longer than predicted or I can figure out, that they looked after each other as best they could - it’s horrible to know they loved each other and were in that situation together, maybe one having to see the other be killed, or each other be assaulted/killed. I hope someone can come forward and shed light onto what happened, that the case can be solved the way it deserves to be, and the girls can be put to rest, the families can have answers and the person(s) responsible can face serious brutal  justice.
comment.author: @sammm6210

comment.text:
No one could ever be 100% sure of what really happened to these 2 girls, but to me the fact that they just had an accident and that no foul play was involved it's very unlikely to me.
I think that the answer of what really happened it's in that photo in their camera that's been deleted. I mean, that specific photo is the photo between their last "normal" photo taken on April 1st while they were apparently normally hiking, and the start of the series of mysterious night photos presumably taken on April 8th. It might be just a coincidence, but damn, there are MANY weird coincidences in this story. It's also believed how that photo has been deleted using a computer software. Yes, it could have been the police, but if it was really the police to delete that photo, i don't think it's been an accident. I mean, how can you delete a photo in a computer software by accident? You should select the photo, click on 'delete' and then confirm. And even if it really was an accident, it's a hell of a coincidence that it was only that specific photo to have been deleted, don't you think? If it was really the police who deleted the photo it was to cover up something or someone.
comment.author: @matthewzn.4957

comment.text:
On every true crime video, it seems there's someone who comments how out of the many, many true crime cases they've watched, THAT one is the that sticks with them the most. This is that case for me--well, tied with the whole Turtle Island Thailand gang-corruption-coverup murders haha. 

Any theory on this case (or derivative) get be picked apart so it's frustrating. Some things start to make sense in your mind, it's all clicking together, and then you go "but wait, what about the ___ " So yeah the only thing i'm certain of is that i'm not certain. I do notice however, that people who support the theory that they just got lost (whether coupled with an animal attack, a fall of a cliff, effects of dehydration etc.) don't seem able or willing to refute arguments for the (a) foul play theory. 

Even to believe they were kidnapped by a gang would open up so many more questions that have left people scratching their heads. But I tend to lean towards some form of the foul play theory, and here why.

Points that contradict the theory that they just got lost:

1) the backpack -- it was found 70 days after the girls' disappearance, beside a river bank 15 km away from the pianista trail. The lady who found it said she was at the same spot the day before but didn't see any backpack there. The backpack was NOT wet -- it was in pristine condition and the items inside were dry and appeared untouched. The phones and digital camera were in there, so it becomes difficult to see how the girls could've been the ones taking the pictures and calling emergency services in the jungle for 11 days, and yet the backpack doesn't get wet or dirty, and somehow makes a long journey on its own without getting wet. 

2) Lisanne's severed left foot was found in her hiking boot, and the cut was clean -- This disproves any animal attack theory and shows a human being cut off her foot. Unless Pokemon are real and a Scyther jumped out and cut her foot off, then it was a human. It can't be argued that an animal could have done that, plus the boot was clean and still tied to her foot, with no sign of scratches or claw marks

Honestly, I don't see how anyone can believe they just got lost given the above 2 points. Ok let's tack on some more for goal differential :P

3) Pictures -- I'm hoping people have watched/read other things about this case, to gather more details. The daytime pictures and nighttime pictures tell completely different (albeit incomplete) stories. 

Timeline: they start their hike on April 1st. Yikes, I didn't even notice that was April Fool's, ugh. 

-> daytime pictures - The girls are smiling. These are the ones at the foot of the trail, along it and leading up to them reaching the peak where I wish they had been able to turn back. In the strange pictures of Kris beside the stream of water and crouched by the bushes, she's not smiling at all and some believe at this point they were either kidnapped or had run into another group and knew they were dangerous.

 These initial pictures were taken before 1:30-2:00pm, so that refutes the taxi driver saying he dropped them off at that time. Nope, he might've just misremembered but this notion that they started their hike at 2pm is simply false. MORE on that taxi driver in a bit ....

> nighttime pictures - After 2pm on April 1st, no one used the camera for 7 days. It just doesn't make sense, if they were alone and simply lost, to not have a SINGLE picture of them, or anything in the daytime for that matter. But then on April 8th, someone took more than 90 photos in less than 3 hours - those hours were between 1am-4am. This is where the "they just got lost" camp suggests that these photos were meant to light up the area so they could see their surroundings, perhaps signal an airplane or search party, or perhaps scare off an animal they (or rather just she, by this point) might have heard. I have to admit, whyy would kidnappers be out at 1-4am taking pictures though? Best chance to not be seen as they make it look like the girls took the pictures in the jungle? Oh, I dunno. But then again, WHY was there 0 camera activity for 7 days?

Then there's the deleted photo and this one's a mammoth. Keep in mind that pictures were taken on a digital camera, not their phones. A computer must be used to fully erase a photo, and the Canon company itself confirmed this. It makes a strong argument that the girls managed to get a picture of something or someone incriminating, and whoever kidnapped them (* cough Feliciano Gonzales) had to have deleted the picture. 

4) Phones -- alright so on the first day, April 1st, the first emergency call to 112 was placed just after 4:30pm. Then a call was placed to 911 but didn't get through. Then phones turned off for 14 hours. Again, why? If they were lost and had their phones, how do they both go 14 hours without having their phone on? 

In total, they made about 80 calls. On day 5 (April 5th) LIsanne's phone died. Kris's phone stayed on until day 11 but between April 7th-10th Kris's phone was off/had no activity. It was turned on again, for the last time, at 10:51am on April 11th. It was turned off exactly an hour later at 11:51am, and this was the end of any phone activity. 

On April 6th, there were several attempts to enter an incorrect code. There were dozens of attempts up until April 11th. The girls obviously would have exchanged pass codes so it's very unlikely that Lisanne would've been locked out of Kris's phone. Plus, they didn't need a pass code to make an emergency call so investigators concluded it was unlikely to have been Lisanne trying to enter the code. The girls hadn't called home or the place they were staying, or anything other than emergency services in those 11 days so that seemed a bit strange. Why "dozens" of attempts to enter a phone, unless it was kidnappers looking for photos or something before they plant the phones in the backpack and leave them by the river. 

5) Tour guide / gang members 
Oh I gotta wrap this up. No one's reading anyway but I can't sleep so let's write until the eyes get heavy haha. Okay but yeah, let's go over some of these characters.

Feliciano Gonzales - the tour guide
Internet sleuths like me believe he's our guy. He basically IS a red flag, everything that he does. The girls were supposed to meet with Feliciano but they didn't. So after the girls went missing, he went over to the place they were staying and was in the girls' room for 30 minutes. There wasn't a door key in the backpack that was found, which doesn't make sense. Then of course it's Feliciano who spotted the boot with Lisanne's severed foot in it, and other bones. 33 bones were discovered, one pair of jean shorts, and one shoe from each of the girls. Then there was a rolled up ball of human skin. Then you look at Feliciano's tripadvisor reviews online and the one where he threatens a woman with a machete sticks out. Machete, clean cut above the ankle, hmm. OH, and then the suspicious deaths. Over 10 people connected to the case have died, including 4 member of the Los gang. The one gang member who survived? Henri Elizas Gonzales, Feliciano's son. Alright. 

Taxi driver -- named Leonardo Gonzales -- drove the girls to la pianista, told police he saw a pickup truck near where he dropped the girls off. He was found dead in a river, 7 months after the girls' disappearance.

Gang member 1 - Osman Velezuales (23 years old) - died April 4th (3 days after the girls' disappearance). 

2 - Juan Rivera Miranda (24)
3 - Jorge Murgas (23)
4 - Adonis Henriberto (23)

One was drowned in a shallow pool, one hit and run, and I forget the other. I'm tired, still need to look up another supposed suspect named Plineo Montenegro. 

But yeah, again no one will have read this but forgive the long rant, anyway. This case just has so many strange elements to it. I mean, the girls actually had a compass, a solar power bank, and a knife in their room. They obviously would've taken these if they planned to go on a long hike, which further makes me believe they were intercepted at some point on the trail. 

It just seems obvious that there was foul play involved. Foul play's a euphemism for what Lisanne and Kris went through, and I can't see any way they just got lost. Again they didn't pack much, they didn't take any daytime photos after the first 2 hours of their hike, the condition of the bone fragments, the knowledge of gang/police/government corruption in Panama, all of it. If they were lost, wouldn't they have tried to mark where they've been? It's dense jungle but even little pieces of clothing tied to a tree could be seen by people searching. What about trying to make SOS signs out of rocks or sticks?> Or at least make piles of random sticks and brush so you'll know you've been there before, and people searching can tell a human made those piles. 

I dunno, it just seems a bit disrespectful to the girls and their lives to believe they were foolish and got lost. Just think, if Lisanne or Kris was your daughter, would you be able to look at this case and accept that the girls must've just got lost? Evidence for them being lost pales in comparison to them being kidnapped, does it not?

Then again, I could be wrong :)
comment.author: @davidmetzler6670

comment.text:
In the disappearance of these two Dutch girls, there are two situations that I don't understand and I believe that need a more careful analysis:
1-If in the first two calls to the Dutch emergency number, they were already under the control of kidnappers, why didn't the criminals take the phones, the camera and all their belongings?

This doesn't make any sense! No offenders with murderous or sexual intentions would risk being photographed by their victims, or even risk the girls calling the police or leaving a message recorded on their cell phones for when they are found by the authorities.

2- Why don't you have any attempt to call 911 during the night?

What would be the worst moment for two girls from an urban environment, lost in the middle of a tropical jungle?
Do you agree with me that this worst moment would be to spend the night in the forest?! Exhausted, cold, with animals moving on the ground, animal movement in the dark forest, a plague of insects, rain spray, hunger, thirst and darkness everywhere. This would undoubtedly be the time when they would most try to connect to an emergency number, but they didn't.

Trying to explain these two situations, the best way to harmonize was as follows:
Lisanne and Kris decided on their own, to continue the trail past the viewpoint, when they realized they couldn't make it back before nightfall, or because they really got lost and disoriented, they decided to make the first two calls in the late afternoon of April 1st. . Without success, they must surely have screamed for help. They were certainly answered and rescued by someone who heard them both scream, or someone who somehow passed them on the trail. This would explain why the girls did not attempt to call an emergency number during the night, that is, they felt safe to be accompanied by someone they believed to be trustworthy and well intentioned.
After that, they certainly went with that someone, to some nearby property, where they continued to be deceived by lies that reassured them, but that at dawn and after a night's sleep, they always tried to make another emergency call, until the cell phone battery has discharged.
It was at that moment that this someone realized that they were totally incommunicado and certainly decided to attack and take their belongings that were all inside the backpack.
From then on, all the evil that befell the girls began.

In my opinion, between the moment the last cell phone ran out of charge and the dawn of the 8th, Kris Kremers was killed, so in the photos taken on the 8th, only the hair of a lifeless body of Kris appears, trying to simulate a disappearance, with them lost in the night trying to signal their position in the woods and kris dead in Lisanne's arms (who doesn't appear in the photos) as it's the killer planting false evidence, not Lisanne!

As the pieces of Lisanne Froon's skin were found in mid-June, in an initial state of decomposition, this shows that Lisanne was killed in early June and was under the control of this someone who killed her, for about 60 days. She was the last to die.

Note 1: Seeing the holes in Kris' Jeans, it shows that her dead body was dragged a short distance, where it was thrown. That is, this may indicate that the place where Kris and Lisanne were killed and the bodies were subjected to a chemical treatment for dismemberment and then concealment, are very close to each other, and may be in the vicinity of this property where they felt "safe" .

Note 2: The photo of Kris' hair at night, may not have been photographed in the forest, but in a closed and dark environment.

Note 3: Kris' boot found, was it clean and without any remains inside? No animal in the forest, would be interested in carrying a leather boot in her mouth! It's not food! That's how the animals would see this boot, any object, they would have smelled it and gone. That boot was taken to the forest by the killer.

Note 4: The police know of more evidence, maybe even the photo that was deleted. At the very least, they want to make some strategic use.

Conclusion: Kris Kremers and Lisanne Froon, were held captive in an environment they thought was safe, were killed, stripped naked, with the bodies being dismembered by some chemical process as yet unknown. Some dismembered parts, along with the girls' boots, clothes and backpack with all the girls' belongings, were deliberately abandoned along the straight-line trail to create false leads and simulate that the girls died of hunger and thirst after getting lost in the deep in the forest.

The death of these innocent girls touched me a lot! This is my small contribution to unravel their deaths and thus lead to a punishment, the possible murderer and the possible collaborators.

Fortaleza-CE, Brazil.

I very much hope that Jesus Christ will comfort Kris and Lisanne's parents.
comment.author: @eliaslima5506

comment.text:
Au sujet de la photo 509, comme tu l'as dit, une fois qu'un fichier a été supprimé on peut le restaurer avec un logiciel spécial, SAUF si des données ont été ensuite écrites sur la carte par-dessus ce fichier. Et ça peut avoir été fait par les photos de nuit, si tu remplis la carte avec des photos ça va définitivement effacer la photo 509.

Donc en résumé, il faut avoir pris la photo 510 en premier, puis avoir supprimé la 509 (si on fait pas dans cet ordre, il n'y a plus de trou), puis pris toutes les autres. On peut se demander pourquoi avoir pris une photo avant de supprimer la 509. Mais peut-être qu'il y a davantage de photos qui ont été supprimées avant de prendre la 510, et que la 509 a été oubliée dans un premier temps.
Par exemple on aurait 512 photos à la base, l'assassin supprime de 510 à 512, puis commence à prendre des photos bidon pour remplir la carte (la première sera la 510), puis s'aperçoit qu'il a oublié de supprimer la 509, la supprime, et continu de prendre des photos bidons.

Pour savoir qu'un fichier n'est jamais totalement supprimé tant qu'on n'écrit pas par-dessus, il faut avoir un minimum de connaissances en informatique, donc on chercherait plutôt quelqu'un qui côtoie la technologie, pas un habitant de la forêt.
comment.author: @ChatCureuil-SimRacing

comment.text:
I'm sceptical of the murder theories, although they're understandable, given past crimes involving young women hikers in foreign countries. I have myself been seriously lost in the woods twice, and once guided out a young woman lost in the woods at night while I was camping just off the Appalachian trail. Each time it was dramatic how fast disorientation and panic set in - it's the panic-fear that makes one automatically do the opposite of what one should do. It's not like your car's GPS stops working on a road trip. It's more like falling off a cruise ship and watching it disappear over the horizon. I can only infer that in the most serious cases, especially after days of food deprivation and chronic anxiety and stress, disorientation could become so severe that the two inexperienced girls in the Panama case would begin acting almost pathologically confused, while desperate hope may have led them to forego goodbye messages for the sake of attempts to reach local rescue until the batteries in their phones went dead and it was too late.

I've watched a couple of the better pieced-together videos and I found myself getting sceptical of the murder theories when I saw too much bias in that direction. For example, some of the "happy" photos early on in their hike were slightly distorted or the clouds seemed mis-timed from one snap to the next or the one girl was supposedly a little depressed or anxious looking, and to me all that seemed overly subjective and irrelevant to any criminal activity. The idea of any killers allowing their victims to keep taking photos is ridiculous, not just because it creates possible evidence but because abduction and murder (rape also) is about having complete power and control over someone.

Why would a killer and not the girls turn the phones on and off? Only the girls had any reason to do that repeatedly, and if they had the chance to do so around an abductor, they also would have had the chance to escape. The backpack could have been misplaced by the girls in their disoriented state until a villager found and took it, then returned it, dry, to the same (or a different) spot once they got wind of rescue efforts for the owner of the backpack and realized it might implicate them in more than just “finders, keepers.”

As for the photos in the camera, how would taking dozens of photos of the sky at night serve to mislead police? And the height-distorted photo of Lisanne? Digital photos occasionally are goofy like that (I have a rear-view pic of my motorcycle where the panniers look like two different sizes). The clouds at the trail overlook completely mismatching in photos taken seconds apart? Weird, but how does that suggest foul play, when the girls are posing normally? The deleted photo? A tech-savvy killer would only take the batteries out of the phones and throw everything in the river or bury it all, making deleting photos unnecessary and also increasing the mystery to the killer’s advantage. Anyways, why disguise a murder as an accident, when both possibilities (murder or losing their way) are going to be speculated about regardless? I can certainly see the girls using the camera flashes to attempt signalling toward airplane sounds and checking for hazards in their path (note the one photo of a dangerous drop down a rock). Furthermore, why would a killer force-march two victims miles through a jungle, only to kill them in the middle of nowhere? That makes no sense - killers aren't lazy, but what advantage would there be to the killer?. 

I think these girls just got hopelessly lost, and that leads me back to my own experiences of being lost in the woods - the more you try to guess your way out in a panicked and confused state of mind, the more lost you get. To me, the most important thing about this tragedy isn't how the girls died, but the decisions they made leading up to their disappearance. They'd worked hard as waitresses in the Netherlands to save for the trip and they were young, idealistic and eager, so it's understandable they'd be adventurous. But they'd already reached their goal of living in that small tropical town in Panama and they hadn't even seriously explored the town itself yet. They had a guided hike scheduled for the next day. What was the hurry to get into the jungle? Going to extremes is always a dangerous thing, and getting too adventurous too soon was going to an extreme. I think the girls were their own killers.
comment.author: @craigfinnegan8534

comment.text: It is interesting how Kris was unsmiling and looked uneasy in her last photo at the river. Given the mood of their previous photos, they should both have been ideally standing on those rocks together smiling and taking photos together. The fact that this particular photo shows Kris alone at a distance on the river looking back with an uneasy expression on her face is a cause for concern. Even if she had instructed Lisanne to take a solo photo of her, she should have at least been smiling and posing because she was comfortable in her friend's company. This leads me to believe that they had already encountered their assailant(s) at this time. Perhaps it was the assailant behind the camera taking a photo of Kris for whatever reason hence her worried expression. The argument that they got lost holds no water simply because of the state some of their remains were found in and the detective is right, they would have left at least a message or something narrating what went wrong. Their bodies would also have been found intact because they would probably have died of starvation if they got lost in the jungle. The night photos are the biggest puzzle in my opinion. It makes no sense at all that they would suddenly decide to use the camera as a flash to illuminate the way after all those days. Even if that is the case, it doesn't explain the photos of the sky or kris' hair with hints of blood on it. I actually thought that that photo could have been Kris herself holding the camera behind her head to try and take a picture of the wound in order to assess the damage. If that is true, then it means that she must have been alone at this point and was probably taking pictures of the sky as a way to try and signal her position to Lisanne or potential search teams whom she would probably have expected to be on the lookout for them. The photos of the surrounding could then imply that something or someone was lurking nearby and she was trying desperately to see who/what it was. Based on the evidence, i know for a fact that it was murder. The only questions that remain unanswered are who did it, how they did it, why they did it and the location of the rest of the remains.
comment.author: @martinking2909

comment.text:
Quelle horrible histoire ! RIP Kris et Lisanne, pensée pour les familles. Ces deux jeunes filles connaissant mal l'espagnol n'ont pas été bien accueillies, n'auraient pas pu aider ces écoles. Mais elles ont sûrement été repérées.
Le guide, bizarre son omniprésence. A-t-il voulu surveiller les recherches pour couvrir des personnes connues ? Son fils ?
Le sac à dos réapparu, intact, pas possible qu'il soit resté dehors tout ce temps. L'enquête avançant, les ravisseurs/assassins l'ont sorti pour laisser croire à un accident. La carte est laissée dans l'appareil photo pour "montrer" que personne n'y avait touché à part les filles. Mais la photo soigneusement effacée : sûrement pour ne pas trahir une ou des personnes prises en photo par une des filles. Les autres photos "étranges" : peut-être prises en douce par une des filles qui aura été transportée ou tirée dans cette jungle quelques jours après par des ravisseurs/violeurs avant le pire ? Comme elles ne montraient personne, elles n'ont pas été effacées. Les téléphones avaient peut-être été confisqués ? Plein de traces d'ADN, pourquoi pas de recherches ? 
Enquête vite close avec conclusion de disparition accidentelle : corruption policière, juridique  pour protéger des locaux connus, ou bien en effet pour préserver la manne du tourisme ?
Le corps (débris) ayant eu de la chaux vive, preuve d'assassinat, tentative de destruction...
Pauvres familles quand elles ont su...
Merci Lionel pour la mémoire de ces deux jeunes filles.
Elles ont tout de même fait preuve de naïveté et d'imprudence, quel gâchis !

Edit : le sac à dos ne présente pas de traces de violence. Celle qui le portait ne s'est donc pas débattue avec celui-ci sur son dos.
La photo effacée est la clé du mystère... Ont-elles suivi quelqu'un en toute confiance ? Le guide (il a une maison plus ou moins dans le secteur, et un fils dont on ne sait rien) ? Puis attirées dans un traquenard d'abord à leur insu, d'abord "gentiment accueillies", puis séquestrées  et violentées, mais loin du fameux mirador ? Les a-t-on forcées à marcher jusqu'à ce lieu ? Ont-elles été droguées à un moment ? 
Les photos mal prises ont peut-être été faites par l'une des deux filles qui aurait tenté de fuir un ou plusieurs jours après ? Mais elle aurait été rattrapée, hélas. Il faudrait voir l'horodatage des photos.
comment.author: @fcomme5754

comment.text: I always thought I was seeing 2 teeth in the lower right corner. However, when I looked at the times these photos were taken in darkness, the photo before that was taken at 1:45 am, then the hair photo at 1:49 and the next photo at 1:50. That HAS to be random, you would not be able in this short time to decide to photograph something peculiar about the hair/ head/ face and then immediatedly resume shooting into the sky. It was probably so dark, that Lisanne just did not realize Kris was standing before the lens or she accidentally pressed the shutter button while holding the camera down for a moment. Maybe the camera was overheating and she wanted to check why it would not take another photo when she was pressing the shutter button and then she realized it was working again when she accidentally took the hair photo.
comment.author: @Fidi987

comment.text:
Have you ever seen photos taken by a child or observed a child playing with a locked phone? I strongly believe the girls encountered a missing child and possibly tried to comfort them by showing the child how to use the camera. It seems the child took the final photos of the women, indicated by the quality and distance, differing from the girls' usual selfies. This aligns with the possibility of the girls deleting a poor-quality photo the child took, or perhaps a more unsettling scenario where a photo of the child with the two women was deleted, potentially by authorities for unknown reasons.

Several pieces of evidence support the theory of the girls encountering a child:

1. Their direction indicated they were attempting to assist the child by heading north, likely trying to help the child return home.
2. A photo of Kris displaying a playful gesture suggests she was trying to make the child feel at ease while he is photographing her.
3. The photos only feature Kris, implying Lisanne might have been engaging with the child while photos were taken.
4. Subsequent photos bear resemblance to those typically taken by a child.

I believe the child might have been used as a lure, leading to the tragic end of the two women upon reaching the child's family or someone else. The child might have been rewarded with the women's belongings or simply retained them, including the camera and phones.

The child seemed to have limited knowledge about using the camera, likely taught by the two women. However, the child struggled with using the phones, inadvertently triggering emergency calls and entering incorrect PINs. Fascinated by the camera's functionality, the child randomly took photos, including one of Kris' deceased head. Subsequently, someone disposed of the bag, potentially an essential piece of evidence. Later, a villager discovered the bag and initially chose to keep it. However, upon learning of a potential reward, they opted to hand it to the authorities, considering the reward more valuable than the bag's contents.
comment.author: @mysimplelife2076

comment.text:
Combien de photos de Lisanne après le sommet du Pianista ? Aucune.
Depuis le départ de Bokete jusqu'à l'arrivée au sommet, elles se prennent en photos mutuellement et font des selfies. Elles sont souriantes et enjouées. 
Une fois passé le sommet, plus aucune photo de Lisane, uniquement des photos de Kriss. Et Kriss ne semble pas avoir un visage très enjoué notamment sur la dernière photo, comme le dit un autre commentaire, on pourrait penser qu'elle est préoccupée. 

Il faut une heure entre le sommet et le lieu de la photo 508. C'est un paysage et un environnement très différent en passant le sommet. Pourquoi Lisane n'est pas sur quelques photos ? Pourquoi Kriss ne propose pas de prendre Lisane de temsp en temps ? 

Soit elles ne comprennent pas pourquoi le sentier ne les ramène pas à Bokete et elles ne comprennent pas qu'elles vont plein Nord alors que Bokete est plein Sud. Donc elles s'inquiètent  un peu car le temps passe, il faut du temps pour avancer dans cette jungle. Mais en même temps,Même juste après avoir pass" le sommet, je trouve anormal qu'il n'y ait aucune photo de Lisanne. 

Soit elles ne sont pas seules , notamment au moment de la photo 508. Et c'est juste après cette photo qu'il s'est passé quelquechose (?).
comment.author: @JM-lu8nn

comment.text:
They reached the summit an hour ahead of what they had planned and decided to go looking for waterfalls, though they had been advised not to. (They both had extensive search histories concerning the location of said waterfalls in the week leading up to their disappearance, but assured those who warned them not to look for them that they wouldn't... but they did end up with around two extra hours they weren't expecting to have by reaching the summit early...) The gullies they photographed themselves in were not all along their original path and have since been identified. As has the dirt trail they were on a week later. What most likely happened was that they realized they weren't going to be able ro make it back to the summit (and thus the only path back to town) before it got dark  and were going to have to spend the night on the mountain. In that gully area, the only cleared ground suitable for setting up any sort of makeshift camp would be one of the gullies themselves. They made their first attempts to contact help around an hour before dark which makes sense. The temperature was in the mid to upper 50's at night, and they were in shorts and tee shirts, so they would have wanted shelter. The debris formations they took pictures of themselves in front of would have seemed ideal for that. Such gullies are dangerous (especially before the rainy season is fully under way) since blockages can form and hold back water, leading to a very strong surge with debris down the mountain when the blockage gives. It likely rained that night, and they got hit by such a surge with nowhere to go inside the debris tunnel they were in. I've seen such surges, and they would definitely have been injured to some degree and washed along for a bit. Had one or both been carried to where the incline steepened, it would have led to significant injuries and no viable way back up.

They would have had to travel down the gully, which would have taken them to the river. There, they would have had water, but nowhere to really go (especially if one or more were injured) and would likely have decided to wait and hope a boat would go by (highly unlikely), or searchers would find them. You can go quite a while without food, but after about a week, you'd be pretty desperate. The dirt path they were on in their week later photos has since been identified via drone, and when you see it, things start to make sense. It ran along a gully and from the bottom likely looked like it went all the way up. It didn't. About halfway up, it essentially ran into a wall of dense foliage with nowhere to go. That would have been the last of their energy and the point at which at least one was likely to more or less give up. They probably went back down the mountain to their water source to wait for help, one died, and the other was too weak to make it for much longer. The only way back up would have been a gully, and by then, there was likely a good bit of water flowing down, so the survivor would have had no options. Nature took care of things from there.

The concerned looks on their faces in some of the gully photos were likely the result of their realizing they weren't going to get back in time but might as well take the pictures since that's what got them into the mess in the first place. While the night photos were likely just them using the flash as a flashlight. The head photo makes sense if you have an injured half starved person going up an incline with the person behind them taking periodic pictures to see where they were going. A stumble and fall would bring the person behind down as well, and a photo could easily have been snapped in the process. The photos aimed upwards were probably an attempt to signal a drug plane heard but not seen (as they run without lights) which regularly fly over that area at night. (Somewhere down there, there's probably such a pilot who saw those flashes but can't say anything about it because then they would have to explain why they were flying over that area at night with no flight plan registered anywhere.)

The physical evidence all makes sense as remains and items will get washed into the river during the rainy season. Also, the people in the village were not informed of the missing hikers until quite a while afterward and their stories as to where the evidence was found and it's initial condition were different depending on which villager was asked. They had probably already found the stuff, cleaned it, and were using some of it when they found out, and just threw it all back together to turn it in. The phones and camera were damaged and not in working condition with quite a bit of garbled data on them. The investigators were simply able to retrieve some of the data from them. The oddities of missing photos etc. could easily be explained by that. The "famous" missing photo had a registry entry but no trace of the actual image file. That can happen from a glitch. The investigators merely said that the only way it could have manually been removed was via PC, not that it had been removed so. Anyone smart enough to remove the image file would have purged the registry entry as well and attempted to adjust the numbering to completely cover it... or just destroyed the camera (and phones) to make sure there was no evidence to begin with. The foot in the shoe is perfectly natural when it comes to human remains. Shoes slow the decomp process down which leads to the feet eventually falling off. Shoes are somewhat buoyant, so if they end up in the water, they'll travel along. The "sun bleached" bones were most likely not truly or fully sun bleached. A couple of species of the last stage decomp beetles in the area excrete phosphates as they do their work. Such phosphates easily and quickly leech into the bone and turn it very white (they even have a slight glow in the dark for a bit after prolonged exposure to sunlight.)

I think that covers most of the "mystery."
comment.author: @possumverde

comment.text: As someone with a bachelors in photography, im not surprised by the missing photo 509 at all. Ive had weird things happen before. Taken photos and you snap that perfect shot, you go to look at it on the computer and its just gone, its just not there, like you never took the photo. Tech isnt 100%, so I'm not surprised at all by a weird glitch and a missing photo. I also think she thought she heard something and started using the flash as a way to try to get attention. Either that or her friend was on the brink of death and got really desperate to maybe try to catch someone's attention with the flash, hoping a rescuer in the area will see it.
comment.author: @danadomino

comment.text:
If these girls were lost and died as a result of injuries why were only 10% and 5% of their remains found? Why were their remains "widely scattered," broken up and bleached? Medical examiners reported the bones were found clean, with no bite marks or scratches that would indicate that a predator or scavenger attacked at any point. Photographic evidence from the phone reportedly showed Kris laying down with blood on her temple. Why are larger bones and more remains not being found grouped together? It's not natural for the rapid fragmentation of bones over a short period of time. 

The killer(s) could have taken pictures of the murder site so that they could return to it later. Of all the things Lisanne would do why would she take a closeup photo of her injured or deceased friend in the middle of the night? Especially 2 days after she was injured or deceased. (The failed PIN attempts indicate someone wasn't able to get into Kris's phone after April 6. The photos were taken April 8th.) That is incredibly bizarre. Lisanne was apparently alive several days after Kris, why would she not leave any other type of message with her camera or phone? Why would she only take photos very late into the night if she was alive for days after?

Also why were the girls carrying a large mirror while hiking? Most young people use phones to look at themselves.

One more point. Kris's phone was used to take the night photos after there were already multiple failed attempts to put the PIN into the phone. There was also a single deleted photo numbered 509 which was taken in-between the daytime photos and the night photos. Is it even possible to delete a photo when there is a PIN code lock on the phone?
comment.author: @JMo2255

comment.text: vous bloqué sur 1 photo manquante mais je pense qu'il y avait plus de photo , il est possible qu'ils ai supprimé les photos et oublié de supprimé une photo et pour être sur de ne pas pouvoir récupéré les photos ils ont créé plein de photo pour écrasé définitivement les photos d'origine mais en contrôlant l’appareil via un pc il ce sont aperçu de l'erreur et on supprimé la photo oublier. Mais pour moi si ils ont fait autant de photos c'est qu'il y avais beaucoup de photos à caché.

comment.text: Coucou Horia, je connaissais déjà cette histoire mais tu m'as apporté de nouveaux petits éléments et de nouvelles réflexions dans cette histoire, en plus j'aime la façon dont tu racontes les histoires. Pour la théorie de la photo supprimée, je ne crois pas à la suppression de la photo par la police. Si jamais elles étaient dans la jungle, seule dans le noir et qu'elles tentaient d'interpeller un hélicoptère et qu'on voyait cet hélicoptère sur la photo, d'où la raison de sa suppression, je pense justement qu'elles auraient "bombardé" les photos pour les interpeller encore plus et donc de ce fait il n'y aurait pas eu une seule photo supprimée mais plusieurs. Pour moi les photos étranges dans la jungle le soir servaient juste d'éclairage pour qu'elles puissent marcher et les photos vers le ciel je pense étaient vraiment faites pour appeler à l'aide, sans succès. La photo de la chevelure de Kris est bizarre mais je ne vois ni bouche (comme tu le dis les cheveux ont l'air de venir par le droit donc bizarre cet emplacement de sois-disant bouche et nez), ni sang. Honnêtement je pense à un simple accident, les os confirment une chute de très haut, le fait que les os de Kris soit complètement nettoyé ça c'est bizarre mais comme tu l'as dit peut être que ça vient de l'ensoleillement intensif qu'ils ont pu subir, je ne sais pas. Que ce soit criminel ou accidentel, elles n'ont pas eu de chance et elles étaient là au mauvais endroit, au mauvais moment.
comment.author: @gwladysraulin1959

comment.text:
I think their Diaries are a huge clue. 2 girls who wrote in their diaries every day would have definitely left a message if they're trying to call for Emergency every day starting April 1st. When Lisanne skipped a few days, her next entry she provided all 3 dates and said "Of course I'll fill you in." That was just a few days before she went missing. Of course they would leave a message. 
The Emergency calls could have easily been placed by the abductors handling their phone. Told to call it around the same time everyday and they didn't worry because they know there is no reception there. 1 of the calls makes a signal for 2 seconds, so what do they do next? They turn the phone off 36 seconds later. Now why would they turn the phone off now that they finally made a connection? Maybe they feared they would be traced.
Also the night photos are very creepy because that photo of Kris' hair seems to be on purpose. Why only 1 photo of hair, and why Kris' hair? Because we know it's Kris' hair and we don't question it. If it was Lisanne's hair we would assume it's her but so many people have brown hair that maybe it wouldn't be. They took a photo of Kris' hair to confirm it's the 2 missing girls, and imo the rest of the photos is a tease to investigators basically saying "You'll never find them, and you won't find this spot. Not in this big jungle.".
The photo of the red hair is in focus, it's not blurry. Which means they took their time taking that photo. Every strand of hair is in focus so they definitely were not moving. We only see her hair and nothing else. Also for being in the jungle for a week, that is the cleanest hair. No dirt, no grass, no leaves, her hair doesn't even appear wet. Yet we are supposed to believe Panama saying it's an accident and they fell off a monkey bridge into a river? That's not even possible when you look at the photos taken in a dry location. The orbs are probably from the mist from a river nearby, but they aren't in the river.
We've got a suspect that could be investigated but nobody bothered. I'm talking about the tour guide who is suspicious in every single way. Let me ask you something, how would you feel if your tour guide showed up at your house if you skipped a tour with him? Wouldn't you be creeped out? What if you skip an appointment at the barber shop, do you think it's normal for a barber to show up at your house, drop everything he's doing to come look for you? 
He's a tour guide, he's not that important. If you skip a tour with him it's not a big deal. He runs a coffee farm too, meaning he dropped everything and ran around town looking for 2 girls? Seems odd to me. He even entered the home they were staying at on April 2nd and stayed for about a half an hour. He literally went into their house. Maybe they had a hangover or slept-in did he ever think of that? Or did he worry that they spoke to others about meeting him so he wanted to protect himself by appearing concerned? Since he's the only proof we have of the April 2nd meeting at 8am. It's all according to him.
Also with a mystery this big, isn't it odd that it also has 1 of the biggest coincidences? Or maybe because it's not a coincidence. I mean how the tour guide who was supposed to meet these 2 girls, also finds their foot. I mean what a coincidence. Even the reporter he talked to about it felt the same way. He talks about finding the foot behind the tree, and the reporter's 1st response is "So it was invisible?" because how do you just so happen to spot a shoe behind a tree in dense jungle full of foliage. His response was "No well if we didn't happen to look behind that tree at that exact moment walking down the path, we never would have seen it." WOW well wasn't that convenient.
Also they conveniently find the backpack after the reward money was raised to $30,000??? There are way too many coincidences in this 1 mystery to be considered just a coincidence. That tour guide knows a lot more I believe. Even if he didn't harm the girls himself, I think he knows exactly what happened to them.
Then the tour guide gives Kris Kremers' parents their own tour to retrace their steps. The mom points to a path and the tour guide is like "NO, NO!" not there, anywhere but there. comment.text:
I’m gonna say it. THIS WAS NO ACCIDENT. There was a third party involved, no question about it. Let me explain my view of this.
1. The girls bag contained neatly folded clothing, and everything seemed recently organized. The backpack was found neatly placed on a rock by a stream, out in the open, almost like it was put there intentionally. One  of the girls shorts were also found neatly folded as well. In their supposed situation, I highly doubt you would care about folding things and making them perfect.

2. The cameras’ night photos used flash. People assumed they were trying to light their way, but a camera flash is blinding in itself. Surely they couldn’t have seen at all. Your eyes have to adjust when introduced to light, and in the short span of a flash, there isn’t time for that, thus you are blinded anyway. 

3. There is a photo of the back of kris’s head, with what appears to be blood. If kris was in such shape, I doubt she would still be trekking on. They were thirsty, and weak. With injuries added to that, and they were dressed in skimpy shorts and tank tops, I doubt they kept going strong. If another person was involved, I think that because perhaps the girls were already dead, they took a picture of the back of kris’s head as not to raise suspicion that the girls weren’t the ones taking the photos. At first glance, it seems lizzane took the image of kris because it’s understood that they were together at the time. However, we never see anything of lizzane after the daytime pictures. The person assumed that because kris was “injured” she wouldn’t be taking the pictures, so the person decided against showing lizzane in any images.
 
4. There is a deleted image in the camera. In the girls situation, why would they worry about deleting images? Also, the missing image is the gap between the last daytime photo, and first night photo. This missing image may have captured something that the third party did not want police to see. It’s too suspicious.

5. Their skeletons were found, scattered and sun- bleached only 35 days after the last phone use? No. It takes at least a month for their skeletons to reach the state in which they were found. The girls have been dead longer. They probably died the first day, and the phones were used by the third party. Science can back this up, they didn’t survive in the jungle injured, hungry, and without water for 10 days. That just doesn’t happen.

comment.text: I can confirm, as an amateur photographer, that cameras name new photos regardless of the photos that were deleted (for instance if you take a photo and it's called 0010, and then deleted it, the next photo you take will be titled 0010, not 0011.) comment.text: Dude, my boyfriend and I LOVE this channel, but we have unanimously come to the conclusion that this is hocus pocus. Almost all of the "unusual" and "unexplainable" mysteries surrounding this case can reasonably be explained away by common happenings in missing hiker situations. For one thing, the friend that looks "worried" in some of the later photos, doesn't really look all that worried to me? Assuming for argument's sake that she is boasting a less-than-happy expression, that is likely because the photos are candid (which they definitely appear to be) and I don't know many people that can naturally flash an extravagant smile, such as those shown in the earlier posed photos, while being candidly photo'd. Not only this, but she's likely a lot more worn down at this point in the hike. Secondly, while it's true that emergency calls can be made without unlocking a smartphone, once a person is dehydrated they are really very disoriented and it would not be surprising if they had forgotten this knowledge, assuming the phone did have that capability and they were aware of that capability in the first place (I was pretty ditzy at 21...). Not only would they have been dehydrated, but it would seem that the owner of the phone had either perished or was close to it, which would definitely panic the living friend--making it even more likely that they would behave erratically and not be in the right mindset to 1. Remember the pin code (if their dying/dead friend had given it to them before) 2. Recall that emergency phone services are available without unlocking the phone. Also, we have no idea what the person trying to unlock phone was actually trying to achieve--maybe it was something that did require the phone to be unlocked. There's really no telling what a severely dehydrated and panicked lost hiker is thinking. The photos in the dark are definitely either one of the girls flashing for help or lighting their way in the dark. Photos from a digital camera should be retrievable even if they were deleted from the camera, so idk why investigators didn't try to retrieve them if there are deleted photos as was stated. Maybe the photos were one girl taking a photo of their deceased friend for documentation, but were then deleted because the girl changed her mind about having such a gruesome thing documented? Serious speculation on my part there, but it really could have been anything that was deleted. As for the remains potentially indicating foul play... it would be very very VERY strange for a "killer" to hold the girls hostage until they literally died from natural causes. Like, all evidence points to them dying slowly, making multiple concerted attempts over a lengthy span of time to contact help to no avail. I have no idea what the motive would be for a kidnapper or murderer to just tag along with the girls until they died. Their remains showing little to no decomposition could very well be evidence of scavenging animals picking the corpses clean. Given the sheer biodiversity of Panama, there are likely many animals around to take care of that job. Of course, the forensics would have to show signs of this, so if they don't then 🤷‍♀️ also any footprints left by animals would have been washed away after 70 days, though it is possible their remains washed into the river during a high water event and were carried downstream from the actual place of death anyway. Of course locals are going to say it's hard to get lost in that forest... they're locals! Not only that, but hikers go missing ALL THE TIME on well-marked and well-traveled trails. A fall or injury would exacerbate getting lost. I agree that some things are strange, like the clean cut to the leg if that is accurate. And the rolled up skin... though that one perplexes me as, surely investigators would have taken that to a lab for DNA testing? If another person rolled that skin up (or monkey or whatever) there would probably be some DNA trail. 70 days in a rainforest may have eliminated such data, though. The pristine backpack is pretty strange, but I'm betting the condition of the backpack is maybe exaggerated a little... bht still 🤷‍♀️ The best explanation is the most likely one. I get making stories out to have dramatic or creepy spins for content, but this just sounds like a really sad story of two friends getting lost in the Rainforest and dying with some odd twists thrown in the middle ☹
comment.author: @TheWorldofRobbie

comment.text:
They reached the summit an hour ahead of what they had planned and decided to go looking for waterfalls, though they had been advised not to. (They both had extensive search histories concerning the location of said waterfalls in the week leading up to their disappearance, but assured those who warned them not to look for them that they wouldn't... but they did end up with around two extra hours they weren't expecting to have by reaching the summit early...) The gullies they photographed themselves in were not all along their original path and have since been identified. As has the dirt trail they were on a week later. What most likely happened was that they realized they weren't going to be able ro make it back to the summit (and thus the only path back to town) before it got dark  and were going to have to spend the night on the mountain. In that gully area, the only cleared ground suitable for setting up any sort of makeshift camp would be one of the gullies themselves. They made their first attempts to contact help around an hour before dark which makes sense. The temperature was in the mid to upper 50's at night, and they were in shorts and tee shirts, so they would have wanted shelter. The debris formations they took pictures of themselves in front of would have seemed ideal for that. Such gullies are dangerous (especially before the rainy season is fully under way) since blockages can form and hold back water, leading to a very strong surge with debris down the mountain when the blockage gives. It likely rained that night, and they got hit by such a surge with nowhere to go inside the debris tunnel they were in. I've seen such surges, and they would definitely have been injured to some degree and washed along for a bit. Had one or both been carried to where the incline steepened, it would have led to significant injuries and no viable way back up.

They would have had to travel down the gully, which would have taken them to the river. There, they would have had water, but nowhere to really go (especially if one or more were injured) and would likely have decided to wait and hope a boat would go by (highly unlikely), or searchers would find them. You can go quite a while without food, but after about a week, you'd be pretty desperate. The dirt path they were on in their week later photos has since been identified via drone, and when you see it, things start to make sense. It ran along a gully and from the bottom likely looked like it went all the way up. It didn't. About halfway up, it essentially ran into a wall of dense foliage with nowhere to go. That would have been the last of their energy and the point at which at least one was likely to more or less give up. They probably went back down the mountain to their water source to wait for help, one died, and the other was too weak to make it for much longer. The only way back up would have been a gully, and by then, there was likely a good bit of water flowing down, so the survivor would have had no options. Nature took care of things from there.

The concerned looks on their faces in some of the gully photos were likely the result of their realizing they weren't going to get back in time but might as well take the pictures since that's what got them into the mess in the first place. While the night photos were likely just them using the flash as a flashlight. The head photo makes sense if you have an injured half starved person going up an incline with the person behind them taking periodic pictures to see where they were going. A stumble and fall would bring the person behind down as well, and a photo could easily have been snapped in the process. The photos aimed upwards were probably an attempt to signal a drug plane heard but not seen (as they run without lights) which regularly fly over that area at night. (Somewhere down there, there's probably such a pilot who saw those flashes but can't say anything about it because then they would have to explain why they were flying over that area at night with no flight plan registered anywhere.)

The physical evidence all makes sense as remains and items will get washed into the river during the rainy season. Also, the people in the village were not informed of the missing hikers until quite a while afterward and their stories as to where the evidence was found and it's initial condition were different depending on which villager was asked. They had probably already found the stuff, cleaned it, and were using some of it when they found out, and just threw it all back together to turn it in. The phones and camera were damaged and not in working condition with quite a bit of garbled data on them. The investigators were simply able to retrieve some of the data from them. The oddities of missing photos etc. could easily be explained by that. The "famous" missing photo had a registry entry but no trace of the actual image file. That can happen from a glitch. The investigators merely said that the only way it could have manually been removed was via PC, not that it had been removed so. Anyone smart enough to remove the image file would have purged the registry entry as well and attempted to adjust the numbering to completely cover it... or just destroyed the camera (and phones) to make sure there was no evidence to begin with. The foot in the shoe is perfectly natural when it comes to human remains. Shoes slow the decomp process down which leads to the feet eventually falling off. Shoes are somewhat buoyant, so if they end up in the water, they'll travel along. The "sun bleached" bones were most likely not truly or fully sun bleached. A couple of species of the last stage decomp beetles in the area excrete phosphates as they do their work. Such phosphates easily and quickly leech into the bone and turn it very white (they even have a slight glow in the dark for a bit after prolonged exposure to sunlight.)

I think that covers most of the "mystery."

comment.text:
Il y a un élément TROUBLANT que tu n'as pas cité dans ta vidéo : la prise d'angle totalement inhabituelle des 90 photos suivant leur disparition. En effet, la hauteur, l'angle et le style photographique sont des paramètres propres au photographe, un peu somme sa signature, son écriture. 

Autre élément accablant NON MENTIONNÉ : les appels au 112 et 911 sont passés à des intervalles très régulières !!! Entre 10h et 13h, 3 jours d'affilée ! Comme si les appels étaient programmés.. dans ce genre de situation, c'est presque impossible d'appeler à ces horaires aussi réguliers. 

N'y avait t-il pas d'empruntes sur l'appareil photo? Les téléphones ? Avoir des gants dans une jungle, ça me paraît un peu trop prévoyant.

De plus, si de la chaux a été découverte sur un os, les doutes sont levés.

Autre élément prouvant le meurtre est le dépôt du sac en parfait état et sec plus au bord de la rivière, en plus de la photo 509 supprimée délibérément après coup. Le sac aurait été retrouvé en aussi mauvais état que les corps, les corps ont eux été jetés au lieu du sac. 

Enfin, les autorités panaméennes ont  délibérément étouffé l'affaire pour ne pas attiser les tensions avec les cartels locaux. A rappeler que le pays est sujet à la corruption, et un intérêt économique incontestable incite les autorités à opter pour la facile option de l'accident. 

Dernier point : la photo prise des cheveux de la victime a été prise dans le but de prouver quelle était encore vivante "entière". 

Rappellez vous des photos prises par les deux jeunes femmes avant le meurtre : pourquoi aurait elle prit une photo de la tête de son amie?! Et avec un angle aussi rapproché? La raison est évidente : essayer de prouver quelle était en vie, les agresseurs se sont trahis en prenant ces photos à l'angle trop différent, en déposant le sac, en dissolvant les tissus et os à l'aide de putréfacteurs chimiques.

Paix aux âmes de ces deux jeunes femmes qui peuvent garder l'âme haute pour leur esprit humanitaire et leur dévouement. La vie se chargera de ces tueurs, sous hommes, dont le karma rattrapera les âmes.

comment.text: Ive watched a few videos on this case and one other thing I found odd was that there were a few people who had reported seeing the girls leave/make it out of the trail, but for some reason the police didn't follow these leads and wrote them off as mistaken identity. I think there are a lot of things that point to foul play, but Kris's bones being chemically bleached and Lisanne's foot being cut off with a clean cut are the main pieces of evidence that don't line up to the authorities story. Authorities eventually wrote off the crime as the girls being lost and dying of natural causes, specifically claiming that they believed the girls fell off a cliff into a body of water. And that the water carried their remains all over the trail. However, their bones had no scratches, dents, cuts, chips, or any damage that would show their bones being carried. Kris's bones were found to have been missing tendons that would take years to decompose. Her bones were completely clean and bleached. If animals had found their bones and eaten what ever was on them, there would be bite marks or some type of remittance to show this. I always found the pictures taken at night very unsettling because we will never know who took those photos. Specifically the one picture of the back of Kris's hair/head. For someone who was walking around in the jungle for days, her hair looks completely clean and kept. The angle is very odd and either looks like she is lifting her hair up from underneath or that she is laying on the floor. As creepy as it is to say, she may not even be alive in that photo. I feel like those photos have something more behind them. Some have said that they believed they were using the flash to see their way, but this doesn't make sense. Some of the pictures look like they are taken near a cliff,  and some don't make sense.  Why would they be concerned about deleting a photo? Why did Kris continue to enter the pin to her own phone wrong several times? Why did their taxi driver take it upon himself to go to the home they were staying in, stay in their room for 30 minutes unattended, and only let the police know hours after starting his own search for them? Seems he gave himself enough time to cover things up, plant evidence, and hide the true events that took place there. If I was lost in the jungle, id be using the night time to rest. No way in hell would I be wondering around in the dark all night where there are wild animals, cliffs and bodies of water all over the place. Id rather sit under a tree until the sun comes back up and I can see where I'm going. Also, the rolled up piece of Lisanne's skin is odd because your skin is one of the first things to be decomposed. Also, Lisanne's foot was severed clean, but there was no blood anywhere? From what I know about that, if there is no blood splatters, drops or anything it indicates that the crime happened somewhere else and the remains and belonging were dropped off/planted. I think Panama officials failed these girls. I think that they cared more about how 2 potential murders would affect the reputation of Panama as a tourist attraction than they did about actually finding out what happened to them. They knew that saying these girls had been murdered would cause people to not visit and travel there, which is one of Panama's main source of income. All the evidence points to something more sinister, and to me, they only had one suspect that I believe had something to do with there deaths. The taxi driver.

comment.text:
In the disappearance of these two Dutch girls, there are two situations that I don't understand and I believe that need a more careful analysis:
1-If in the first two calls to the Dutch emergency number, they were already under the control of kidnappers, why didn't the criminals take the phones, the camera and all their belongings?

This doesn't make any sense! No offenders with murderous or sexual intentions would risk being photographed by their victims, or even risk the girls calling the police or leaving a message recorded on their cell phones for when they are found by the authorities.

2- Why don't you have any attempt to call 911 during the night?

What would be the worst moment for two girls from an urban environment, lost in the middle of a tropical jungle?
Do you agree with me that this worst moment would be to spend the night in the forest?! Exhausted, cold, with animals moving on the ground, animal movement in the dark forest, a plague of insects, rain spray, hunger, thirst and darkness everywhere. This would undoubtedly be the time when they would most try to connect to an emergency number, but they didn't.

Trying to explain these two situations, the best way to harmonize was as follows:
Lisanne and Kris decided on their own, to continue the trail past the viewpoint, when they realized they couldn't make it back before nightfall, or because they really got lost and disoriented, they decided to make the first two calls in the late afternoon of April 1st. . Without success, they must surely have screamed for help. They were certainly answered and rescued by someone who heard them both scream, or someone who somehow passed them on the trail. This would explain why the girls did not attempt to call an emergency number during the night, that is, they felt safe to be accompanied by someone they believed to be trustworthy and well intentioned.
After that, they certainly went with that someone, to some nearby property, where they continued to be deceived by lies that reassured them, but that at dawn and after a night's sleep, they always tried to make another emergency call, until the cell phone battery has discharged.
It was at that moment that this someone realized that they were totally incommunicado and certainly decided to attack and take their belongings that were all inside the backpack.
From then on, all the evil that befell the girls began.

In my opinion, between the moment the last cell phone ran out of charge and the dawn of the 8th, Kris Kremers was killed, so in the photos taken on the 8th, only the hair of a lifeless body of Kris appears, trying to simulate a disappearance, with them lost in the night trying to signal their position in the woods and kris dead in Lisanne's arms (who doesn't appear in the photos) as it's the killer planting false evidence, not Lisanne!

As the pieces of Lisanne Froon's skin were found in mid-June, in an initial state of decomposition, this shows that Lisanne was killed in early June and was under the control of this someone who killed her, for about 60 days. She was the last to die.

Note 1: Seeing the holes in Kris' Jeans, it shows that her dead body was dragged a short distance, where it was thrown. That is, this may indicate that the place where Kris and Lisanne were killed and the bodies were subjected to a chemical treatment for dismemberment and then concealment, are very close to each other, and may be in the vicinity of this property where they felt "safe" .

Note 2: Kris' boot found, was it clean and without any remains inside? No animal in the forest, would be interested in carrying a leather boot in her mouth! It's not food! That's how the animals would see this boot, any object, they would have smelled it and gone. That boot was taken to the forest by the killer.

Note 3: The police know of more evidence, maybe even the photo that was deleted. At the very least, they want to make some strategic use.

Conclusion: Kris Kremers and Lisanne Froon, were held captive in an environment they thought was safe, were killed, stripped naked, with the bodies being dismembered by some chemical process as yet unknown. Some dismembered parts, along with the girls' boots, clothes and backpack with all the girls' belongings, were deliberately abandoned along the straight-line trail to create false leads and simulate that the girls died of hunger and thirst after getting lost in the deep in the forest.

The death of these innocent girls touched me a lot! This is my small contribution to unravel their deaths and thus lead to a punishment, the possible murderer and the possible collaborators.

Fortaleza-CE, Brazil.

I very much hope that Jesus Christ will comfort Kris and Lisanne's parents.

I actually have previously watched a documentary about this case but decided to watch MrBallen's video just to see how he told the story. There are a few pieces of information I want to add from what I remember from the documentary. 

I remember from the documentary that they had mentioned that the area they wanted to hike in was very dangerous, not just the conditions of the hike but the possibility of other people being inside the dense vegetation. There apparently had been other murders not far from where they were hiking that were "unrelated". The theory with the photos being taken in the dark was done so the girls could see where they were going, they were using the light from the flash to see where to go which is why the photos seem very strange because they weren't actually taking photos, just using the light (OR their murderer took the photos to confuse investigators). 

Another part of the story is the failed attempts to log in to the phone. It was theorized that the girl who owned the phone fell down into a ravine and the other girl was trying to get into her phone to call for help but didn't know her passcode, and that's why there were so many failed attempts. OR their murderer tried to throw off investigators by making it appear that they were still alive after they had been taken or murdered. 

Their remains were also extremely strange and suspicious. The only parts of Kris that were found were part of her pelvic bone and one of her rib bones with no flesh attached, completely clean and bleached. Traces of phosphorous were found in the bones, which when samples were taken of the area the bones were found, no traces of phosphorus were found, meaning they were intentionally chemically cleaned with phosphorous. Also, in addition to there being no blood found (the water would have washed away some blood but bone marrow is the longest surviving tissue and the last to decompose), the bones were found on the shore, and since bones are denser than water, they would have surely sunk and gotten caught in some rocks in the "snake-like" river they were found on the bank of. Instead, they were placed in the same general area as the other remains (which is very unlikely due to the shape of the river). 

For Lisanne, they found a chunk of flesh that still had larvae in it, and appeared to be in the "second stage" of decomposition, which is radically different from the state in which Kris's bones were. Also from Lisanne, they found her femur, shin bone, and left foot (which was still inside her hiking shoe), all with flesh attached and bone marrow inside. The cuts were clean and not jagged like you would expect if it was an animal or an accident. I'm not an expert, this is just what I remember plus some quick googling to make sure I said the right things. Overall, definitely does not appear to be an accident.
comment.author: @Dee-us3jg

comment.text:

– Multiple attempts to unlock the phone: Maybe one girl died earlier and the surviving one was trying to unblock her phone not knowing the password
