If someone was after them they'd write a description. They left zero information on their phones basically. I mean you want to conserve the battery but there are a few instances where you leave a note, a deathbed confession basically. After all those days of the phones not working I'd expect you'd give up on making calls and just explain what happened and tell your parents you're sorry or whatever. But if you killed two women and wanted them to look as if they were lost in the jungle then I guess you could make it look as if you were trying to be found each day. And if you don't want to lose tourism you're going to say the murder victims were simply hikers that fell. Taking photos to leave a message but not leaving an actual message? I mean why not write in the sand and photograph that? You want to focus on being found but eventually you want people to know why you died.
comment.author: @wheelmanstan

comment.text:
It was the guy who told them about the pond. They 100% returned back to their starting point. Many people saw them come back, and greeted them. Upon their return they had a conversation with a guy who suggested they go to a certain pond, a swimming hole. There is a picture of him on the internet standing over two prone, apparently unconscious girls -- the girls are  both posed exactly the same, hands folded between tucked legs, on their sides, eyes closed -- he stands forefront/over them with a club, or a roughly hewn bat. The picture is taken at the same pond the guy told them to visit. 

Just google "pictures of pond the guy told about in kris kremers and lisanne froon" and you'll see his pic. Search more and you'll find the two girls pic. 

Both girls' -- Lisanne and Kris-- parents flew to the location and traced their path - it was literally impossible for them to get lost and there was nowhere to fall from. No cliffs, no danger, in fact, you COULDN'T stray from the path. This is according to both sets of parents, eyewitnesses to the nature of that path. And so many people saw her return anyway, so it was after that, when they got back. 

I believe the night photos were not taken by the girls, that they were planted to make it look like they'd gotten lost. Note how their faces are never portrayed in the night photos, not once. Because they weren't the ones using the camera at that point in time. 

I believe they were lured to the pond by dude and killed, their belongings variously kept/scattered in different locations to further muddy the waters.
comment.author: @readdeeply9278

comment.text: Initially I thought this was a tragic accident. However, the deeper I get into this case the more I believe it wasn't. I think something happened to those girls and it started shortly after picture 508 was taken. To be precise just before 16.39 when the first emergency phone call was made (and shortly after second call). No more emergency calls made until 14 hours later. The missing 509 photo which would have been taken during this time. Unusual phone records. The 77 wrong PIN & SIM logins.( Not down to confusion as initially thought, because purposeful actions were taken like swiping the screen and opening the control panel.. So who was trying to use that phone?). Strange photos taken in the night. State of the backpack. No bodies ever recovered apart from a foot and pelvic bone. The different state of decay those bones were in and where they were found (miles away). The Special Forces & local searches that found absolutely nothing. Far too many inconsistencies and unanswered questions. One of the most mysterious cases I've come across in 30 years. Maybe that local guide knows more?

comment.text:
I’m definitely torn on this one. There are some odd pieces about this case that make it confusing to determine foul play vs. natural death. My theory:

The girls had no plans for the day they went missing so they decided to go check out the trail. Maybe they really enjoyed hiking and wouldn’t mind doing that two days in a row, or they figured if it was a simple hike they could cancel the following day’s scheduled hike and do something else. I’ve taken many vacations and this seems very likely. They could have got lost looking for the dog if he ran off..which is why the dog made it back home that night but the girls got lost further off the trail. The one girl most likely fell off the monkey bridge and into the water below..she died from the fall and that’s why after decomposition her foot was severed from her leg and still in her boot. Animals got to her and that explains the somewhat scattered bones. The second girl tried to phone emergency services multiple times and tried to make it as long as she could alone in the wild by herself, but she eventually died herself from starvation, dehydration, and the elements. 

However, a few things to question and note: 
1. The camera’s random 90 photos were taken 10 days after their disappearance, and found 10 weeks after that. 87 of the 90 photos were black, and only three showed the environment. Did the one girl not know the lense was on? Did she try to use it to see where she was going but was disoriented from 10 days of being lost and dying? 

2. Why were the one girl’s bones bleached? Is there a natural explanation for this that hasn’t been discussed? It’s very confusing. 

3. There are rumors that their taxi driver that day was also found dead months later. Coincidence or another factor in this case? 

4. It’s odd to me that they would just keep going further into unknown forest..the trail they began on was popular with both tourists and locals..it’s odd that NO one on the trails would have seen or heard them in all of those 10 days. It could have been must easier for them to find some indication of where they were in the daylight. 

Really odd but I don’t necessarily get a murder vibe from this one..but more likely a sad tragic series of events being lost and stranded in the foreign forest.

comment.text: I think the vast majority of evidence leads to them getting lost. The night photos taken on the 8th was the first night that the search group stayed in the jungle. I don't think this was a coincidence, i believe the girls perhaps noticed some light in the distance where the searchers were camped and tried to draw attention with the cameras flash. Expert analysis of the photos has determined that most of them can be overlayed to create a composite which shows that the camera was being pointed towards a specific direction. I'm guessing in the direction of the rescue searchers camp. Once i discovered that information, i had less doubt that they simply got lost. I find it very unlikely that a third party would sit in the jungle and take dozens of photos over the course of hours at a specific spot in the distance to fabricate some kind of evidence to throw of the investigators. It should also be mentioned that most of the photos in their RAW state, appeared black. It was only after the investigators adjusted the brightness on a computer that the images could be made out. This also helps to debunk a third party taking photos theory because they wouldn't have known what images they were capturing, to them it would just be black image after black image. Hardly something you would use as fake evidence.

comment.text:
A couple things to clarify:
1) The backpack was actually originally found dirty and wet, with the investigators waiting for the electronics to dry before searching them. The claim that it was found clean seems to stem from a misinterpreted article.
2) People have recreated the same camera model skipping a photo number by deleting it directly on the camera, by having it fall, or having it sustain water damage.

I think they either got lost or slipped and got injured or somehow immobilized. The "suspicious" stuff actually convinces me that foul play didn't happen. Manually deleting photos, faking 112 calls, scattering body parts in the jungle, etc. Seems like an insane amount of effort and risk when it would be much easier and safer to make sure that bag and those bodies were never found.
comment.author: @kevlarcardhouse252

comment.text:
After watching The island with bear grylls which coincidentally was filmed in panama I think the most logical explanation is that they got lost. If you Google el mirador del pianista boquete panamá you can find multiple traveler photos of the trail. At the time they went on the trail there weren’t any signs or markers to indicate that the trail had ended. The girls didn’t speak Spanish and they weren’t from the area. The trail doesn’t have signs or a post that indicate which way back to town. After exploring beyond the mirador for close to 3 hours, the girls panicked when they realized they were going in circles and it was getting dark soon. 

The jungle is pitch dark and there are tons of predators which include snakes, spiders, jaguars, cougars, coyotes. Plus reports at the time indicated that rain had slowed down the rescue efforts. My best guess is they tried to climb to high ground in order to get a cellular signal. 

The night pictures showed what appears to look like S.O.S sign with white paper. The camera appears to have been used as a flashlight as there was proof of pictures taken with flash every 9 seconds standing in the same spot. The night pictures also indicate they were on high ground overlooking a steep drop below. 

At some point it appears they tried to follow the culebra river until they reached a town. Unfortunately the culebra river runs to the Caribbean side which would take them farther away from boquete. 

I don’t believe that they were killed by a gang of local boys that followed them into the jungle because it would be easier to dig a grave and bury the girls and all their belongings and ensure they vanished without a trace instead of turning phone off and on 77 times on several days and taking 100’s of photos in order to make it appear the girls were lost in the jungle. Lastly, it doesn’t make sense to fold all the girls belongings and put camera in waterproof bag so that someone can find it later.

comment.text: Maybe the 77 password errors was the other girl trying to enter the phone, but not knowing the password. This would fit the theory that one of them was lost, injured, or in danger. It makes more sense than if an assailant was trying to enter the phone. If I was an assailant, I would not waste my time trying to figure out a password of a stranger. If I was a friend though, I may feel that i know enough about my friend to guess their password. The friend may have felt she had a chance by trying middle names, pet names, birthdates, etc. To me, trying to find a password 77 times is something her friend would try rather than an attacker. Also, I believe the photos could've been taken by the friend. On my phone, there are two options you can click before logging in. They are 1) take a photo 2) emergency calls. The two icons are right next to eachother. I think it's plausible that while she was trying to use the call button, or just desperately trying to unlock the phone by clicking a bunch of buttons, that a few accidently pictures could be taken.

comment.text:
There is a 3d model expert who worked in forensics that specifically worked on time of day analysis. He got the coordinates of the sun on the 1st of April and their local coordinates of the photo location at the summit. Also he used directions Lisanne was facing in the photos and used 3d modeling and lighting to determine the time the photos could have been taken and he concluded around 1pm. He showed how shadowing would have looked at 2, 3 and 4pm as well as before 1pm and suggested the time had to be near 1pm.
     That matches the camera meta data. I think witnesses are often mistaken and it happens a lot in cases. People don't always look at the clock to determine in memory events. I think the meta data is correct that they reached the summit at 1pm and were dropped off around 11am by the Taxi.

comment.text: Someone snapped the 90ish photos to fill the memory card.  That way the deleted photo's data would have been overwritten.  When you delete a photo, it doesn't delete the photo itself, it only deletes the reference in the file allocation table to where in memory the photo starts and ends in the memory block.  The actual photo data is only destroyed when the memory is occupied with new data.

comment.text: Brilliant analysis! Extremely interesting interpretation of awkward evidence such as the pattern in the emergency calls. In a comment I have posted elsewhere I sketch an explanation of the change in the girls photo documentation pattern after photo 508 on the simple basis that after this photo they just turned back and started descending the trail. Therefore no more photos were needed since the locations had been documented on their way up. The time frame of them turning back after 508 fits perfectly with the time of day they would want to return from the trail before it gets dark (arrival at the root of the trail at 4:30pm the latest, when sun sets at 6:30pm on April 1st) and fits with first emergency calls being made shortly after arriving at the start of the path. I think it would be worth considering whether the girls had pre arranged to be picked up by taxi or the guys off road vehicle at the start of the trail around the time they intended to return ( 3:30ish to 4:30ish)... A pre arranged vehicle would make sense as the signal in the jungle was bad. This pre arrangement would have given the predators time to prepare the actual foul play plan. Your explanation about the first two emergency calls is brilliant and we can picture ourselves doing the same in an odd though as yet not threatening situation. They way you bring in the narrative the various protagonists, their motives and participation is ingenious just as the way you explain why the emergency calls throughout had this quirky pattern. Amazing job!! But, how do you explain the photos in the jungle and particularly the one with Cris hair???? If taken by the perpetrators during the move to the cave, why was the picture with Cris hair was taken? And do you think she was alive at the time? There's sth in the way the look of the hair almost defeats gravity that emits a sense it was taken when Cris was not in life anymore. Would love to see more from you on this case!!!

comment.text:
Au sujet de la photo 509 supprimée, je me dis que si quelqu'un voulait éviter de laisser des traces, et bien il n'avait qu'à conserver la carte SD avec lui et / ou la détruire complètement. Pourquoi la remettre dans l'appareil? Pour éviter des soupçons? Effacer les preuves complètement est plus plausible comme avenue selon moi.

Donc au final, je me demande s'il n'y aurait pas eu en effet un "glitch" ou bogue avec la caméra pour expliquer cette absence, probablement en effaçant une image directement dans la caméra.

Étant très connaissant dans le domaine de la photographie (j'ai fait plusieurs contrats professionnels mais ça n'a jamais été mon métier principal), j'ai régulièrement été prévenu par des collègues professionnels de ne jamais effacer une photo directement dans la caméra. De toujours attendre que la carte SD soit dans l'ordinateur pour le faire. 
La raison étant le risque accru de corruption des fichiers. Ça ne m'est jamais arrivé mais quand on lit sur le sujet ça semble être vrai et bien réel comme risque. Donc je reste perplexe à considérer ce fait comme preuve indéniable de manipulation par un tiers. Possible, mais pas 100% certain.

J'ai déjà supprimé par erreur des photos et j'ai utilisé le logiciel fourni par la compagnie de la carte SD et dans certains cas j'ai pu retrouver la ou les photos supprimées par erreur. 

Par contre je me demande si une fois la carte formatée, si ce genre de logiciel est encore capable de retrouver des images perdues...

comment.text:
Here is what I have concluded based on the known evidence and my own investigation of this tragic matter.

1. That area has wildlife and woods but it's not the amazon folks. There are farms  nearby that path, pasture,  etc. They did not get lost.  
2. I reject the idea that the two were eaten or killed by wild animals even though Panama does have jaguars. I base this conclusion on the fact that the dog on loan to them returned to its original owner . Any predator animal would have killed the dog defending them , first.  
3. There are Fincas in the area. Based on the night photos, I do believe the women were being stalked.  Perhaps they thought if thry took photos in the direction of the sounds made by the person or persons following them, he would flee . 
It is possible there existed a photo of the murderer (s) which was deleted  by the culprits.
4. The persons of interest should be, in no particular order,  the jilted Guide, someone who lives on or owns one of the nearby Finca houses  who might have encountered them and invited them over gorgeous a meal or guarroom or lemon ade.
5. I do not believe the photo of the head of  blond hair belongs to either woman. It might not be that of a woman. Why take such a photo? 
6. Given the placement of the various body  parts  and the fact money  ( some of it) was found along with the cell phones and camera and other items , I believe these were " arranged ". 
7. At some weeks after their death,  the animals did eventually come to the various locations to eat them as the foot found in one boot may indicate. 
8. This was made to look like the two got lost by the culprits who fid them in. 
9.  Notice, I say culprits,  plural, but it was only 1 man if the killer had both at gunpoint . 
10. A man or a small group of 2 -3 men may have been rejected by the 2 women whereupon they were murdered.  This was not a simple
 robbery unless it had gone terribly wrong. 
11.The police should visit every Finca and work hand in the area . They may have been invited to get a bite to eat only to discover once inside that they were going to be robbed or sexualay assaulted or sadistically killed. 
Not an accident.  Not lost and starved to death. Not attacked by wild animals. They either met up with a Panamanian they recognized from a prior encounter who stalked them or ...someone along the famous path how lived nearby murdered them in cold blood and then took great pains to make it look like  it was not a robbery,  not a sexual assault, and/ or  not a murder. 

The dog returned .There has to be a reason why she took a photo  picture of a person with blond hair. 

Hope this helps your investigation.

comment.text: I really enjoyed your analysis of the evidence. It was well-thought, well-reasoned, and objective. The biggest question for me is the state of the remaining bones and tissue. I understand some bones were separated. What body parts/sections were found intact? In what position? And were skulls found? Could they have detected any chemical/artificial bleaching through testing? The mere question surrounding photo 509 establishes foul play. Photo 509 could only have been deleted manually with a computer that had specialized software. Ergo, either the perp(s) happened to have a charged laptop with this software on their person; or, the memory card was taken, the photo deleted, and the card returned to the camera in the backpack in the jungle; or, the photo was deleted after discovery. Deletion after discovery seems the most probable. Especially when you consider the fact that they framed what is clearly probable homicide as nothing more than a tragic drowning accident. If they can unabashedly claim that an apple is a banana, then they can certainly stoop to deleting an unfavorable photo. Great coverage!

comment.text:
THIS IS MY EXPLANATION. Tell me what you think:

1) The girls leave the trail and get lost.
2) Some local notices that the two girls are lost. Someone starts following them with bad intentions (Organ trafficking? Mere Violence? It doesn't matter)
3) The girls get more and more lost deep into the jungle.
4) The girls fall and injure themselves (one or both doesn't matter). The bad guy (or guys) gets closer.
5) At night, the girls take photos hoping to be spotted perhaps by an airplane. They start realizing someone is following them. They hear a sound in the forest. They shoot a picture to light the forest: in THIS PHOTO the bad guy is distinguishable (but the girls DON'T SEE HIM in the moment). They keep taking pictures hoping to attract attention (33 photos taken at 2 minutes intervals!)
6) The assailant decides to attack, kills the girls, and takes their backpack.
7) The assailant dismembers the bodies and scatters them (maybe as he did several times in the past)

— Important: The assailant does not sell the tourists' belongings nor exchange or use the girls' $83. This would have raised suspicions.

BUT HERE COMES THE TWIST!

8) The international search begins. The $30,000 REWARD is announced. This attracts the bad guy's attention. The girls backpack could be the way to get the reward.
9) The bad guy checks the camera SD card. He FINDS THE PHOTO in which he is visible and he decides to delete that photo. Then he arranges the unexpected discovery of the backpack (probably in agreement with whoever would have found it and thus collected the reward. That was the plan!).
10) The backpack is found perfectly preserved (but with THE PHOTO missing). 

— Additionally, the 3 guys who died accidentally in the following year were potential witnesses or accomplices.

Everything seems to perfectly match. No mysteries.
What do you think?

BTW: in this documentary they managed to interview the girl who found the backpack. She complained about the fact that she found the backpack but her family didn't receive any reward. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OA430_4VJ_Y
comment.author: @Marco.e.Mara.official

comment.text:
Points that contradict the theory that they just got lost:

1) the backpack -- it was found 70 days after the girls' disappearance, beside a river bank 15 km away from the pianista trail. The lady who found it said she was at the same spot the day before but didn't see any backpack there. The backpack was NOT wet -- it was in pristine condition and the items inside were dry and appeared untouched. The phones and digital camera were in there, so it becomes difficult to see how the girls could've been the ones taking the pictures and calling emergency services in the jungle for 11 days, and yet the backpack doesn't get wet or dirty, and somehow makes a long journey on its own without getting wet. 

2) Lisanne's severed left foot was found in her hiking boot, and the cut was clean -- This disproves any animal attack theory and shows a human being cut off her foot. Unless Pokemon are real and a Scyther jumped out and cut her foot off, then it was a human. It can't be argued that an animal could have done that, plus the boot was clean and still tied to her foot, with no sign of scratches or claw marks

Honestly, I don't see how anyone can believe they just got lost given the above 2 points. Ok let's tack on some more for goal differential :P

3) Pictures -- I'm hoping people have watched/read other things about this case, to gather more details. The daytime pictures and nighttime pictures tell completely different (albeit incomplete) stories. 

Timeline: they start their hike on April 1st. Yikes, I didn't even notice that was April Fool's, ugh. 

-> daytime pictures - The girls are smiling. These are the ones at the foot of the trail, along it and leading up to them reaching the peak where I wish they had been able to turn back. In the strange pictures of Kris beside the stream of water and crouched by the bushes, she's not smiling at all and some believe at this point they were either kidnapped or had run into another group and knew they were dangerous.

 These initial pictures were taken before 1:30-2:00pm, so that refutes the taxi driver saying he dropped them off at that time. Nope, he might've just misremembered but this notion that they started their hike at 2pm is simply false. MORE on that taxi driver in a bit ....

> nighttime pictures - After 2pm on April 1st, no one used the camera for 7 days. It just doesn't make sense, if they were alone and simply lost, to not have a SINGLE picture of them, or anything in the daytime for that matter. But then on April 8th, someone took more than 90 photos in less than 3 hours - those hours were between 1am-4am. This is where the "they just got lost" camp suggests that these photos were meant to light up the area so they could see their surroundings, perhaps signal an airplane or search party, or perhaps scare off an animal they (or rather just she, by this point) might have heard. I have to admit, whyy would kidnappers be out at 1-4am taking pictures though? Best chance to not be seen as they make it look like the girls took the pictures in the jungle? Oh, I dunno. But then again, WHY was there 0 camera activity for 7 days?

Then there's the deleted photo and this one's a mammoth. Keep in mind that pictures were taken on a digital camera, not their phones. A computer must be used to fully erase a photo, and the Canon company itself confirmed this. It makes a strong argument that the girls managed to get a picture of something or someone incriminating, and whoever kidnapped them (* cough Feliciano Gonzales) had to have deleted the picture. 

4) Phones -- alright so on the first day, April 1st, the first emergency call to 112 was placed just after 4:30pm. Then a call was placed to 911 but didn't get through. Then phones turned off for 14 hours. Again, why? If they were lost and had their phones, how do they both go 14 hours without having their phone on? 

In total, they made about 80 calls. On day 5 (April 5th) LIsanne's phone died. Kris's phone stayed on until day 11 but between April 7th-10th Kris's phone was off/had no activity. It was turned on again, for the last time, at 10:51am on April 11th. It was turned off exactly an hour later at 11:51am, and this was the end of any phone activity. 

On April 6th, there were several attempts to enter an incorrect code. There were dozens of attempts up until April 11th. The girls obviously would have exchanged pass codes so it's very unlikely that Lisanne would've been locked out of Kris's phone. Plus, they didn't need a pass code to make an emergency call so investigators concluded it was unlikely to have been Lisanne trying to enter the code. The girls hadn't called home or the place they were staying, or anything other than emergency services in those 11 days so that seemed a bit strange. Why "dozens" of attempts to enter a phone, unless it was kidnappers looking for photos or something before they plant the phones in the backpack and leave them by the river. 

5) Tour guide / gang members 
Oh I gotta wrap this up. No one's reading anyway but I can't sleep so let's write until the eyes get heavy haha. Okay but yeah, let's go over some of these characters.

Feliciano Gonzales - the tour guide
Internet sleuths like me believe he's our guy. He basically IS a red flag, everything that he does. The girls were supposed to meet with Feliciano but they didn't. So after the girls went missing, he went over to the place they were staying and was in the girls' room for 30 minutes. There wasn't a door key in the backpack that was found, which doesn't make sense. Then of course it's Feliciano who spotted the boot with Lisanne's severed foot in it, and other bones. 33 bones were discovered, one pair of jean shorts, and one shoe from each of the girls. Then there was a rolled up ball of human skin. Then you look at Feliciano's tripadvisor reviews online and the one where he threatens a woman with a machete sticks out. Machete, clean cut above the ankle, hmm. OH, and then the suspicious deaths. Over 10 people connected to the case have died, including 4 member of the Los gang. The one gang member who survived? Henri Elizas Gonzales, Feliciano's son. Alright. 

Taxi driver -- named Leonardo Gonzales -- drove the girls to la pianista, told police he saw a pickup truck near where he dropped the girls off. He was found dead in a river, 7 months after the girls' disappearance.

Gang member 1 - Osman Velezuales (23 years old) - died April 4th (3 days after the girls' disappearance). 

2 - Juan Rivera Miranda (24)
3 - Jorge Murgas (23)
4 - Adonis Henriberto (23)

One was drowned in a shallow pool, one hit and run, and I forget the other. I'm tired, still need to look up another supposed suspect named Plineo Montenegro. 

But yeah, again no one will have read this but forgive the long rant, anyway. This case just has so many strange elements to it. I mean, the girls actually had a compass, a solar power bank, and a knife in their room. They obviously would've taken these if they planned to go on a long hike, which further makes me believe they were intercepted at some point on the trail. 

It just seems obvious that there was foul play involved. Foul play's a euphemism for what Lisanne and Kris went through, and I can't see any way they just got lost. Again they didn't pack much, they didn't take any daytime photos after the first 2 hours of their hike, the condition of the bone fragments, the knowledge of gang/police/government corruption in Panama, all of it. If they were lost, wouldn't they have tried to mark where they've been? It's dense jungle but even little pieces of clothing tied to a tree could be seen by people searching. What about trying to make SOS signs out of rocks or sticks?> Or at least make piles of random sticks and brush so you'll know you've been there before, and people searching can tell a human made those piles. 

I dunno, it just seems a bit disrespectful to the girls and their lives to believe they were foolish and got lost. Just think, if Lisanne or Kris was your daughter, would you be able to look at this case and accept that the girls must've just got lost? Evidence for them being lost pales in comparison to them being kidnapped, does it not?

Then again, I could be wrong :)
comment.author: @whoever_81

comment.text:
This video should not be so quick to wildly speculate about foul play. There is simply no evidence of it. The "incorrect pin attempts" (if that happened at all) could be the result of Lisanne trying desperately to guess Kris's pin OR it could be the result of the effects of exposure and starvation. (Note: other human beings in similar circumstances have been known to get simple things wrong, such as writing the wrong date in their journal.) It's also unclear if they were trying to unlock the phone and putting in wrong numbers or simply checking the signal!

Secondly, if they eventually fell and/or drowned in a river, their bodies would rapidly start to decompose which in the right conditions can cause the body to break apart. It's very common for the feet of people who drown in rivers or other moving water to detach from the body cleanly at the ankle. The Salish Sea human foot discoveries are perfect examples of this - from Wikipedia, "Decomposition may separate the foot from the body because the ankle is relatively weak, while buoyancy caused by air either inside or trapped within a shoe would allow it to float away. The B.C. Coroners Service never found cut marks on any bones that suggest the feet were severed from the bodies." Lisanne's foot found detached in this way doesn't raise more questions; it clearly answers the question of where her body was when it began to decompose - the river.

Thirdly, the DNA found on the bag could have found its way onto the bag at any point leading up to hike, and it is very reasonable to assume that it would be difficult to get any meaningful DNA from such an item (which wasn't clean when it was found; that's simply incorrect). We know, for example as per this video, that they were volunteering at a school. That DNA could have been from any number of adults or children who came into contact with them leading up to this day.

Fourthly, what evidence is there that the bleaching was unnatural? What evidence is there to prove it would have taken too long naturally in this area in this time of year? To what extent is the bone bleached? The fact the bleaching is discussed at such a high level indicates this script was written by someone without the right expertise or willingness to seek it out.

Fifthly, the picture of the hair is over exposed, that is all, just like most of the other photos shared in this video.

Finally (god so many things...), in what universe do you need a computer to delete a single photo on a digital camera? Perhaps the woman taking the photos was simply upset at the photo they took. Maybe the other woman was dead or unwell and the photographer didn't want to see the photo anymore. It could have been any reason. OR it was simply a damaged SD card from water exposure.

So many people wanting to find a murderer in this small place when the story is about the locals doing what they could to find these women alive.

comment.text:
Il y a un problème que je ne me m'explique pas rationnellement; ma psychorigidité voudrait  voir ce modèle d'appareil photo et les réglages qu'on peut y faire.
Pour les étranges photos de nuit '510 et au delà'; les points peuvent être des "orbes". Artefact qui apparaissent flous car trop près de l'objectif ou en mouvement. Souvent des poussières, du pollen, insectes (c'est la jungle) ou comme dit dans la vidéo des gouttes de pluie ou ruissellement.. Ces photos s'expliquent assez aisément (Le rasoir d'Ockam est toujours une précaution nécessaire).

Point plus problématique où je serai curieux de voir CE modèle d'appareil et les réglages possibles.
Ça pourrait expliquer la présence d'une fonction de nommage/numérotation des photos. Certaines applications donnent des numéros de sauvegardes à l'intérieur du fichier (exif) et( se sert de ce numéro pour nommer. Ainsi, sur ces applications, on peut faire 3 sauvegardes (appelées 01, 02 et 03), les effacer, et les sauvegardes suivantes se nommeront pourtant 04, etc. et non 01.
Mais ça c'est surement un truc logiciel, il faudrait voir comment était configuré l'appareil.

Mais il y a un plus gros problème. Je veux bien que ce modèle d'appareil n'ait pas de géo-localisation (gps), mais je SAIS qu'il y a des données exif et même dans le commentaire, ce n'est pas clair. La date !
Sur certaines photos, l'horodatage n'apparait pas (normal, on l'affiche ou non à volonté). Mais pourquoi la date/heure apparait-elle subitement sur les photos de nuit ? Parce que l'appareil s'est réinitialisé avec les paramètres par défaut (hordatage On) ? Ça aurait pu expliquer que la date n'est pas la bonne, mais l'appareil indiquerait alors le mois de janvier, non avril… 2013 pour une histoire qui se passe si j'ai bien compris en 2014.

comment.text: Only issue with this theory of the sequence of images being changed to appear as if they never returned is their shadows at the start of the trail are all consistent. comment.text: Though murder and rape are very common reasons why young women go missing, especially in this part of the world, getting lost is also a very likely possibility. I feel like there are many holes in the 'murder and kidnapping' theory. People seem to think that the Panamanian police are trying to pass this off as them getting lost when they know there was a violent crime involved for tourism reasons, but there were cases before and after this where someone went missing and the police later found that they had been murdered and raped in one case. Why would the police go thru such trouble and risk to photo-shop photos and make up stories in an age where technology means everyone is watching? Why was there no effort to try to cover up all these other violent crimes? I also think that it is very unlikely any criminal would 'fake' 911 calls every day deep in the jungle as well as take a bunch of random pictures to throw off police. The best and easiest solution in this case would be to destroy the phones and camera along with any other evidence. Also, the calls were made to both 911 and 112, which is the Dutch emergency line. Are you saying this criminal took the time to find out where the girls were originally from, what the emergency line is over there and came up with the idea to call it every day in the case someone goes searching thru their call records? This would have to be some really insightful criminal going thru a ton of trouble to do things the hardest way possible, when as I previously mentioned, destroying the evidence would be the safest and easiest way to not get caught. The bag being found in good condition, in me eyes, probably means it was not in the river at any time and may have been left behind by the girls and found by someone (like a native) who kept it for some time and then returned it/got rid of it once realizing what it was and the implications of having it. You can say it is strange that the bag is in too good of a condition for being in a jungle for so long, but we already know that it was with Lisanne in the jungle for at least a week and if it hasn't showed significant signs of damage in that time then it is not unreasonable to assume it could stay in that condition after a month or more. The bras being in the bag is normal; wearing a bra or underwear while all wet can give you a really bad rash. The girls probably took off their bras and maybe Kris took off her pants too in an effort to get her underwear dry. I also want to address the idea that getting lost on the trail was impossible; that may be sort of true, considering you actually stick to that trail. If the girls had left the trail, even to relieve themselves, there is the possibility they got turned around and could not find their way back to it. If you look at the surrounding area in the final daytime photos taken I'm sure you can imagine how hard it would be to find the path again once you are no longer near the stream and have walked down into the dense foliage. I think that at some point between the time that last photo was taken and before the first call to emergency lines the girls wandered off the trail and got lost. Maybe they were calling because it was going to get dark soon and they could not find their way back or maybe an accident had already occurred. We do know Lisanne's foot was broken as if something had fallen on it when her remains were found and that Kris's head was bleeding at the time the night pictures were taken. It is really too bad they did not leave us any videos explaining what happened or to remember them by, but that isn't evidence that they were attacked and didn't have time to do it. I know that I personally would not want to leave behind any messages; I know my family knows I love them and I would feel pretty ashamed about explaining to them how I had made a mistake and gotten lost. I wouldn't want people viewing those kinds of videos of me after I was dead and I wouldn't want them to be the last way people I loved saw me; after reading her diary, I feel Lisanne was the same way. It is also possible she was sick and had a fever at the time when it finally became apparent that this was the end. I know the parents say that the girls wouldn't ever wander off the trail because they were responsible, but as much as I hate to say it, the fact that they went there alone without a guide even though they had already booked him for the next day was highly impulsive and irresponsible. The clothes they wore and the items they packed also showed that they had no idea what was in store for them in the jungle and once it got dark, cold and wet it is possible they could have suffered hypothermia unless they found some kind of shelter. I'll finish off by saying that the apparent 'bones' and 'shadowy figures' people keep finding in the pictures are obviously your mind playing tricks on you. In the last few photos Kris does look concerned but they are still clearly on the trail though the last one where she is standing in a large junglescape looks like they may have already gotten turned around. I personally would have taken more photos of landmarks but keep in mind the jungle probably all looked the same to them and one of them was probably injured so rationally assessing the situation and retracing their steps became more and more difficult.

comment.text: What I didn't catch you mention about the tour guide is one thing about guilty parties - they involve themselves as much as possible in the case. This can be done for various reasons. One is to keep abreast of the investigation - what is found, what investigators know, how close they are to evidence or potentially solving the case. Two is because they enjoy seeing the fruits of their crime play out - the investigators squirming for answers - they get a sense of superiority from outsmarting, if you will, the investigators. Everything I have heard and read on this case circumstantially points to the tour guide. I would have focused my investigation on him, his coffee farm, employees that could have conspired out of fear of him & I would have interviewed in a formal setting as many of his tour guide customers, particularly female ones, as possible. My suspicion is that he told them where to go because he knew the area intimately & then at some point killed them, probably at his coffee farm, took those pictures, deleted an incriminating one, & that he himself was the one "attempting" to dial emergency services in an area he knew wouldn't have proper coverage. He did all this to support the narrative that the two were lost. He then later could easily place some remains, their backpack in various areas going unnoticed to further support this narrative. I believe he would have PC's at his coffee farm - whether for inventory, receipts or whatever else related to running this farm - and would have deleted an incriminating photo, that perhaps would have linked him to the crime. I don't believe they were ever lost out in the jungle for a week, they were probably held for days, then killed. As a final note about the incorrect password usage - I would be willing to bet the girls knew each others phone passwords because they were very close friends and also because they were traveling & just in case of an emergency either one could use either phone. They were rather prepared and intelligent young women, they would have thought of this. Who wouldn't know the password? The tour guide.

Finally, the pristine backpack and the suspicious other "random" findings weeks later don't add up either. and maybe it's just my own theory, but i don't think it was one person. it would be interesting to know if there were other people in the cab with the girls when they were dropped off at the hike. but no one can confirm that from what you said. thanks for all the hard work on laying this out for everyone! dropped you a sub. the nighttime photos still give me chills.

comment.text:
In the disappearance of these two Dutch girls, there are two situations that I don't understand and I believe that need a more careful analysis:
1-If in the first two calls to the Dutch emergency number, they were already under the control of kidnappers, why didn't the criminals take the phones, the camera and all their belongings?

This doesn't make any sense! No offenders with murderous or sexual intentions would risk being photographed by their victims, or even risk the girls calling the police or leaving a message recorded on their cell phones for when they are found by the authorities.

2- Why don't you have any attempt to call 911 during the night?

What would be the worst moment for two girls from an urban environment, lost in the middle of a tropical jungle?
Do you agree with me that this worst moment would be to spend the night in the forest?! Exhausted, cold, with animals moving on the ground, animal movement in the dark forest, a plague of insects, rain spray, hunger, thirst and darkness everywhere. This would undoubtedly be the time when they would most try to connect to an emergency number, but they didn't.

Trying to explain these two situations, the best way to harmonize was as follows:
Lisanne and Kris decided on their own, to continue the trail past the viewpoint, when they realized they couldn't make it back before nightfall, or because they really got lost and disoriented, they decided to make the first two calls in the late afternoon of April 1st. . Without success, they must surely have screamed for help. They were certainly answered and rescued by someone who heard them both scream, or someone who somehow passed them on the trail. This would explain why the girls did not attempt to call an emergency number during the night, that is, they felt safe to be accompanied by someone they believed to be trustworthy and well intentioned.
After that, they certainly went with that someone, to some nearby property, where they continued to be deceived by lies that reassured them, but that at dawn and after a night's sleep, they always tried to make another emergency call, until the cell phone battery has discharged.
It was at that moment that this someone realized that they were totally incommunicado and certainly decided to attack and take their belongings that were all inside the backpack.
From then on, all the evil that befell the girls began.

In my opinion, between the moment the last cell phone ran out of charge and the dawn of the 8th, Kris Kremers was killed, so in the photos taken on the 8th, only the hair of a lifeless body of Kris appears, trying to simulate a disappearance, with them lost in the night trying to signal their position in the woods and kris dead in Lisanne's arms (who doesn't appear in the photos) as it's the killer planting false evidence, not Lisanne!

As the pieces of Lisanne Froon's skin were found in mid-June, in an initial state of decomposition, this shows that Lisanne was killed in early June and was under the control of this someone who killed her, for about 60 days. She was the last to die.

Note 1: Seeing the holes in Kris' Jeans, it shows that her dead body was dragged a short distance, where it was thrown. That is, this may indicate that the place where Kris and Lisanne were killed and the bodies were subjected to a chemical treatment for dismemberment and then concealment, are very close to each other, and may be in the vicinity of this property where they felt "safe" .

Note 2: The photo of Kris' hair at night, may not have been photographed in the forest, but in a closed and dark environment.

Note 3: Kris' boot found, was it clean and without any remains inside? No animal in the forest, would be interested in carrying a leather boot in her mouth! It's not food! That's how the animals would see this boot, any object, they would have smelled it and gone. That boot was taken to the forest by the killer.

Note 4: The police know of more evidence, maybe even the photo that was deleted. At the very least, they want to make some strategic use.

Conclusion: Kris Kremers and Lisanne Froon, were held captive in an environment they thought was safe, were killed, stripped naked, with the bodies being dismembered by some chemical process as yet unknown. Some dismembered parts, along with the girls' boots, clothes and backpack with all the girls' belongings, were deliberately abandoned along the straight-line trail to create false leads and simulate that the girls died of hunger and thirst after getting lost in the deep in the forest.

The death of these innocent girls touched me a lot! This is my small contribution to unravel their deaths and thus lead to a punishment, the possible murderer and the possible collaborators.

Fortaleza-CE, Brazil.

I very much hope that Jesus Christ will comfort Kris and Lisanne's parents.

comment.text:
Around the same time I went into the amazon basin alone to visit a tribe, there are 1000 ways to die. 

I ended up going in alone as my friends bailed. At a village I met a tribesman with his family and they took me to the main tribal camp. Things can happen that most don't even think about, quick sand will stop you long enough to be killed. Jaguars are smarter/stronger predators than man, the elder hunters of the tribe feared this word. Not to mention accidents from falling, dehydration, everything is poisonous snakes/spiders/frogs - everything. Being lost in the basin is probably a feeling most Westerners wouldn't be able to handle well in real life, if you're actually there... it's dark, everything's moving, everything's dangerous, every time you look down something new is crawling on you.

Nights are the worst BY FAR. This can be a serious anxiety and panic inducer.  Speaking from experience about the 90 photos they found, I was in a hammock and could hear cracking sticks around me, damn scary, pitch black, if I had a camera with a flash, I would have used it to help see in the dark.

The tribe I was with never met with the uncontacted tribe 20 mins away as it always led to bloodshed, there are no rules, there are no police. Men of society, or tribes men, are free to act as they wish, nobody's watching. People who knew about these girls - after it exploded with international news - would cover it up with misleading evidence to point you right when you should be going left, like the bag pack, hence why we still have truth seekers going round in circles of speculation for years about this. If someone knew in the tribal/village community, regardless of what happened,  given that news strangely travels very quickly through word of mouth, it's important to remember that tourism brings a lot of money in to these places, so much so that it can become dependable for some who will do anything to protect it.

The amazon is an unforgiving machine which recycles and feeds off of everything. The most common predator in there is arguably man, but it could be a combination of 1, 2, or 3/1000 things which will kill you.  In my opinion, this will never be solved.

comment.text:
This case still haunts me. 

Not only was the backpack found far from where they were last seen, but it was completely on the other side of the watershed that runs between Chiriqui province and Bocas del Torro Province. 
The girls would have had to have hiked up one of three river valleys, the Pianista River valley, the Paloma River valley or perhaps the Palo Alto river valley. These are the most logical ways for them to have hiked, as the trail from where they left follows the el Pianista for a short while. Whichever way they went they would have had to climb up to about 1800m at least if not 2000m to cross the watershed and enter the other drainage. 

The Culebra river is NOT JUST 15 km from where the women were last seen! 
It is over 35 km away AS THE CROW FLIES!!! 
Also, this guy means the Chianguinola RIVER not the Chianguinola PROVINCE! Chianguinola Province is all the way over on the EAST COAST! Chianguinola Province is over 70km from where the girls were. 

In order to get to the Culebra River the girls would have had to hike up El Pianista, climb 1800-2000m cross the watershed and enter Bocas del Torro Province. From there if they went downhill they would have entered into the Chianguinola river drainage first. Most likely around the middle fork of the Chianguinola river. From there they would have had to hike down the Chianguinola river. The Culebre river empties into the Chianguinola river near Punta Blanca and La Mina where the two rivers form a lake. That is an insane distance from where the girls were last seen. It is at least 35 if not 40 km!!!! 


Also, where the bags were found was UPRIVER on the Culebre, so the girls would have had to go up the Pianista river, cross the watershed at 1800m to 2000m of elevation, go down into the Chianguinola river drainage. They would then have had to follow this river for like 40 km and finally they would have had to GO UP THE CULEBRA RIVER in order to get to the small village near where the packs were found. There were hundreds of fingerprints on their backpacks and belongings.

Accident theory:
On one hand, it is very easy for someone to slip, have a fall and hurt themselves, but there were two of them. The girls were obviously not planning on hiking, but they still could have survived a very long time without food there, and being in a river drainage, they would have had plenty of access to water. The temperatures in that area in April are on average between 25°C and 15°C. Higher up they temperatures would have been a little cooler. The girls certainly would not have died of the heat up there in April. 

Ironically, it would have been quite possible for them to get hypothermia at night especially if they were wet. It is almost always wet in that area. Did they have anything with them to make a fire with?  I do not know what the girls' hiking or orienteering skills were like, or if they really knew where they were going, when they set out. It does not seem like they planned to hike for days. It looks more like the planned to go the 750 or so meters up the La Pianista trail to the summit, make some photos and return. 

Did they get turned around and go into the Chianguinola river drainage thinking it was the Pianista river? That is possible, but they would have certainly realized that at some point. If not by dark om the first day, then certainly by noon the next day. I find it highly unlikely that they would travel 40 km down the Chianguinola river, passing the rather large Rio Playita entering the Chianguinola from the left (West) and even passing the river Estrelita also entering from the left or West only to turn up the Culebre after what would have taken them at least 2-5 days and over 40km of hiking. It just does not make sense. Unless they did not know what they were doing got lost and panicked? If they had any sense at all and had been camping or hiking at all before then I just do not see this happening. 

As far as I can recall the weather was nice for a few days and then it did rain. Perhaps they got turned around and were lost headed down the Chianguinola thinking it was the Pianista for awhile and then got caught in a flash flood? Their bones from what I understand, were found strewn all over. Most of them were in the riverbed, but some where higher up. If I recall correctly the bones were found years after the girls disappeared. One was a boot with the girl's foot still in it, but there was no signs of severing or broken bones and the investigators believe that the limb became separated after severe decomposition. Drowning would explain why most of the bones were found in the river drainage. The bones found higher up on the banks could have been carried there by scavenging animals. 

Apart from that, there are venomous snakes and jaguars, but those scenarios are pretty unlikely. I suppose it could have been possible for one of them to have gotten hurt and then have been predated by jaguars, but this theory is very implausible. The most likely scenario here is that one of the girls got hurt and the other girl went for help and got lost or hurt herself. 

Foul Play:
Foul play seems to be the most likely theory to me. Their packs were found 40 km away from La Pianista as the crow flies that is up one river over a continental divide of 2000m, then 35-40 km down another river and then up another river for like another 2-3 km. It seems unlikely that a gang would take them to the city and go clubbing with them only to come back out into the jungle and dispose of the bodies in such a remote area. There is no vehicle access out there. No. More likely they ran into someone or went with someone. Someone, whom they knew. Maybe someone, who was going to "show them the area". He got them out there alone and he murdered them. It could have been up to several people. If they partied perhaps they wanted to party in the jungle. This seems far more plausible to me. 


As much as I know how easy it is for people to die of exposure. I cannot imagine that it what happened to them. That area is remote, but it is not like no one walks along those trails. There are huts, sheds, remote homesteads along the Rio Chianguinola on both sides. A few of them are probably visible from the river. If the houses had any kind of lighting, they would have been very visible at night.

comment.text: I'm a taxidermist and when I first started a few years ago I would look for raccoon and possum bones and whatnot in the woods near train tracks, so with the bones mentioned here, I'd be curious to know more about what the "bleaching" described. If the bones were corroded and the bone was flaking, you could easily say it has been bleached by human beings. But, there are natural decomposition circumstances in which a bone could end up whitened. It's very very common in places with heavy rain, and it's very common for bones found from the same animal to be not only scattered around by wildlife, and the bigger the deceased animal the bigger the scattering of the bones because the predator or scavenger is likely much bigger, and also, when bones are scattered like this early in decomposition a bone under a tree found in mud could very likely have more remaining flesh or grease (yellow/brown color) that bones found on rock or in the sun not protected as much from the rain. Also, often when someone drowns in water it's common for feet still in shoes to be found downstream because decomposition in water weakens certain joints much faster than the rest of the body so during decomposition feet will often detach in those circumstances. I hope I don't sound crazy, I'm just a taxidermist, I mean no disrespect to these girls. I do think it's very possible they got scared by something and ran off, separating them from the dog, but from what I know of decomposition I think in the end, one girl drowned, the other took photos so search parties might be able to figure it out, and then the other died of the elements, and maybe scavenging wildlife scattered the remains post mortem.

comment.text:
In the disappearance of these two Dutch girls, there are two situations that I don't understand and I believe that need a more careful analysis:
1-If in the first two calls to the Dutch emergency number, they were already under the control of kidnappers, why didn't the criminals take the phones, the camera and all their belongings?

This doesn't make any sense! No offenders with murderous or sexual intentions would risk being photographed by their victims, or even risk the girls calling the police or leaving a message recorded on their cell phones for when they are found by the authorities.

2- Why don't you have any attempt to call 911 during the night?

What would be the worst moment for two girls from an urban environment, lost in the middle of a tropical jungle?
Do you agree with me that this worst moment would be to spend the night in the forest?! Exhausted, cold, with animals moving on the ground, animal movement in the dark forest, a plague of insects, rain spray, hunger, thirst and darkness everywhere. This would undoubtedly be the time when they would most try to connect to an emergency number, but they didn't.

Trying to explain these two situations, the best way to harmonize was as follows:
Lisanne and Kris decided on their own, to continue the trail past the viewpoint, when they realized they couldn't make it back before nightfall, or because they really got lost and disoriented, they decided to make the first two calls in the late afternoon of April 1st. . Without success, they must surely have screamed for help. They were certainly answered and rescued by someone who heard them both scream, or someone who somehow passed them on the trail. This would explain why the girls did not attempt to call an emergency number during the night, that is, they felt safe to be accompanied by someone they believed to be trustworthy and well intentioned.
After that, they certainly went with that someone, to some nearby property, where they continued to be deceived by lies that reassured them, but that at dawn and after a night's sleep, they always tried to make another emergency call, until the cell phone battery has discharged.
It was at that moment that this someone realized that they were totally incommunicado and certainly decided to attack and take their belongings that were all inside the backpack.
From then on, all the evil that befell the girls began.

In my opinion, between the moment the last cell phone ran out of charge and the dawn of the 8th, Kris Kremer was killed, so in the photos taken on the 8th, only the hair of a lifeless body of Kris appears, trying to simulate a disappearance, with them lost in the night trying to signal their position in the woods and kris dead in Lisanne's arms (who doesn't appear in the photos) as it's the killer planting false evidence, not Lisanne!

As the pieces of Lisanne Froon's skin were found in mid-June, in an initial state of decomposition, this shows that Lisanne was killed in early June and was under the control of this someone who killed her, for about 60 days. She was the last to die.

Note 1: Seeing the holes in Kris' Jeans, it shows that her dead body was dragged a short distance, where it was thrown. That is, this may indicate that the place where Kris and Lisanne were killed and the bodies were subjected to a chemical treatment for dismemberment and then concealment, are very close to each other, and may be in the vicinity of this property where they felt "safe" .

Note 2: The photo of Kris' hair at night, may not have been photographed in the forest, but in a closed and dark environment.

Note 3: Kris' boot found, was it clean and without any remains inside? No animal in the forest, would be interested in carrying a leather boot in her mouth! It's not food! That's how the animals would see this boot, any object, they would have smelled it and gone. That boot was taken to the forest by the killer.

Note 4: The police know of more evidence, maybe even the photo that was deleted. At the very least, they want to make some strategic use.

Conclusion: Kris Kremer and Lisanne From, were held captive in an environment they thought was safe, were killed, stripped naked, with the bodies being dismembered by some chemical process as yet unknown. Some dismembered parts, along with the girls' boots, clothes and backpack with all the girls' belongings, were deliberately abandoned along the straight-line trail to create false leads and simulate that the girls died of hunger and thirst after getting lost in the deep in the forest.

The death of these innocent girls touched me a lot! This is my small contribution to unravel their deaths and thus lead to a punishment, the possible murderer and the possible collaborators.

Fortaleza-CE, Brazil.

comment.text:
This video was definitely one of the best and most nuanced one I’ve seen on the case so far.  I personally still flip flop between what I believe happened to them to be honest because while there’s a lot of weird, nonsensical parts to it that don’t really fit with a lost hiker, there’s also a lot of parts that don’t really mesh with the idea of it being a crime either.  A lot of the stuff that people point to as evidence of wrongdoing can be fairly simply explained as not being suspicious, but there are definitely a few little things that make me raise an eyebrow too.

The part I have a hard time justifying with the idea of them being simply lost is the fact that no one was able to trace them at any point during the search, not even so much as a broken branch, or anything of theirs left behind until suddenly months later there stuff is so easily discoverable.  The missing photo, the decomp, all that other stuff I can fairly easily rationalize because of how peculiar things like that behave in a jungle environment, but the fact that there was no inkling of them at all during such an insanely large and thorough search is kinda baffling to me.  Idk, I doubt we’ll ever truly find out what happened though in any case sadly.

comment.text:
So I fell down the internet HARD after watching this, and have tripped across a few details that seem important. First of all ... the location of the LAST PHOTO with Kris in it (taken late afternoon the first day) has been identified and it is NOT on the main trail, it is on a very tricky and dangerous side trail, which seems to indicate the girls definitely got themselves lost one way or another. The source showed pictures of these secondary trails; they are really rough - deep ravines and sharp rocks and sadly they lead deeper into the jungle. There are documented accounts of even local guides getting lost on these jungle trails. Second...  THE 90 NIGHT PHOTOS were all taken in the span of 5 hours from 1am to 5am on night #7 and in the SAME location. So the girls were not trying to travel at night (possibly heard something that scared them so they were trying to see, or scare it away, or thought they heard someone and trying to signal?) Third (and sorry this one's a bit gruesome)... THE FOOT that was found had a lot of broken bones that the forensics examiner said were broken pre-mortem and consistent with a bad fall (which is awful, it means one of them was badly injured). 

My feeling now after diving in to this mystery is the girls got lost and sadly died in a very dangerous jungle.

comment.text:
I have a huge hunch that they were perhaps followed & kidnapped, and here's my theory of how things went down:


As they were hiking, they went off the beaten path & got lost.  With the dog returning home without them, I suspect that one (or both) of the girls fell and hurt themselves, and they released the dog hoping it would go home & therefore alert the host family. The girls likely stayed where they were until they realized how dark it was getting, and tried to get back by themselves while also searching for a signal to call the emergency line.  When darkness fell, they used the flash of the camera to find where they were going.  I'm assuming that photo 509 might have contained an image of the person who had been following them, or some other damning piece of evidence that led to that particular photo being deleted later by the person who took them.


Either way, I think that at some point, Kris became so injured or so exhausted that she likely passed away, and Lisanne took Kris' phone so that she could hopefully still contact authorities and save herself, explaining the multiple failed PIN attempts, although this could also be the moment that the person following the girls had gotten ahold of Kris & he was attempting to get into her phone to make sure there was no evidence of them on it.  Either way, I think that at this point, the person who had been following them grabbed Kris while Lisanne ran on alone.  Eventually, Lisanne came to the edge of the cliff in the last photo (assuming other commenters are correct about the photo), where she was cornered and taken.


And I think this psycho who found them left their backpack as a way to taunt the police.  The bleached pelvis could have been left by the killer, or could be something that the police made up to cover up their negligence in this story.  Hell, the police may have even found the bodies themselves, dead of exhaustion after being alone in the jungle for so long, but didn't want it to come to light that if they'd taken action a few days sooner, they could have located the girls alive, and subsequently be blamed for the girls' death.


As for how they survived so long without water, I'm not sure.  Maybe they had quite a few water bottles with them, and survived off that for so long by drinking extremely sparingly.  I mean, people's bodies can do some crazy shit when that survival instinct kicks in.


This story really is a heartbreaking one, with a lot of speculation and very little evidence.  It's an extremely dark situation, with multiple hard lessons for everyone to take from this.
1)  Always make sure someone other than the people with you know where you are going and when you expect to be back, especially if you're going hiking in unfamiliar territory.
2)  Never go off into the woods alone, especially not unprepared.  Plan for the worst, and take some time to brush up on basic survival tips, in case you do become lost.
3)  Always be aware of your surroundings.  You never know what could be hiding near you.
comment.author: @Jojo.F87

comment.text:
I thought someone had come forward and explained that they were abducted by those two boys they met, held captive for about two weeks, were raped and later used to sell their organs. And that the night photos might have been taken during a night where they managed to escape, got lost and were retrieved by the abductors. 
The one thing I don't understand is why they would not have exchanged their phone codes in that situation. The idea was that the calls were made when they were allowed to use the bathroom outside the cabin and that they were allowed to keep the phones because the abductors knew that there was no reception in the area.
Even though this is a horrible scenario, it seems a "better" fate then dying lost, hurt, thirsty and starving in the jungle, at some point knowing they would never get back and never be found.
However, the abduction theory would explain the clean hair several days after the disappearance. If the were lost in the junge, the hair should have been sweaty and probably tangled with dirt, leaves etc. from sleeping on the floor. It would not have been that clean. It would, however, if they were in a cabin and maybe allowed/ asked to shower or wash themselves.
The other thing I don't understand is the potential abductors' motivation to delete one photo and return the others. If they have abducted several women this way before, why was nothing similar found before (cameras and stuff of other victims)? Did they want the families to have one last info/ memory of their daughters or what else could have been the motivation to show this? And then, why keep the night photos, especially the hair photo? Why not delete them, too?
So, someone sat down with the memory card in front of a computer, deleted this one photo, returned the memory card and then put everything into backpacks and placed it in the jungle instead of keeping under cover?

comment.text: I think they started to had back shortly after image 508 was taken. They never did go deep into the jungle. It was on the return journey that they were absconded by local criminals. comment.text:
It's good, however some details don't make much sense:
1) Why phone emergency services before getting in the spring with the men? Why only twice then no other calls since they seemed happy enough in the photo of them in the spring. 
2) The school director knowing about it and setting them up. They might not have spoken Spanish but both the schoolkids and the girls probably knew English. They could have taught that way.
3) The detailed series of events saying that the men were armed with 2 pistols and a machete. These are events that might have happened, though there is no concrete evidence.
4) Organ harvesting isn't something that can be done in a cave by someone with no experience and equipment. You would need a sterile room and a surgeon with a decent knowledge of anatomy to harvest a set of lungs. It's not a simple procedure that you can do with a pocket knife, you have to cut the sternum, break the chest cavity open expose the lungs, cut all the blood vessels to  and from the lungs and do all of this without puncturing a lung in the process. The procedure needs to be done very quickly post mortem too. Double lung harvest is extremely difficult. A junior surgeon could maybe harvest a kidney but not a set of lungs.
5) Why leave the girls with their phones? I guess if you were certain they couldn't phone out it makes a little bit of sense but they could leave a message, unless they did and it was deleted by Panamanian authorities. 

I liked the documentary, just some questions that I would like to see answered as these bits don't make much sense.

comment.text: It’s hard to separate fact from fiction. There are oddities like Feliciano’s sway over the indigenous folks (who found the backpack) and his influence even in the town. Then there’s the backpack. Wet and somewhat tattered maybe but in oddly good shape considering it was floating down a river for months during the rainy season. The fact that they did not find the girls on or near the trail must mean they were not lost on trail. It’s a well used trail. Someone would have found them and it was well searched. The jungle wasn’t, however. But, there’s no way they would have, let alone could have, gotten far in the jungle I think. The way I’ve heard it described, unless you have a machete, you really can’t penetrate it and you can’t go very far. I’m not sure exactly of the terrain there or if there’s some possible hidden precipice where they could have fallen and gotten stuck, but even then, I think someone would have heard them. They also never found the remnants of the help signals the girls had made that were featured in some of the (one of the?) night photos. I also found it odd that Kris’s hair was dry and seemingly clean in the photo Lisanne took of the back of her head. I do not think Kris was dead in this photo. It looks too much like she’s sat up and her hair isn’t falling in a way to suggest she’s lying down and there’s no ground beneath her. It’s possible they found a cave, but after a week in the jungle, I would think a girl’s bright blond hair would be absolutely filthy. It’s just odd. It’s as if they were on the trail and then poof ended up somewhere else where they must have KNOWN they couldn’t use their phones very much and they realized that their calls would not go through so they didn’t attempt more calls in that week or so that they were using their phones. It’s just so weird they never found ANYTHING to show where they may have been except the remains and backpack. Nothing. That part is very odd. Then there’s the story by the German man. Then there are the odd and contradictory stories by the villagers about when they saw the girls. Then there’s that photo of those two boys and two girls which MAY have been of them, but it’s entirely possible it’s not. Perhaps two men scared them off trail and they ended up somewhat deep in the jungle? Lissane’s bones DID show signs of excessive use ie: she walked for a very long time. And, again the jungle was not searched and I can only assume you’d get very turned around in there and possibly slip and hurt yourself. Edit: I realize this is kind of unlikely because of what I said about the jungle, but it’s also the only reason/explanation for their not being on trail and not heading back the way they came when they realized they maybe had gone too far. Otherwise there could feasibly all sorts of foul play scenarios, but it’s hard to fathom when you have the night photos. They used flash… how would their captors not see they were using it?

He notices there's incriminating evidence in pic 509. He hastily deletes it. Killer 2 advises him that deleting the pic doesn't actually delete it; it has to be written over. So killer 1 proceeds to take 99 random photos in the middle of the night in an attempt to [overwrite] deleted pic 509. Killer 2 [or 3 if gang-related] then explains that there's no guarantee he overwrote the entire file, and that it may still be [at least partially] recoverable. Now, for whatever reason, they have already planned to plant the backpack with the phones and camera, etc. [to make it look accidental, possible police cover-up], and really don't want to just smash the camera or its memory card. So instead, they remove the memory card, insert a new one and format it. Then using a computer they copy the contents of the old card onto the new one. The computer won't copy deleted data, thus pic 509 is missing for good [there was no trace of pic 509 ever existing, and per Canon, it is impossible for the camera to randomly skip a photo in sequence]."
