comment.text:
Sad story, I guess we'll never know for sure now but it is still more likely they went and got lost, got hurt and perished in the elements.  But there are so many irrelevant points brought up that have no significance, presented as crucial pieces of evidence. eg;
-Who was or wasn't wearing a backpack in which photo - over 4 hours, it's just as likely they just swapped from time to time along the way as they got tired - it doesn't mean anything and has no relation to which direction they were walking in.
-Why would they stop twice in the same spot to waste storage space to take the same posed selfie pictures in the same place after they've already done it going one way?  A normal person just keeps walking home.  The photos were taken at the same time, in one session.
-The highly dramatic travel channel documentary took the word of one indigenous man that they were not actually photographed at the Serpentine trail and took it as true gospel over all the other professionals who actually walked the trail searching for them specifically using their camera trail.  He was simply wrong.  That was not a photo of them heading back up the trail home, it was confirmed to be them having passed the "do not pass" sign and continuing down on into the deep jungle.  They may well have paid that native chap to say what they wanted him to say.  They even posed at a random stream crossing claiming it proved the girls were going back up the trail home, even though the rock formations were completely different.  They BS'ed that it was different because "it's a dynamic setting".  Those large boulders were completely embedded and had been there for likely thousands of years.  No small stream or even raging river will move them, they are fixed and will only be eroded incrementally over hundred of thousands of years.
-It's claimed often there is no way to get lost on this trail. This is preposterous and even Indigenous inhabitants have died on this trail. After the initial tourist trail half where they stopped to take photos, the trail becomes wild and is for the Indigenous people to use, it is genuinely wild and small with multiple possible tracks becoming available.
-Speculation about the other people is fine, but people seem to get fixated on the ideas taught to them that these countries are always drug gang murder capitals of the world.  Panama is one of the safest countries in the Americas and that town particularly, even safer.  There is the occasional serious crime like there is in any town but this was shocking for them too.  There is still no evidence that any of those people were there or involved in any way - small town gossip is real and eyewitness accounts of old memories are proven to be virtually no better than guessing.
comment.author: @malligrub

comment.text:
It is difficult to imagine how the parents and family must feel after so much speculation and absurd theories have been shaping the investigation of this case. There are two key things on this case that we should consider – if we are truly serious about finding answers and more than anything, I hope the relatives assimilate for sake of finding peace.  

First, everyone must understand how deep and profound is the mistrust between the native indigenous populations and their neighbours in the developing countries. This relationship varies between countries, but in Central America, the relationship is sometimes openly hostile between many rural indigenous communities and the “westernized” population.

Second, in Central America, professional, modern, skilled forensic investigation is essentially, nonexistent. I do not mean insufficient; I mean it just does not exist any shred of basic forensic science being developed and run within the people in charge. Not saying there are not many great people fully compromised with justice, I am just saying they are decades behind first world standards. 

I can assure you: there are police stations in the developing world where employees do not even know how to take a decent legible fingerprint when booking someone. Some of the people in charge of policing are not even trained! When you talk about rural areas, poor areas, like Boquete, it is even worse. Many just volunteer their time and effort to do good in their community.

Local people understand this and accept this as normal. That is the reality.
There are facts we cannot simply put aside for convenience or to fulfill likes in our you tube feed! (yes, you know who you are).
We would not be talking about this tragedy, if the girls would have stay put as soon as they realized they were lost, and if there had been a professional search and rescue team available- first thing in the morning -at the latest. 

I honestly believe, the official conclusion is correct. This was an accident but many things do not make sense simply by the fact, that the truth was not told as of when and where- the backpack was found! Why? Because no innocent indigenous person is willing to go to jail, for the sake of the Panamanian tourist industry or simply to help close a case the corrupt and incompetent authority cannot even begin to process! Simply as that! 

The indigenous Nobi are not hiding a crime. I honestly believe they had nothing, nothing to do with the disappearance, more in fact, they would have helped the girls! They simply do not trust the Police. They trust no one outside their community. Police in Panama is more than corrupt! There are no laws in Panama! (even for white collar people and multinational corporations and that is why they operate based in Panama) The indigenous would have been locked up as scapegoats just to appease the Dutch Government. Their logic is this: you found the backpack? You killed these girls. You go to jail. Case closed. Look up on the internet on how police and the government operate in Latin America. Indigenous people are not even considered third class citizens at best, and this is reality, no matter how hurtful this is. It is a real life drama.

To add to this, the Police botched up the case. As simple as that. And once again, not because they did not want to find the truth, just because police in these parts of the world have no clue on how to run a decent professional investigation. It is the sad reality. I know this, you know this.

Why do you have so many sets of fingerprints on the camera? Possibly, because there were Nobi hands all over the girl’s things and, because you had many hands playing with everything at the police station! Why can’t you find picture 509 in the memory card? Possibly, because a wise guy at the police station deleted the file while transferring the files by accident? Or even possibly, and this may be something some people will find absurd – but – it may be true as true is that all electronics are not 100% perfect: the card was corrupted or defective and photo 509 is simply photo 510. The card could not process or execute a file titled 509. We cannot simply assume this is not possible. The family may be able to confirm this bay looking up for photo albums taken with this camera.

I venture to think “photo 509” did not exist or was deleted by the police. So, when think about serial killers, a sexual predator, drug trafficking ring, human traffickers…let us get real! It is smore likely you can find one of these in your neighbourhood- or right next door -than in the middle of a jungle in Boquete. I can assure you, Boquete is safer than many neighbourhoods in big cities in Europe and North America. Many people depend on tourism and many live simple and decent lives and have no ill wish to tourists. 

What happened then? No one will know exactly what happened. I believe eventually more remains will appear, but no one will know for sure. I believe Kris and Lisanne made a few mistakes and then made a heroic and admirable intent to rectify and survive the drama. They started their hike a little late and quite possibly, assumed the trail was some kind of a “loop” and they continued with the hike and eventually became concerned about being lost. There was no accident, imminent danger and that is why there were only two calls that evening. They assumed they could walk out the following day. They continued to walk even farther away from Boquete.  I am sure they thought they would walk out the jungle at some point and – or be found.

So many assumptions regarding many things. The fishy guide. Why did he go to look for them? Because no party to guide meant no income for the day. They had an arrangement. That is why he went to look up for them. Why did he find the remains? Possibly because those are the trails he walks often as a guide for hikers. Who else knew those trails better than him? He did. His life has been a nightmare ever since. If someone had stalked, attacked, and killed those girls: they would have done the deed early, the phones would not have been found/ used. As simple as that.  
It has been stated the frantic photos at night clearly show intent to leave signal of a site. To pinpoint something in the case the camera was found. I believe the camera was used in a state of panic, and confusion after one of the girls passed late at night during rain fall.  The other girl quite possibly kept moving and later also passed on, not far away from where ethe pictures were taken.

I believe, the backpack was left in a ravine or somewhere safe from the rising waters and found very soon after the girls passed. The Nobi kept everything clean and dry for weeks and eventually decided to turn them in to avoid problems after hearing about the lost girls from their community. 

Something everyone seems to be concerned of: why the two bras were in the backpack? How about the shorts? Simple. See, they did not carry only -1- bottle of water. Right? You cannot assume they had only one bottle because only one bottle was found in the backpack, right? I am sure at one point, walking thru a humid and warm jungle they decided to quite possibly remove clothing as convenient and comfortable. Sometimes without the bras, only on tops and sometimes only with the bras or swim trunks.

And more importantly: I believe they carried extra clothing as they could have even tried to reach the waterfalls. They carried swimming suits. If you think about this, somethings start to make sense – at least that is my humble take. Why weren’t these found in the backpack? They were wearing the swimming trunks when they perished.

Kris’ shorts may have been found in the backpack. I could almost bet on it, but we will never know unless who ever found the things comes up clean. The shorts and the clothing may have even been used by the indigenous for a while. How couldn’t we even dismiss this? 

No one, not you or me would last a week in a jungle, with no water, no food. I believe their remains simply were taken and disposed by wild animals and scattered as they moved thru their habitat.
We cannot even imagine how we would have reacted, processed reality while living this nightmare. I truly feel sad for the girls and even more for the parents. Somehow, reading so many absurd stories and people even making money out of this tragedy (yes, that is you Juan Perea) makes me feel upset and I can only hope more people could be have more objectivity while searching truth because finally, we should all be helping these families heal and have peace.
comment.author: @am3986

comment.text:
It seems like most of the popular comments suspect murder, but to me this seems like a pretty clear case of two girls getting lost. I also just listened to an Unsolved Mysteries podcast about this topic and there is nothing tangible to suspect anyone of foul play. 

One of the "suspicious" points is the deleted photo. For sake of argument, let's say that photo was incriminating for the murderer. Two questions arise: 1) how/why did someone take ~90 photos 7 days later? 2) Why wouldn't the killer have just destroyed the camera? This was a camera, not a camera phone so there wouldn't be any cloud storage so destroying it would leave no trace of what happened. 

The other "suspicious" point is the failed phone login attempts on the 7th - 10th. My theory for this is Lisanne was trying to get into Kris' phone because Lisanne's phone was dead (last used on the 5th) and Kris was either dead or unconscious.


Here is my theory for what happened:
Day 1: Hiking as planned. Possibly they deleted a photo immediately after taking it because it was blurry or something. At some point, one of the girls, probably Kris, gets hurt and they can't find the trail again. If they fell down a cliff, they wouldn't be able to get back up easily and would have lost track of the dog. Even experienced adventurers tend to act irrationally after getting lost. 
Days 2-6: Continue to wander lost in the jungle. The rains started during this time so they were able to drink from streams to keep themselves alive, but likely got sick from parasites in the water. 
Day 7: Kris dies from a fall off of the bridge. Lisanne frantically tries to guess Kris' pin but is unsuccessful.
Day 8: With no phone access, Lisanne uses camera flashes to try to light the way. This could have also been when a photo was deleted immediately after it was taken.
Days 9-11: Lisanne tries to find her way back alone while occasionally trying to guess Kris' pin but eventually succumbs to exhaustion, starvation, or dehydration.
Next 2 months: The girls' remains are scattered around by animals and flowing water.

I don't think they should have been moving at night at all though, they should have tried to make some kind of camp and moved in daylight.

comment.text: They were likely raped and killed. One of the perpetrators is Henry Gonzalez, the son of the tour guide Fernando Gonzalez. They didn't die during the hike. They made it to the top of the trail then went further along past the top to a small creek, they then walked back safely to the beginning of the trail. There a red car approached them to take them to Caldera Hot Springs. There is where photo 509 was taken, a photo taken by an unknown person that features the two women and two men posing in the hot springs. After that they were probably raped, at least one of the women (Kris) was probably kept alive longer than Lisanne was. In the meanwhile they took their phones to plant fake calls to emergency services at a place where there was no service, this explains all the failed pin code attempts. After a week the perpetrators went back to the jungle with Kris (probably deceased) to plant fake evidence, hence the strange night photos, they also took photos of the back of the head of Kris, hence the clean hair to make it seem like the women took the photos. They then took the bodies and severed the body parts also using bleach, after the parents announced the 30k reward money, they planted the body parts and the backpack as evidence near the site where they vanished hoping to collect the reward money. Local people and experts have declared that there are no dangerous predatory animals near the Pianista Trail, there was no real place where they could stray from the trail or fall off. There is no feasible way that in only 3 months there bodies would decompose that quickly that body parts could separate and belong in different positions.

comment.text: a) One call to emergency services connected for one second before dropping. If it had been the girls making that call, don't you think they'd have stayed at that spot and tried calling over and over again? Again, unlikely. d) naive these girls may have been but stupid they weren't. they would be unlikely to venture deep into the jungle once they reached the summit. Far more likely to turn back. All this plus the issues with the backpack/clothing/physical remains evidence points fair and square to foul play, not a "lost in the jungle" scenario.

comment.text:
Le guide fait parti de la même communauté que les villageois qui ont retrouvé des indices. Ils connaissent la zone de la rivière du serpent par cœur. Les autorités panaméennes savent qu'il s'agit d'un crime exécuté par un ou des membres du village que tout le monde couvrent pour préserver leur communauté. N'allez pas me faire croire au vue du nombre de faits dans cette région qu'il s'agit de quelqu’un d'autre que ceux qui vivent sur ce lieu. D'autres ossements sont retrouvés mais tout le monde s'en fout, une femme et un enfant, ça ne pose pas question ?
Je ne sais pas qui est l'auteur de ce carnage mais je suis convaincu que tout le monde sait car avec le temps les langues se délient et la vérité éclate. Elle est souvent sous nos yeux mais on continue de douter de nos intuitions qui sont souvent proche de la réalité. La page du guide sur un site de référencement spécialisé est curieuse. La première photo date de 2012, après il y a des photos de 2014, l'année de ce double meurtre ( + viol probablement, la présence des soutifs dans le sac à indices soigneusement déposé sur un rocher est une évidence). Les premières photos de 2014 sont de février et jusqu'en juin (mois de la trouvaille des indices des villageois) il n'y a aucunes nouvelles photos. Après les photos sont de plus en plus partagées au fil des mois et des années, le guide semble avoir percé, il est encore en activité apparemment. Je ne suis pas certain que le guide soit le meurtrier mais il sait quelque chose. Ils se connaissent probablement tous sur les berges de cette rivière du serpent. Le tourisme ne doit pas s'arrêter pour quelques dérapages de locaux, on couvrent l'affaire et le temps se chargera de faire oublier dans l'esprit des gens, qu'un ou des psychopathes vivent au bord de la rivière du serpent de Boquete et que de temps en temps ils décident de sacrifier des touristes pour assouvir des désirs honteux
comment.author: @Al-Ngogo369

comment.text: The simplest conclusion is that these girls got lost. But I find it strange (for those who know the whole story of the case) that, right after the last photo taken in a small stream, the girls didn't take any more photos or use their cell phones for 3 hours. Kris's father, in the video "Answers by Kris," who hiked the trail with Feliciano (the guide) and Kris's mother, claimed that up to the point where they went—which, according to their calculations of hiking distances, would be the closest point to where the girls made the emergency call—it wasn't so easy to get lost. They would only get lost if they left the trail. And they didn't have a logical explanation for the girls doing that, because they weren't taking any more photos in that section. There was no obvious reason to leave the trail and get lost. Looking at the whole case, it seems the girls simply got lost. But the strange thing, which even Kris's father comments on in this video, is: Why didn't they take more photos during that 3-hour hike since the last photo, before making the first emergency call?
comment.author: @Nômade-exo

comment.text:
I'm surprised you didn't notice anything odd with Kris's photos especially. Most of the early shots she's happy and excited but towards the latter, you can easily tell she's distraught, not smiling and obviously not having any fun. The one where she's at the creek looking back you can easily point out there's no excitement and zero happiness which can lead one to believe they've been caught by person's of interest as they're the ones taking the pictures. The photo showing Kris's hair at 7:04 is actually the top front of her head. You can easily see her nose at the bottom and, if you blow it up, her deadened eyes. There actually exists two photos like the one at 7:04 where her mouth is wide open as if she's gasping for air while being choked. The choking was pointed out by several sources as you can (again blowing up that photo) notice a black thumb right by her mouth. That rock with plastic and twigs is actually from the Caldera Hot Springs where Kris and Lisanne were seen in a photo with Jose Murgas and Osman Valenzuela. Both were members of Henry Gonzales's gang (the son of Feliciano who had a dire lust for Dutch women). Osman died three days after the girls' disappearance from an apparent drowning (deemed homicide) .. Jose a year later by a hit and run. The girls didn't get lost on the trail as numerous witnesses noticed them coming back into town hours later only to be picked up by a red truck. Case grew cold only followed by several theories after that. 

All of this was a cover up to protect the tourist attraction that makes the majority of Boquete's economy run as the investigation by Betzaida Pitty mishandled key evidence. Why wasn't Feliciano and his property ever investigated? How is it possible that Dutch cadaver dogs (who can sense decay for up to 6 miles) couldn't sense anything yet Feliciano just happened to stumble upon their bones as well as several others from different people? How is it possible that their non-waterproof backpack wasn't waterlogged with everything inside damaged after spending weeks in the jungle? Everything was dry and neatly folded / placed inside on top of a rock.. last I checked heavy river currents don't fold laundry. The backpack was nearly pristine.. material sitting in the jungle for weeks would have succumbed to the elements; that much is evident. Their bones would have had animal marks but they were unmarked, perfectly bleached and clean.. hmmm..  I know we'll never see the light of day with this case because the right people were paid off while the loose ends were all dealt with.

comment.text:
Hm. It must be incredibly easy to get lost in a rainforest and die.
But were the bones really bleached? How? Was the backpack in an overall good condition, for allegedly being out there, in the forest - exposed to the environment for months? How?

If there was a foul play involved- the phone calls - a local person can make 911 phone calls, especially when he knows, there’s no signal anyway. Just do it for a few days, to make it look like they were alive, looking for help.

As for photos - if there are legit photos of them days after being lost, that’s weird. The photos in the dark, again, anyone could have taken them for any reason.

If you’re a killer, you probably don’t want people to know it, you make up “evidence” - phone calls days after they could have been dead, photos of weird things - they’re lost, starving, paranoid, take weird pictures, why not. 

If someone harvested their organs - why bleach their bones though- and if that’s something you do, why return these particular bones to be found? 

Did they just get lost and died - probably. But phone calls, backpack found - that doesn’t have to mean anything - especially if you want to make it look, like they got lost and you’ve gained something far better than a couple of bras, phones and $80. 

If they were taking genuine photos of themselves afterwards, I haven’t seen those, why would you do that, why not record a video for the family instead, I don’t know.

comment.text: Coming from a programmer, the deleted photo is 100% an indicator for an involvement of a third party. Computers don't "magically" forget files, not both all of the content and the record in the actual file directory. And you don't go around deleting photos when there's enough space on the thing and esp. when you are in a dangerous situation. The police deleting the photo is unlikely because it's the most important one, at least somebody would have been able to describe what he/she saw + deleting doesn't actually overwrite the data unless the specific blocks on the storage are used again so it would have been easy to restore it if it was deleted after all of the photos.

comment.text: My heart literally aches to see Kris' Mother face. As a parent, it is unimaginable to comprehend the pain she must feel. I would do the same as her, revisit the trail whenever possible and continue the search for answers. Deep appreciation to all those involved in this video, as it is very helpful as I try to understand this unexplained tragedy. At first glance, I would speculate something important happened about the time of the last photo. Something caused the 2 ladies to either rush further down the trail, or possibly seek cover by veering off the trail (and subsequently become lost). I agree completely with Kris' mother; the two would not have left the trail haphazardly. There are too many unanswered questions to make serious conclusions about the events that took place after the last photo, but the fact they began making emergency calls about 2-3 hours after the picture at the creek tells me (1) they were likely not abducted at that time and (2) they realized they needed help, i.e., they were probably lost. So, my best guess is they left the trail for unknown (but important) reasons and (2) subsequently became lost and (3) likely wandered through the forest, finally finding the small river below and spent the next couple weeks in that area and probably tried exploring upstream in search of help/civilization. Based on everything else I have read, I would guess that they encountered a person or people while near the river who turned out to have criminal intent. The backpack was relatively undisturbed, apparently, and suggests that the 2 had set it aside as they bathed but then were either abducted or for some reason suddenly left it behind. The fact that the camera and cell phones were in the pack tells me the people responsible for harm were not sophisticated in nature. I have further speculations as to what happened, but I have extended my hypothesis beyond what is reasonable already. My sincerest condolences to the families, and thanks to all the wonderful volunteers from Panama who have tried to help.

comment.text:
I stopped wearing bras years ago. I'd only wear a sports bra on a hike. If i had a wire bra on in this same situation, it'd have been torn off and tossed in the woods (but really in my backpack because I'm not a litterbug) within the first 12 hours. I personally find bras are more for other people's comfort or enjoyment rather than the wearer. My super big boob friends also feel the same way...(lower boobs put less weight on the back...lower center of gravity. Mile higher boobs force the upper spine to bear the most weight. Plus it's consolidated.


So anyway, I'm sorry for what happened to these girls. At least they didn't choose to suffer in bras.

And also... I'm not going to elucidate too much into my hacking skills here, but I've got a few decades experience in deleted file recovery as well as photography. I'm with kendall, photo 509 is probably a regular disk error of some kind. If someone were going through the trouble to delete a photo beyond recovery....just ditch the whole thing. By trying to remove it, you're more likely to leave a digital trail. The memory card would have recorded a hidden file linking it to the device it was connected to. And i highly doubt someone would have even thought to do that if they only thought to delete a picture blah blah blah.

If a device overheats, experiences a power inconsistency, if the camer gets turned off while trying to take a picture (night pictures are delayed even with flash while the camera tries to focus on a subject in the dark preflash).

I can always be wrong but i think these little things distract from the big picture.

RIP

comment.text: As sad as this story is, I don't believe they met with foul play. I believe that one of them injured herself, and the other not knowing the way back, stayed with her dying friend. It was surmised that it was Kris Kremers that sustained a head injury, and when this story first was covered in the news, I did see the actual photo of the injury, but that was 3 years ago, and at the request of her family, was removed and I can't find it anywhere now. So, after seeing that, it's known she had some injury to her head, and being out in the jungle without food or water, you aren't going to last long. I think she may have fallen into one of those ravines and Lisanne couldn't get her out, so stayed with her waiting for help. Based on the weather reports for that day, the first real storm of the rainy season began on the 8th of April, the same night the photos were taken in darkness. When it rains up there in the cloud forests, it comes down hard and fast-which I believe  caused the ravine Kris was in to fill with water and eventually turned into a raging stream capable of drowning the injured girl, and Lisanne could have been using the cameras flash as a desperate attempt to see the water level. Then, after realizing she could no longer help her friend may have tried to cross that monkey bridge and fell in and drowned as well. Even if a stream or creek doesn't look too bad, anytime it's running fast from rainwater is a dangerous time. Although I don't believe either one was dragged through the river, if their bodies were in it, it would've helped speed up decomposition with fish and other predators and eventually broke their bodies down and that would explain why they only found a small amount of remains. As for Lisannes foot being in the boot still, that is because she was wearing them when she died. The boot would've helped keep her foot intact longer, and prevented animals from getting at it to a point. I've read about plain crashes and explosions where they can't find anyone's remains, but will come across a shoe with the foot still in it. And the camera, I have one identical and it was inadvertently left outside all summer, fall,  and most of the winter and where I live, it can be 100°F in summer and -35°F in winter which was that year and had gotten rained and snowed on and when I found it I figured it was shot, but I hoped since it was still in its case that that might very well have saved it. And luckily it did, and I still use that camera to this day. A bit different from a jungle type climate, but still extreme heat and cold and water damage , and yet it still worked and all my photos were on the memory card. So I just think they had an awful amount of bad luck and bad timing. So very sad, but I don't think anyone made them disappear.

comment.text:
I am going to add a couple of comments, that I wrote in another video covering this case about a year back; that video, and a couple of others covering that case, have been taken down since then, very odd. Here are my thoughts from that video:

Everything points to foul play: from delayed investigations, to ignored evidence, culminating in rushed conclusions. 



Of special note, are the camera images supposedly used to communicate a message, and that "one deleted photo" which probably contained the face(s) of the perpetrator(s). In the latter case, the photo has been deleted professionally, to the point that you cannot recover it, someone used relatively sophisticated means to erase it; some have said that the members of the tribe that found the belongings deleted it for good, which is quite impossible (after all, tribes that live in the middle of nowhere aren't exactly high-tech savy), I repeat, you need advanced software to eliminate it, without damaging the rest of the photos. The other photos were probably taken and left intact, to fool people into thinking it was a freak wilderness expedition accident.



And most importantly, if the girls got lost on their own and actually wanted to communicate what happened to them... do you think they wouldn't have the brains to write a message on mud or soil, or with pieces of clothes, or with leaves, or rocks, or sticks, or anything, so that they could then take a picture of the message, to tell us exactly what had happened to them? Another possibility, is that they didn't have time to write such messages, because they were being chased by a person, considering that what remained of them has no sign of animal attacks.



Their disappearance was, undoubtedly, the act of a criminal group, with solid connections.
comment.author: @TalkingAboutGames

comment.text:
Here is my theory based on few known facts and some speculation:
We know that they started hiking around 11am and they would've summited around 3 and returned to  the starting point around 5pm or so. I also saw in another video that the host family dog went with them.

Based on the girls' personalities, it was almost impossible for them to do something rash unless emergencies happended(their excessive planning tendencies).

The guide, Feliciano is still guiding people on this trail according to alltrails and he is quiet popular. We knew that he went in the girl's room and checked on them which is soemwhat weird considering that he was denied on being their tour guide?

We knew that there was one picture deleted in their photos. Why was only one photo deleted? It seems somewhat weired to stop and just delete one photo.

The Dutch rescue team searched almost the entire mountain and found nothing. The backpack and body parts weren't found until two weeks later and the bones were bleached. Somehow one of the girl's bones decomposed faster than the other and one of them sustained an injury after she died.

So here is my theory:
On the day the two girls went hiking, they were dropped off by the taxi driver around 11, the two summited but realized someone was following them, they tried to escape the follower(s) so they kept going but were eventually caught up. They could've sustained a fall with one of them, or it could be caused by traumatic injuries by the culprit at different time frames. There are private propertis up on the trail likely invoved with the local gangs. They were locked up in a cabin of some sort, likely suffered abuse with no cells signals(as there are claims on alltrails as to gps and signals non existent). Pictures were taken to make it look like they were lost in a jungle and wanted to use the flashlights to find their way. Then, they were evetually bleached and disposed.

Few more additional notes: dog returned to the lodging by end of the day, there were comments about the tour guide being creepy to european females(perhaps tour guide tipped off locals?), taxi driver was killed so there could be some mistake with the timeline.

comment.text:
It is clear that it was a crime, a crime still without clarification, let's hope that the case will be reopened and the perpetrator (s) will be found. The backpack with still operational content, such as cell phone memories and the camera, is an important element when ruling out a fortuitous accidental event. Probably, the victims were intercepted before the last photographic take and both the cell phones and the camera were no longer in their possession. The emergency calls that were made and that did not succeed are only a distracting element to confuse the authorities, since if it had been in the hands of the victims, they would have recorded photographic shots, filming or audio recordings of what was happening, in addition to trying to communicate to ask for help. In the event of an accident or that they had been lost, it is impossible to think that they would stop taking photos, in several days of loss and agony. Lost and alone they would end up talking to the camera. The erratic photographs taken at dawn were not taken by the victims, but rather the result of a distracting action to confuse the police, or of an act of remembrance, which is why it is probably after the death of the victims. The conserved backpack is initially a trophy of the author, for that reason it conserves the bras of both victims, but for some reason, probably to reinforce the idea of ​​a fortuitous accident, it is placed to be found. Everything missing, especially bones, are trophies that the predator keeps.
The predator, in this case, is an educated person, a planner, who probably speaks the language of the victims, has no economic motivation, his motivations seem to be basically to inflict pain and terror on the victims, there seems to be some sexual component.

Pourquoi les filles (ou la survivante) n'auraient pas pris clairement des photos pour montrer la situation dans laquelle elles étaient dans l'espoir que quelqu'un retrouve l'appareil photo et comprenne l'affaire ? Si il ne restait plus que Lisanne, pourquoi n'a-t-elle clairement pas pris une photo du corps de Kris et des alentours pour montrer où il était avant de partir chercher les secours ? 
Et pourquoi n'ont elles pas réessayé de contacter les secours avec le téléphone de Kris puisqu'il restait de la batterie (même si Lisanne n'avait pas le code, ce qui semble tout de même peu probable, elle aurait pu utiliser la fonction appel d'urgence qui ne nécessite pas le code) ? 
Et pourquoi n'ont elles pas essayé de baliser leur chemin avec les affaires qu'il y avait dans leur sac plutôt que de tout laisser dans le sac ? 
Je ne comprends pas non plus pourquoi les ossements de Kris sont propres, ni pourquoi tous les os ne sont pas ensemble (je veux bien qu'il y ait des animaux mais on aurait retrouvé plus d'os, même aux alentours). 
Enfin, trop de questions sans réponse à mon goût...

comment.text: It's actually totally possible for a camera to skip a number on its own. If you read Canons documentation they recommend doing a full format on an SD card after transferring images off the card. If they took 509+ photos on that card before and never formatted it, it's totally feasible that the cameras system just thought that file still existed and skipped the number. There are forum posts on Canon and other places with other camera brands of this happening on the rare occasion.

interesting theory, definitely. although, most of the things you mentioned could be explained otherwise. the decomposition, for example, is faster in rainforests (because of the temperature and humidity, that makes it easier for all those tiny organisms to grow and decompose a body). and if they died because of an injury (maybe even got mauled by a wild animal or something), that would explain the state the bones were in. and they probably didn't dehydrate, since in a rainforest is plenty of water. and usually teenage girls don't have anything on hand to filter that, so they could very well have suffered from the effects of the water, while maintaining at least their hydration. that could explain the pin too, if that wasn't after the first girl died. and honestly, the deleted photo could just be a reflex, maybe before they knew they were in actual danger. often people underestimate the situations they're in. 
and if there was a murder, first, how did the killer knew the pin to delete the picture? it would be easier just to destroy the phone. and who took the photos at night? the girls would be better of hiding instead of making themselves vulnerable with the flash and still, in that case a killer would probably still destroy the phone to be safe. did the killer do that? and if yes, why? if he wanted to get attention, like some do, he'd show off their corpses or something. 

after all, to me it's more likely that some kind of animal killed them (or ate their corpses, that would be pretty likely actually), or they died in an accident or because of dehydration (or the poisoning, if they drank dirty water). but of course nobody can be sure what actually happened.

comment.text:
I’ve always thought that the guide was extremely suspicious. Why would he go to their room the next day, only because they hadn’t met him as scheduled? That makes zero sense. The normal thing to do would have been to call them, and if he didn’t even try to call them, that’s not normal. 

If  tourists don’t show up for a guided tour, the  tour guide might try to call, but if they can’t get through, they shrug their shoulders and would then go about his or her day. Who would go to where they were staying and GET KEYS to enter their room-and snoop around it for a half hour? 

They were obviously young, naive and an easy target. If someone knew where to look for them on the trail, they would have been convenient prey. It seems very unlikely that so many things went wrong and this  was all coincidental. 

Later, finding the backpack with their things still conveniently in it in working condition is too bizarre. The phones, and then the camera and that one  missing photo, randomly deleted is absolutely  suspect. The weird way that their bone fragments were located, plus Lissane’s skin being found later on, all fails to add up. 

I don’t think that 2 young girls, ill equipped for a long hike and who were  unfamiliar with their surroundings would have been tempted to go off trail so far into the jungle unless something/someone was pursuing them.  They were trying for get away from something and it wasn’t an accidental mistake. 

The cover up has been filled with red herrings and senseless information to throw people off, like the dog Blue, who is in none of the pictures, and probably didn’t join them. The cab driver saying that he dropped them off so late in the day also doesn’t make sense. I don’t think they would start a hike that late when they had no idea how long it might take to get there and back-especially dressed as they were, without jackets or extra clothing, 

The ONLY logical conclusion to me is that they were pursued and subsequently caught and the evidence that turned up later was all planted. It’s very horrible and sad. but I don’t believe that they wandered around for 10 days and then took a bunch of weird pictures but never thought of writing goodbye text messages to their parents or friends. The picture of Kris’ hair was probably taken by someone else after she was dead. RIP Kris & Lissane! I’m sorry that we don’t know what happened, but it definitely is not the official story

comment.text: I've been watching several vids about the topic. Personally I think it went like this: they wanted to go to swim in the nearby waterfall, which they found out about online when looking for things to do in boring little village while waiting for their volunteering work to start. They packed light back bag for swimming: little bit water, some cash and bikinis. After all, they were planning to hike a bit, have a swim and come back in the evening. They hiked the trail to the top of the mountain and then tried to find to the waterfall nearby. They left the path confidently and descended, but couldn't return back to the trail because it was too steep or one of them got injured while descending the mountain. They tried to call emergency services for help. Call didn't get through. Sun was setting and they panicked. They tried to go around to the mountain to get back to track quickly, but lost the sense of direction. They tried to scream for help, the locals didn't want to get involved as they thought someone was being murdered and didn't want to get into trouble themselves. Night photos were either an attempt to gather attention of the rescue helicopter which they heard or a predator like big cat was pursuing them and they tried to scare it away. So they used the flash of the camera for this. As for the backbag. I think some local found the bag and picked it up. They tried to open the phone so they could use it, but they didn't guess the right PIN code. After the whole situation escalated, they must have heard about the incident on the news. Being scared of probability of being accused of murder, the local returned their possessions to be found. They didn't want to incriminate themselves, so they took it far from their dwellings. Maybe eventually the big cat caught them. Being exhausted, dehydrated and confused they were easy pray. I think they stopped taking photos to conserve the battery if they needed. If they were scared and confused, I don't think the first thing they want to do is take selfies. I've gotten myself lost in a jungle and it's very scary how fast the sun sets in jungle. You can almost see the sun going down. Panic hits pretty fast when you realise you have only 10 to 15 mins before it's completely black.

comment.text:
So for the rash of pictures being taken in the dark that tells me that (A), they didn't have a light source but they badly needed to see something and (B) something was scaring them in the dark and they were flashing pictures to use the flash of the camera to try and get a visual. As for the missing picture I have to go into a somewhat lengthy explanation to help show why I'm fairly confident that this was foul play and looking at the area I'm willing to bet Coca farmers did something awful to these girls.
   So the way some operating systems work in regards to deleting a file is based on how they index them. Think of the old days at a library. If you want to find a certain book you checked the card catalog which is an index. Computer Operating systems work the same way. When you delete a file it's not actually gone. What happens is the computer simply deletes the record of that file in it's index (and allows the space that file is stored in on the hard drive to be writable again so that other files can be written over the non-indexed file).. That's like destroying a card inside a card catalog at your library. The book is still on the shelves. Now no one can find it unless they stumble onto it by accident. For that picture to have gone missing completely it means someone who had basic computer skills purposely wiped it. It's probably not a feature built into the camera. If the camera does have that ability then the girls might have just missed clicked in their panic to get light but I highly doubt this. I think camera manufacturers would diliberately not allow a feature like that so their customers didn't accidentally destroy irreplaceable photos. I have a feeling these two girls stumbled into cartel territory where they were either harvesting or even manufacturing coca paste for distribution. I speculate coke traffickers just becuase Panama has been a haven for coke traffickers since the early 80's. I'm fairly confident it was foul play at the bare minimum. As for the other three human remains found there this sounds like hikers who stumbled onto the wrong area of the jungle and cartel members didn't want any lose ends. Especially knowing that a reward of $30,000 USD wasn't enough to get anyone to come forward. People who take poverty over $30,000 USD tend to make that decision out of fear. Cartels are amazing at generating fear. The remains were scattered becuase in order to carry a human corpse through the jungle you need to dismember it or you're not going to get very far in a decent amount of time. A group of guys dismembered the bodies and took them out into different parts of the jungle and tossed them.

comment.text:
I will put forward my speculative theory because what happened to these girls is a common occurrence where I live. It happens so often that I just cannot unsee its glaring presence in this case.
There are gangs that operate in popular tourist spots and they especially target and kidnap solo travelling female tourists of young age (male tourists are usually avoided because kidnapping them causes much complications. So having even one guy in your tour group will theoretically save you from traffickers). The motive of kidnapping is usually related to pr*stituion or organ trade. The information about such vulnerable tourists is leaked by the tour guides and people in the hospitability industry (in return for money or debt deduction or free drugs). I suspect the host mother of the house where the girls were living because she must have judged the girls to be naive easy targets and reported this piece of information up the chain. This also explains why she didn't bother to inform the authorities about the disappearance. She made the most cliché excuse I have heard in my life. You want me to believe that two young girls all alone in a foreign country with no one to protect them didn't come back by the time they were supposed to and you, being a woman yourself didn't feel concerned for their safety? Didn't bother to check up on them or even call them or their family? I call BS. 
Here's what I think happened to these girls. The information about their hiking trip was somehow leaked to the kidnappers. They must have dispatched someone to lure the girls out of the trail. They usually hire young, hot, local (exotic) guys to do the luring (who doesn't want to hook up with attractive local guys on a trip abroad, right?). Must have been an easy job to track the girls because the trail had limited, predictable scope. The predator/predators must have befriended the girls on their hiking trip, tricked the naïve girls into thinking they would be shown some of the exotic spots off the trail (or invited to a beach-side villa to attend a exotic party). The girls, none the wiser, followed the predator/predators on a hike to wherever they wanted to take them. This explains why the girls' initial photos seem normal.
Now, why would the kidnappers randomly litter the girls' bones only to be found by the authorities. My guess is that they did it to end the investigation for good. It's because the gangs that operate on that level are usually deeply involved with the authorities. In order to close the case, they needed just enough evidence but not their entire bodies, or it would complicate the investigation. 
The girls must have sensed something's wrong so they secretly kept calling 112 whenever they could while trying their best to pretend to appear normal before the predator and his friends. They must have also switched off their phones to save battery. 
As for what was there in Image 509, you guessed it... the picture of the damn heartthrob or his friends. Every bit of information was deliberately left on their phones to help close the case as mere accident. The kidnappers were definitely getting hints from the authorities in order to be able to fabricate stuff with such finesse. 
Where I live, the gangs usually kidnap vulnerable female tourists from Russia, Thailand and various other countries, make them reliant on drugs and then employ them in brothels. The local authorities know about this and do nothing to stop it. One of my friends spent just $100 to spend a night with a poor Russian woman in a brothel (because he is an idiot and deserves karmic justice). She knew English and told him in tears everything she had to go through which brought her where she was. She also shared similar stories about other females from various countries in a similar situation as her. They all had come happily as tourists and now stay imprisoned as hoes. Their only mistake was to come alone and got targeted for it.
The issue is that these gangs are way too powerful in the places where they operate. You cannot escape from them or call for help, or they will kill you and make you disappear from the face of the earth, just like the two girls in this story.

comment.text: I think they were using the camera flash as a flashlight after the phone batteries died.  Hence why they were of nothing and they were only at night.  edit:  as for the deleted photo, the FAT32 file system that the camera probably used will overwrite those deleted photos after it runs out of space.  They're only recoverable until new data is written to the memory card (it writes to it in a circular fashion so that it levels the wear across the blocks of memory).  They probably kept deleting the last photo so they could keep taking photos to light up the area.

comment.text:
I have been following the case since the begining.

I have over 30 years of experience - 3 of them at night - working in tropical forests like the one where the girls disappeared. The theory that best fits all the available data - in my opinion - is that the girls got lost after something strange happened on the trail.

It could have been someone or something that scared them, or they simply decided to relieve themselves off the trail and were unable to return. I have worked with many people in the forest and this is a common practice.

If foul play occurred, it was before they left the trail or after with the backpack. I do not believe in cannibals, organ trafficking and photos altered by bandits.

I do not believe that they were kidnapped for several days either. The data from their phones and especially from the night photos do not suggest this. However, what happened to the backpack is what makes me not 100% sure that they simply got lost.

That said, I must point out that tropical forests are extremely dangerous, even for experienced hikers.

If you doubt try by yourself. I do not agree with several statements that the girls were literally walking in the backyards of houses on a trail where it is impossible to get lost.

It is always possible to get lost.

The forest they were in seems very dense and vast to me from the videos of Romain C that I watched. I have gotten lost countless times on easier trails than this one in Panama. Trails that I know well.

This happens mainly on the way back. Because the light conditions change - fog - and there are small paths - forks - that are only visible on the way back... Now imagine two girls who did this long trail for the first time, without GPS, without knowing the place and without much water or clothes.

It would be almost impossible for them not to get disoriented at some point. And the photos before the Mirador suggest that they had doubts about the path even on the way up. On these trails there are people and animals that can create false paths anywhere at any time.

Trees can fall, causing you to leave the trail to go around. Anyway.

Another thing is the holes in the forest floor. In Brazil, there is a famous case of Kamal Guster who disappeared COMPLETLY AND FOREVER when he was only 80 meters away from his friend in the forest. I have fallen into a hole in the forest once. If you hit your head and the hole is small but deep you may never be found. Rivers are also very dangerous. Anyway.

Nature is a formidable killer. When you are at the top of the mountain, the simple decision to take the wrong path down in a moment of distraction or due to dehydration can be fatal. It is curious how few people here have realized that the path beyond Mirador is a mirror in terms of reference points in relation to the path up.

The reference points are repeated, giving the impression that you may be descending on the correct side of the mountain. But you are not. Anyway, I have been through countless things and met many strange people on trails too, so it may also be possible that they initially suffered foul play and then got lost. Best regards.
comment.author: @videosdeecologia7468

comment.text: 8:00 - Just thought I'd throw this out there but every smartphone has to have to ability to contact emergency services, even without the PIN or other security measures, and even if the service is disconnected. So the idea that someone was trying to access the phone to call is off putting. If the phone was an apple device, the phone would've been locked out and even so the memory is encrypted to access. The only way I see this, is that someone was trying to access the phone for information (maybe the missing photo) and if they managed to remove this, this had to of been an SD card with pictures defaulted to save there or it was an un-encrypted OS running on the phone (possibly android). In which case you should be able to access the phone and track down logs of what devices accessed what on the phone....Hopefully stored meta-data would help

comment.text:
In the disappearance of these two Dutch girls, there are two situations that I don't understand and I believe that need a more careful analysis:
1-If in the first two calls to the Dutch emergency number, they were already under the control of kidnappers, why didn't the criminals take the phones, the camera and all their belongings?

This doesn't make any sense! No offenders with murderous or sexual intentions would risk being photographed by their victims, or even risk the girls calling the police or leaving a message recorded on their cell phones for when they are found by the authorities.

2- Why don't you have any attempt to call 911 during the night?

What would be the worst moment for two girls from an urban environment, lost in the middle of a tropical jungle?
Do you agree with me that this worst moment would be to spend the night in the forest?! Exhausted, cold, with animals moving on the ground, animal movement in the dark forest, a plague of insects, rain spray, hunger, thirst and darkness everywhere. This would undoubtedly be the time when they would most try to connect to an emergency number, but they didn't.

Trying to explain these two situations, the best way to harmonize was as follows:
Lisanne and Kris decided on their own, to continue the trail past the viewpoint, when they realized they couldn't make it back before nightfall, or because they really got lost and disoriented, they decided to make the first two calls in the late afternoon of April 1st. . Without success, they must surely have screamed for help. They were certainly answered and rescued by someone who heard them both scream, or someone who somehow passed them on the trail. This would explain why the girls did not attempt to call an emergency number during the night, that is, they felt safe to be accompanied by someone they believed to be trustworthy and well intentioned.
After that, they certainly went with that someone, to some nearby property, where they continued to be deceived by lies that reassured them, but that at dawn and after a night's sleep, they always tried to make another emergency call, until the cell phone battery has discharged.
It was at that moment that this someone realized that they were totally incommunicado and certainly decided to attack and take their belongings that were all inside the backpack.
From then on, all the evil that befell the girls began.

In my opinion, between the moment the last cell phone ran out of charge and the dawn of the 8th, Kris Kremers was killed, so in the photos taken on the 8th, only the hair of a lifeless body of Kris appears, trying to simulate a disappearance, with them lost in the night trying to signal their position in the woods and kris dead in Lisanne's arms (who doesn't appear in the photos) as it's the killer planting false evidence, not Lisanne!

As the pieces of Lisanne Froon's skin were found in mid-June, in an initial state of decomposition, this shows that Lisanne was killed in early June and was under the control of this someone who killed her, for about 60 days. She was the last to die.

Note 1: Seeing the holes in Kris' Jeans, it shows that her dead body was dragged a short distance, where it was thrown. That is, this may indicate that the place where Kris and Lisanne were killed and the bodies were subjected to a chemical treatment for dismemberment and then concealment, are very close to each other, and may be in the vicinity of this property where they felt "safe" .

Note 2: Kris' boot found, was it clean and without any remains inside? No animal in the forest, would be interested in carrying a leather boot in her mouth! It's not food! That's how the animals would see this boot, any object, they would have smelled it and gone. That boot was taken to the forest by the killer.

Note 3: The police know of more evidence, maybe even the photo that was deleted. At the very least, they want to make some strategic use.

Conclusion: Kris Kremers and Lisanne Froon, were held captive in an environment they thought was safe, were killed, stripped naked, with the bodies being dismembered by some chemical process as yet unknown. Some dismembered parts, along with the girls' boots, clothes and backpack with all the girls' belongings, were deliberately abandoned along the straight-line trail to create false leads and simulate that the girls died of hunger and thirst after getting lost in the deep in the forest.

The death of these innocent girls touched me a lot! This is my small contribution to unravel their deaths and thus lead to a punishment, the possible murderer and the possible collaborators.

Fortaleza-CE, Brazil.

I very much hope that Jesus Christ will comfort Kris and Lisanne's parents.

comment.text:
Just speculation: Three men knew the girls were going to hike the trail that day: the taxi driver and the two men (apparently already in the taxi when the girls got into it if I remember correctly). Four men knew if one includes the guide who went into their room and went through their things. Did he know they weren't coming back?
Locals have said they heard girls screaming, a huge crash, and then three men exiting (running out of) the trail.
The crash was more than likely Kris and Lisanne being pushed over into the ravine (the screams were an indicator that they were either being chased or attacked?) The predators had to kill them because the girls knew them? 
The photographs are seemingly taken at the bottom of the ravine *looking upwards to where the body/bodies had fallen from). It is possible that the person who found the backpack and the body/bodies (some parts at least, considering Kris' hair) was taking photos (checking to see if it worked perhaps?) and was taking photos upwards to where the body had fallen from. Kris' hair was quite clean which is odd; was she in water or in some protected area? It's chilling to think that perhaps the attackers/killers eventually made their way down to the bodies...Perhaps what was left of the bodies was found soon after the plunge to their deaths but left there, unreported, and only the backpack was taken.
The deleted photo? Perhaps the backpack was handed to someone else (a guide, or someone else in authority) and that person encouraged them to hand it over to authorities, or perhaps the people who found the body took the backpack home with them and at some point got scared (superstitions could also add to the fear) and then handed it in at a later date. Perhaps they were too afraid to admit to finding Kris (and perhaps Lisanne) because they had taken the backpack? Kris had beautiful hair - hair that would be noticeable anywhere! Two lovely girls who were probably taught that a stranger is just a friend you do not know!

comment.text:
As the one who’s been following this case for years and read the book by West and Snoeren all I can say is this is a dead end case. 
I would believe that it’s a ‘they got lost and succumbed to the elements’ case BUT there are still two pieces that makes me think it’s not and the 3rd party has been involved :

1) the strange disappearance of the 509 photo, which couldn’t be found even by DRR. If it was just a consequence of an error by the camera, well that's definitely the ugliest joke by fate ever.
i also don’t believe it was necessary for them to switch the SD-cards. it just doesn’t make any sense, all these theories about that they probably didn’t want to save the picture and etc. sound like pure bullshit. Everything was ok till photo 509. i don’t believe they’ve just stopped making photos after they crossed the stream at pic 508. 

2) photos taken in the night after a few DAYS in the jungle. these pics are weird af and i can never believe they could not record themselves if they were alive at that time. just a few pics with their faces, legs, bodies would be enough to make it clear. 

i used to believe that after 4 pm on April 1st the girls headed off the trail and got in trouble but it wasn't a catastrophe, and they were alive until April 4th. 
ALSO i believe the camera was stolen/lost and those night pics were not made by them.
then after April 4th something really bad happened and MAYBE they've met with foul play.
Maybe they were not murdered but somebody was involved. Maybe it’s just a huge cover up case for someone not to be mentioned, ever.
comment.author: @xTigressStylex

comment.text: Really loved most of this video but the number skip/removal with the camera photo deletion speculation falls apart in an instant. You can delete photos from the camera, and if you'd already continued taking photos before deleting, the number wouldn't be replaced. Say I took ten photos, IMG_001 through IMG_010. I could then delete IMG_004 from the camera, but images 005-010 wouldn't 'shuffle' to reflect that. They'd simply continue because IMG_010 still exists.

comment.text:
I have never been to the location myself. But from people who walked the same trail I heard you have to do your best pretty hard to get lost. That it is more rural than jungle. Of course when you go off the trail it quickly becomes dense jungle-like vegetation. I can understand you can quickly lose your sense of direction. On the other hand they had compass…  They kept traveling north away from the trail… 

If I compare it to other stories where people went lost while hiking, you often see that when people realise they are lost… they start to document messages and explanations of what happened for the people that might find them (alive or dead). Absence of this is of course no evidence for foul play. But also,  their deaths are almost no comparison with the regular hiking-gone-wrong stories. It can contain some unique element of course which is a good explanation for this, but I think we should NOT look for that explanation in nature or the jungle. 

My working theory so far is that they tried to escape from someone who tried to do them harm or scared them with it’s behaviour, and therefore went north much further than they ever intended. After which they got seriously got lost. In a moment of presumed safety they started to make those pictures by daylight in which you see Kris by herself, instead of the two of them together. This to record where they have been while trying to get back. This also explains why they have been able to still use their phones and camera, unlike when they would have been kidnapped right away. Eventually the person they tried to get away from was simply waiting for them somewhere on a return path or caught up with them. This is when they eventually still met their fate… 

I’m convinced there is an unknown third party involved here, even though there is no direct evidence for it. So far it is the only theory I can think of that fits why they kept going north, were still able to use the phones, camera and so on and why they met similar fates. I would expect in a death by nature that eventually one of them died one way and the other at another moment in another way. If they died by nature I would not expect their stuff to also end up in different places, neither would I expect clothes to get separated from the body. 

I can only speculate who this was or what has happened then. And what has killed them.  But I do think the person(s) in point got nervous when all the police and investigators started to come in. This is why the criminal(s) has/ have succesfully (killed them, if they didn’t already and) chopped up and undressed the bodies (this explains how clothing and body got separated). Making it easier cooking meat from the bones or using something else to achieve a similar effect. This to eventually mask the cause of death and anything that might point to the one(s) guilty. Eventually this will also make it easy to scatter any evidence , hiding it in nature. To finally make sure enough is found for authorities to draw a conclusion from (the wrong one perferably) and stop any further investigation search. And permanently hide anything that has clear evidence of the crime. It explains why the backpack and everything in it was in top condition while the bodies were far from it. 

If it was organized crime I would have expected them to have enough power to make the investigation stop without scattering any evidence. This leads me to think it is some local criminal (group). Perhaps they removed the photo from the camera with a laptop (it is probably deleted after the last photo was taken, otherwise the number of the file might have been taken by the new photo) because it did contain evidence. Perhaps the local investigators did this after taking in the evidence, we can speculate on why. Perhaps because they want to hide the evidence to not damage the local tourism, perhaps they were pressured into it, perhaps the criminal works for law enforcement, perhaps it was an honest mistake and it means nothing.

I think that photo was the key, but I’m also convinced that any other evidence is needed to really crack this case. And I think any new discovery will support the theory above. We will see. 

I wish my best to the parents and family of Kris and Lisanne. I hope one day they will find closure. I am a father of a daughter myself and I don’t want to imagine what they must be going through. Nothing anybody will say will close this open wound in their hearts.
comment.author: @teqfreak

comment.text:
Haven't looked through many comments.. I don't know if this has been said before, or is potentially an obvious and commonly thought/proposed thing. But which of the girl's foot was it that was recovered that had that fracture or broken bone(s)? Ie, the one that was taking the pictures, or the one that seemed further ahead in the later pictures?
Furthermore, could it be determined if the break had occurred some amount of time prior to death? Because, if those questions aligned, I would suggest the possibility that, why the "photographer" girl seems to be lagging behind in the last photos, is DUE to having a foot injury and being unable to keep up as easily. And if you're in pain, not to mention feeling like you may be dragging/slowing your friend down, at least I'm the type of person who would most definitely take out something like a camera to try to make the situation a little more lighthearted, or take focus off the fact I'm needing to take longer. Or kinda hide my resting that foot with the seconds it takes to stand still to take a photo. etc.

While I def can't say anything for certain, that's something that just happened to come to mind. I personally strongly get the vibe they were being pursued by something. Be it human or even potentially an animal or something, but just, how I interpreted the details anyway, it seems like it all kinda aligns with that.
I also especially agree with, at least the possibility, I think it's more than a slight chance or a shot in the dark to assume that they were snapping photos, to use the flash, to help them navigate at night. I remember one of the first videos I watched and was introduced to this case for the first time, they actually had not mentioned or proposed that, but I naturally had thought of that as a possibility.

comment.text:
Great update. The bleaching and deleting of the hard-coded photo indicate this is done by experts. The most likely answer is they were abducted, and then murdered. At the time of the abduction, staged photos and calls were taken from the locked phone. The girls were held in captivity until the 'heat died down', and during those few months the girls were killed, bodies dismembered and bleached, and the camera had a photo deleted by a computer.   Then the girls belongings and body parts are all returned to the region where the girls went mission, so that they can be discovered and the case can be closed. Its not a coincidence that the bag was found so quickly. It was intended to be found, with the camera and money, so to complete the narrative that the girls became lost and died.

I realize this is a couch-detective nonsense, but given the above, this is not a mystery of how, but a mystery of who (Be it Government, serial killer, or local gang).

comment.text:
Cette affaire est terrible pour les familles . On ne refera pas l'histoire  mais on peut toujours essayer de comprendre ce qui est arrivé a ces deux jeunes femmes . Merci a Lionel d'avoir pu réunir ces documents qui permettent de réfléchir a cette affaire . il ne faut pas se faire trop d'illusions , cette affaire ne se résoudra pas autrement que par la volonté des autorités locales ....Il y a pas mal d'éléments pour la résoudre , semble t'il . D'abord ces jeunes femmes n'étaient pas si naives  et elles ont assurément fait confiance aux conseils d'un guide sauf que ce guide ne les accompagne pas . Ma question est pourquoi n'annulent elles pas leur randonnée dans ce cas ? Elles partent pourtant  rassurées et en confiance , mais bien seules ... Qu'est ce qui a pu les convaincre de partir ? La responsabilité du guide est fortement engagée et celui ci  a du avoir de bons arguments  pour les encourager .Cà , c'est une quasi certitude .Ensuite a la fin de la randonnée , elles s'engagent dans la jungle au lieu de rentrer donc elles ne sont plus seules : On les attendait certainement et encore une fois , elles sont convaincus de suivre des personnes qu'elles ne semblent pas connaitre puisque essaieront de les prendre en photo , l'appareil photo leur est retiré certainement après cela ,cela prouve bien que l'enlèvement est prémédité, il n'y a rien d'opportuniste dans cette rencontre, a mon avis  . A partir de la fameuse photo effacée ,elle ne seront plus maitresses de leurs mouvements ; Elles sont contraintes de suivre mais elles ont toujours leurs tel . Je note qu'elles ne prennent pas de photos avec leur tel mais envoient de nombreux appels de détresse et cela de nombreuses fois entre le 1er avril entre 16h39 elle 3 avril a 9h32 . c'est très long et cela cela correspond probablement à un très long périple d'au moins 12H avant que leurs tel et leurs sac leurs soient enlevé , probablement à l'arrivée . Le fait qu'il n'y  a pas de réseau , c'est qu'elles restent à l'écart de tout centre urbain . Un journée de marche dans la jungle dans des zones escarpées les amènent tout au plus a une trentaine de km de leur point de départ ( 15/20 km a vol  d'oiseau max ) ou elles seront séquestrés un bon bout de temps avant être assassiné . Enfin la découverte du sac et des ossements est peut être un geste envers les familles ce qui me fait penser que l'un des assassins aurait peut être été lui même en contact avec les familles et par intérêt ou je ne sais quoi , aurait laissé de maigres indices pour montrer que Lisanne et Kris étaient mortes .
Au passage ils ont du laisser ces indices loin du lieu de détention pour égarer encore l'enquête .Y aura t'il  résolution de l'affaire un jour , c'est peu probable mais qui sait ... souhaitons le .

comment.text:
For any interested:  The Photo 509 issue was convincingly solved by Rotten Raven Studios.  Their camera's firmware can skip a number in the filename sequence when the user is near a time zone border due to GPS exif data setting the clock back or forward.  Kris and Lisanne were within a few miles of a timezone border.  Photo 509 probably wasn't deleted because it was likely never taken in the first place.

Regarding the condition of the bodies:  It's a well known phenomenon that bodies skeletonize and disperse in just a few weeks when they're in the jungle due to heavy rainfall, insects, and large animals scavenging the remains.  Kris's bones were bleached white likely due to her dying first (as evidenced by the unsuccessful PIN attempts on her phone) so the elements had more time to act on them.  And also possibly by the location in which she died receiving more direct sunlight and/or faster insect-driven defleshing.

The backpack and contents being in pristine condition is the one piece of evidence that doesn't make sense.  But it's also possible that it was found by locals before they were aware of the disappearance, and later returned to the jungle by them anonymously in order to avoid suspicion of involvement by investigators.

comment.text:
Camera's memory card would use NAND flash, and the data woulda been stored as JPEGs. Wear levelling algorithms on the filesystem driver mean that it's highly unlikely the data of the photo 509 was overwritten by data from subsequent photos. Because of how the JPEG algorithm works (DCT --> compression), it's decently resilient to corruption. DCT transform offers some redundancy in case certain harmonics in the cosine sequence are lost, and compression makes it less likely that critical data was overwritten due to smaller size.

Two things make the deletion of image 509 particularly spooky to me:
1) I personally could probably recover IMG_509.
2) Notice that IMG_509 was taken between the last remarkably 'happy' photo taken by the girls, and photos of the wilderness at night... If that's not spooky, I dunno what is.

comment.text: What you say about the photo numbering presumes that 509 was taken and then deleted before another photo was taken. There is no logical reason to assume this. If you take 509 and then 510, then delete 509, then take a picture, that will be 511. The camera will not make another 509 until the highest numbered photo it has is 508. Reason for this is that when the camera saves a picture it simply looks up the highest numbered pic taken and does +1 as filename and saves. It does NOT look for 'missing' numbers in some series. Go ahead and try it your self if you have a camera. This is how every camera I've used and observed this particular aspect of has worked, when they use a numbering scheme, usually the filename is longer like MSCD01022002001 where MSCD is fixed, first 01 is day, 02 month, 2002 year, 001 number. The formats etc change but the logic has been the same across many camera brands.

comment.text: This is such an awful story. It is really haunting. I truly feel for the parents. It is so hard to speculate what the girls might/might not have done and whether they came to harm through natural events or something else. Playing armchair detective is pretty silly but, as a hiking guide, lots of things make me wonder about their story. The first thing is what time did they REALLY start hiking the trail. Morning around 10-11 am (as seems to be the case from their photos) or early afternoon, as the taxi driver who dropped them off states. How many daylight hours would you have left and how would that inform you decision about whether to turn back or carry on? I understand the parents saying 'why didn't they take any photos from here, it's so beautiful?' but I don't really think it tells us much (taken enough pics,  too tired to get your camera out of your backpack, can't be bothered...there are some many reasons).  Something like a sprained ankle could be catastrophic enough, as it impedes one from walking and doesn't leave enough time to return via the way you came in daylight hours), why didn't they split up and the uninjured person try to seek help? I have no idea what happened to them and it's useless to speculate but what an awful way to die and how horrific for the parents, who will probably never get closure.
