comment.text:
This was very well done, but there are a few issues missed:
Feliciano is Henry’s father, and they have coffee farms near where the girls were found. The Indigenous woman who ‘found’ the backpack was one of his employees

While I now believe the girls indeed met their fate at that swimming pool/hot spring, it doesn’t explain why Lisanne’s foot was found in her boot if she was swimming. 

I had not thought about the police changing the photos to fit their narrative. 

The biggest question is motive: Why go through this elaborate cover up when the area is full of criminal activity. This is something that was done in a very calculated, planned manner that lends me to believe there is a larger issue at hand: Something a government or people who are higher up the chain to create this.

The school was a red flag for me from the start, and even more , another student went with Feliciano to the girl’s room and was there for 30 mins with him, and the next day, she flew back to Germany. That was a HUGE red flag and if she could be found, she could confirm if he removed things that indicated the girls did indeed return to the hostel to get swimming garments etc.

I hold the Panamanian Government responsible for this because they are keeping it covered up. If that food/ those insoles of shoes were indeed found at a cave, why were they not tested for DNA? Why was the swimming hole investigation not made public?

Even worse, I think they went to the Henry/Feliciano’s Coffee Farm, you’d find the girls remains and possibly many others, but the government chooses not to, lending me to think that family has ties inside the government and why this was swept under the rug.

Lastly, we have no idea if the girls were raped. That’s just speculation and best not to add for the sake of the families. The witness can only account for what she saw, not what she thought or was told. 
Lastly, since Kris’s bones were found bleached and stripped vs Lisanne’s that were still covered in flesh, it is safe to say Kris died first. Again, until you have concrete evidence to prove that lungs were given to an organ donor, we can not make assumptions. 

Again, please think of the families and the heart ache they must feel hearing these stories over and over again.

comment.text:
What happened here was an accident. Kris and Lisanne wandered off the beaten path and got lost. Both tried to call emergency services to no avail. On April 8th, one week after they originally set off, both girls attempted to cross a monkey bridge at night and Kris fell and most likely died. Lisanne checked the head wound using her camera flash. Realising Kris was dead, Lisanne using paper set up an SOS and a mirror to try to grab attention from above to where Kris' body was. She took many photos at night of the sky to try to catch the attention of helicopters which at this point were looking for the girls and, using common sense, by now she would know there are people looking for them as they have not returned home for several days. Lisanne used two arrows made from twigs and plastic, one pointing to Kris' body, and the other across a monkey bridge, where she would be crossing to get help.

Lisanne's battery ran out on her phone as records show, and at this point, she was using Kris' phone which she could not access as she did not know the PIN. As bone fragments from both girls were found close together, Lisanne most likely also fell nearby and broke her foot and checked for a signal. Unable to go on, most likely she lay there on April 6 for five days to conserve her strength and did not try to use her phone until April 11th. She turned on the phone one last time and left it on for one hour hoping that someone would be able to call her. After an hour the phone was turned off to conserve battery and then passed away. Because she had only Kris' phone and did not know the PIN, Lisanne was unable to leave any messages to loved ones. Due to being in the forest, their bodies decomposed at an accelerated rate and got washed away/eaten by animals.

I cannot imagine what Lisanne was going through in her final days dying of starvation, thirst, and being totally alone.

comment.text:
Theory:

When the girls reached the end of the trail the girls began to walk back.  On the way back they encountered Feliciano Gonzalez and friends(maybe including his son and Plineo Montenegro). Feliciano started to molest them and threaten them with his machete. He then told them to march on along one of the trails. He menaced Lisanne with his machete and threatened to harm her if Kris ran away. He told Lisanne to take a couple photos of on the trail, so as to have evidence on the camera to show they had continued on the trail. He directed them which way to go until they reached his coffee farm. He took them to a cave or building near or on the farm. He and his friends raped the girls. He tied them up so they could not escape. He may have deliberately hobbled them by dropped something very heavy on their feet. With the girls imprisoned on his farm he returned to Boquete to visit the place where they were staying. The girls had either secreted the phones on their persons or they were left in a place where it was possible for them to gain access to them with care. Maybe Feliciano knew there would be no phone connection. Feliciano and friends returned repeatedly over a period of days to the farm to rape the girls. He gave them some food and water. Finally after a number of days when he had lost interest in them and when the hunt for the girls was picking up he ended up killing them both Kris first and Lisanne later. He planted evidence such as the bones and the backpack. The night time photos, I am not sure, I guess were most likely taken by the men and not the girls as I can't see why Lisanne would take a photo of the back of Kris's head. I would think that most of the remains of the girls are on or near his farm.

This gives a clear idea of my train of thought. I am not claiming that every  detail is exactly as I describe it, it is possible that some things happened slightly differently.

I think that it is quite inappropriate to harass Mr. Feliciano Gonzalez. Someone is innocent until proven guilty. Having said, from all I know about the case he would be my prime suspect. It is unfortunate that DNA and fingerprints were not analysed. I daresay he selected/planted only the bones which did not have signs of foul play and that is why the other body parts haven't been discovered. Has anyone taken DNA samples from Feliciano or taken his fingerprints? If you can find his DNA or fingerprints where they aren't supposed to be according to his story then you have got something. For example, his DNA or fingerprints should not be on Kris's shorts as supposedly they were not found by him. I would suspect that his DNA is all over the items in their backpack much more so than if he just found it. It might be possible to find traces of his DNA on bones that were found by others. Where are these items of evidence now: the bones, the shoe, the backpack etc. ?

His farm should be thoroughly searched and where appropriate tested for fingerprints and DNA, even the slightest evidence that could show that the girls had been on or near that farm would be crucial.

comment.text: They went to the summit and continued down the Serpent Trail for a bit to check out a waterfall. Then they returned to the summit and back to town. Look at the photos, and you'll see them switch backpacks. If you're two people with one backpack, you'll have one person carry it one way, and then you'll switch. You won't switch constantly, the photos have been rearranged. The timestamps don't make sense, for example having their hair up and down only seconds apart. Multiple witnesses said they saw the girls return to town around 2-4pm. The girls met up with a small local gang of bandidos, 2 of whom are now dead because they started to crack. One of their mothers said her son told her he saw the girls in their red pickup truck. He drowned suspiciously. The taxi driver who took them to the trail also drowned suspiciously. Another gang member confessed to the mother he killed her son. He was run over suspiciously. There was a female witness, a girlfriend of the gang, who fled to Costa Rica after telling police the gang killed the girls. This information is out there if you look.

comment.text:
I see this case was covered fairly recently this year. I looked into this last year during lockdown and it was haunting and morbidly fascinated me. 
- My overriding conclusion is the same: that they set off on the trail. Kris was injured to the head I think (Lisanne may have tried to take a photo). Perhaps they both fell = Kris hit head, lisanne broke arm? Then they tried to take photos so natives or search parties would see them. I believe they sheltered on a rock ledge near the river slope. The twigs with plastic bag was an attempt to document where they had been - and feeble because Lisanne was injured herself perhaps. Kris may have had a worse head injury than anticipated and lost consciousness, causing lisanne to panic and try to guess pin code to Kris's phone. This was unsuccessful. Then I theorise that Lisanne, or both of them, came to an extreme conclusion which ultimately ended their lives = perhaps Lisanne, though herself injured, tried to carry kris but slipped and both perished in the river. Perhaps they somehow deludedly thought they could float down river quicker and easier than walking to safety? As to the remains being found: I believe perhaps natives found the backpack and placed it neatly with other strewn garments. The bleached bones and strewn remains may have spoke to my aforementioned theory that lisanne was trying to carry Kris down the river somehow, but both ultimately perished in the river. They may have even felt guilty they didn't find the girls themselves and so gathered certain items, bone fragments, remains etc and piled them together to be found.

The haunting aspect, more haunting than the above theory they were tragically killed by misfortune and misadventure, is that you can't rule out that they were intercepted by someone and killed. Not a serial killer perhaps....But an amoral killer, maybe even someone with learning difficulties who lives with the natives or nearby and saw two pretty girls as prey. Or more sinister still a guide who killed them by mistake or out of emotional conflict. That image being deleted is quite incriminating. Though again, I can still imagine maybe the girls even deleted it because it showed them in distress and they didn't want loved ones to see that in the photos if found.

comment.author: @chloec277

comment.text:
In the end, I think they let themselves be trapped by the arrival of night.
After photo 508, I think Lisanne dropped her camera on the ground or in the water. Making it unusable. Despite everything, they continued a little on the trail and at one point they decided to go back but they saw that the light was dropping very quickly in certain portions since we are in the tropics and the sun rises at 6:00 in the morning and goes to bed at 6:00 p.m. all year round.
They are therefore on their way back but they realize that they need at least two or three hours of walking and a large part of this walk will have to take place at night. They worry because they know the places they have already passed and know that without a flashlight, in the dark of night, it is very difficult and distressing.
That’s when they try to call for help, if only to say where they are because they didn’t tell anyone in the end. They just said they were going for a walk.
But impossible to contact anyone: no network.
At that moment, they were not injured, nor pursued by anyone, just anxious at the idea of ​​returning at night. The wisest thing would have been to land somewhere in open ground and resolve to spend the night there and leave the next morning at first light. In a video, the mother of Kriss who came on the trail explains that she is absolutely sure that if one of the girls had been injured, they would have stayed on the trail and waited. The problem actually is that he There was no injury or other, only from being trapped by the time and the arrival of night, and also from not having warned anyone.

I think that by trying to retrace the path at night, she had a high chance of getting lost, falling, slipping, etc. Which at night reinforces the seriousness of the situation.
So they get lost. And the second catastrophe arrives, no one knows where they went or more precisely, no one knows that they continued beyond the Mirador, towards the North on the path. So by the time we organize the research, a lot of time will pass. And we will have to wait until April 6 for research to be done on the other side of the Mirador. That is to say that the girls got lost, that they continued to move during these 6 days, if only to try to find a place with a little network. And obviously in 6 days, without food or very little (?), without water except that of the river (risk of diarrhea that one of the girls already had not long before during the stay), without being able to make a fire. Fear, anxiety, stress, exhaustion...etc. When the search begins beyond the Mirador, the girls are already in a bad state in my opinion.

On April 8, they have been in the jungle for 7 days! It is said that you can survive 3 minutes without breathing, 3 days without drinking and 3 weeks without eating. I think they were in the state of people who go on hunger strike. They must have remained in bed, half lucid. One may be more affected than the other.
On the night of April 8, they heard noise, perhaps light signals in the sky or something else coming from the search teams. I think Lisanne understands that you have to try something to stand out. They are obviously in no condition to scream or anything. So she takes out the camera which she had put to dry and which she had not tried to get it working again since. And it works again. This is possible if the device fell into water and was quickly removed from the water. In time he can works again. So she decides to use it to make flash shots towards the sky. Obviously it takes photos at the same time but the goal is the flash.
She is exhausted and at the same time held by the hope of being seen. She awkwardly directs the flash towards the ground a few times which causes her to accidentally take a photo of Kriss' hair who is probably lying sleepy next to her or her head on Lisanne's legs.
But it doesn't work, the noises and signals go away. The only hope for days has vanished. We didn't see them.

I think they end up dying of exhaustion and hunger. Not necessarily at the same time.

Subsequently, the rainy season set in, causing rivers to swell and causing flooding. Their bodies were carried away by the waves, disintegrating as they decomposed....

RQ / *Contrary to what has often been said, the bag was dirty and damp when they found it. The items they contained were also damp and the devices were unusable. The Dutch experts had difficulty using them; it was easier with SD cards.
*The fact that the young women took off their bras appears normal  considering the conditions in which they were (heat, humidity, etc.).
*The shorts again were not found dry and folded neatly on a stone. It was dirty, wet and with holes.
*There have never been 70 pin code attempts in 1 day as has been said. In fact it was the Dutch experts who determined that since the phone was put into service, there had been 70 unsuccessful pin code attempts. That is to say that since the girl had been using her cell phone, it had happened to her 70 times of making a mistake when typing your code.
*There has never been a scrap of human flesh found with bones, which seemed impossible as decomposition would have made it disappear very quickly. In fact this scrap of flesh was analyzed and it was beef.

comment.text:
This is in my mind, a pretty strong case of human trafficking. Its unfortunately a huge business still, and a very VERY profitable. There are many people in their pockets over it. I was on the fence about this one, until you hear that people who came forward with information ended up dead too. This reeks of exerted power.

The emergency calls were probably done in their pockets in secret, trying to quietly get help. The night photos could have been in panic after running in the dark, trying to see where they were going, or one of them fell down a cliff, and the the other took pictures trying to see where she had landed in the photo - not to actually try and see her with the flash because you'd just turn the flashlight on if that were the case.

The deleted picture was probably one of the captors, who are no strangers to cleaning out phones.

Why not just trash the phone completely?
Because its possible part of the goal of these trafficking cases is, in my opinion, attempting to make sure it looks like no trafficking was involved.

Why has the investigation not released the last photo?
Few reasons - Ongoing investigation into who/what it shows, gore, nudity, or corruption.

comment.text: Kremers was the killer. It was always Kremers from the very start. jealousy, envy and hate are at the heart of this case. it is Kerscher and Knox in the jungle. Kremers was indeed a marvellous actress and she played the role of a lifetime in pursuading the naive and empathic Froon that she was her new "bestie". as much as Knox despised Kerscher, Arias depised Alexander and mertens despised corbett, so it came to pass that Kremers despised Froon. Kremers would plan the necessary demise of her empathic rival, her arch nemesis Froon well in advance. Kremers work pre kill is generally very good. She makes the decision early and correctly that it cannot happen on dutch soil, too many obstacles, lack of a viable kill zone, more competent police officers. Kremers uses Froon's pending graduation as an excuse to promote an adventure abroad. Kremers was in Peru previously but Froon had never been further than southern germany. Through a series of subtle manipulations Kremers pursuades not only Froon but Froon's family that the trip will be fine. Getting Froon out of holland is the first and most important thing. Most of Kremers work PRE KILL is in general very very good and she brings her A game to the table. POST KILL is a different matter and this in my view is down to youth and inexperience. Kremers is only 21 and this is a first kill scenario. This can happen with female killers in particular. Hubers notoriously never got passed her 911 call, Arias stupidly left the camera in the washing machine. Kremers would more or less fall into the same trap. On the positive side, there are some nice touches PRE KILL. The date of april fools day as the nominated kill date is ingenius. theirs was a fake friendship, Kremers an imaginary friend, a made up thing in Froon's head. the date is hugely hugely significant. Kremers has correctly considered the issue of WEIGHT on the day. She ensures only one backpack is taken and that it is lightly packed. this shows that she was still in A game mode on the morning of the hike. she knows that she cannot manage two backpacks and Froon at the same time. Kremers, who after the debacle with the school would have been in self congratulatory mood nearly made a fundamental error. Kremers has miscalculated that anyone would find it odd that her and Froon would go on the hike unaccompanied. Here Kremers has noticed considerable pushback from locals including guides that such a trip would be undertaken alone. Kremers nearly misses a beat here. what should have been a minor manipulation to orchestrate the trip with Froon has suddenly become problematic. Kremers has to manipulate a "back off" maneouver which will have the necessary effect of having not only the host convinced but any guides or other locals querying the hike that they ARE NOT going alone. Kremers books a guide for April 2 to undertake the trail. this is good but she should have booked a different walk and not the same one. April 1 - fools day. Today is the day all be revealed  Kremers and Froon get a taxi to the beginning of the main trail. Kremers is a bit cocky here in my view as the driver (depending on what is said in the taxi) may have alerted the now fatally compromised Froon that it was "madness" to go on the walk without a guide. nonetheless they both exit and begin the walk. Kremers would know by now that she was virtually home and hosed barring some completely unforseen event. It is vital for Kremers to keep up the fake facade for only a little while longer. However this is proving difficult. Kremers is getting very excited, she has fantazied about this for months. Kremers and Froon approach the summit. Kremers is left with one final subtle manipulation. Getting Froon off trail. Kremers will use the fact that the walk itself was uneventful and that no guide was ever required. a simple ruse by locals to earn money. Froon fatally falls again for Kremers manipulations. Once off trail Froon will never be photographed again. In Kremers mind Froon by now an irrelevancy, a figure of fun, a fool. by a series of subtle lies and manipulations over many months she had drawn her prey to her own death. Froon either consciously or unconsciously had the wherewithall to take those final few pictures of Kremers showing the slow and gradual transformation of Kremers from Jekyl to Hyde. the pictures of Kremers show a dominant figure posing with authority. no longer do we see cheesy smiles and hand gestures that mimic her empathic rival. we are beyond that now. the real self will emerge, the monster unleased. I am often asked if Froon knew of her fate. I believe Yes that in those final minutes Froon did indeed know something was seriously wrong with Kremers and she would have been very concerned. Froon left her evidence on her phone and Kremers who was not as smart as she thought she was,  stupidly only deleted the attack photo when she should have deleted all the off trail pictures. the last surviving photo should have been at the summit on the main trail. This would have created a much more enticing narrative.
comment.author: @seanburke7487

comment.text:
No fool play.
In the end, I think they let themselves be trapped by the arrival of night.
After photo 508, I think Lisanne dropped her camera on the ground or in the water. Making it unusable. Despite everything, they continued a little on the trail and at one point they decided to go back but they saw that the light was dropping very quickly in certain portions since we are in the tropics and the sun rises at 6:00 in the morning and goes to bed at 6:00 p.m. all year round.
They are therefore on their way back but they realize that they need at least two or three hours of walking and a large part of this walk will have to take place at night. They worry because they know the places they have already passed and know that without a flashlight, in the dark of night, it is very difficult and distressing.
That’s when they try to call for help, if only to say where they are because they didn’t tell anyone in the end. They just said they were going for a walk.
But impossible to contact anyone: no network.
At that moment, they were not injured, nor pursued by anyone, just anxious at the idea of ​​returning at night. The wisest thing would have been to land somewhere in open ground and resolve to spend the night there and leave the next morning at first light. In a video, the mother of Kriss who came on the trail explains that she is absolutely sure that if one of the girls had been injured, they would have stayed on the trail and waited. The problem actually is that he There was no injury or other, only from being trapped by the time and the arrival of night, and also from not having warned anyone.

I think that by trying to retrace the path at night, she had a high chance of getting lost, falling, slipping, etc. Which at night reinforces the seriousness of the situation.
So they get lost. And the second catastrophe arrives, no one knows where they went or more precisely, no one knows that they continued beyond the Mirador, towards the North on the path. So by the time we organize the research, a lot of time will pass. And we will have to wait until April 6 for research to be done on the other side of the Mirador. That is to say that the girls got lost, that they continued to move during these 6 days, if only to try to find a place with a little network. And obviously in 6 days, without food or very little (?), without water except that of the river (risk of diarrhea that one of the girls already had not long before during the stay), without being able to make a fire. Fear, anxiety, stress, exhaustion...etc. When the search begins beyond the Mirador, the girls are already in a bad state in my opinion.

On April 8, they have been in the jungle for 7 days! It is said that you can survive 3 minutes without breathing, 3 days without drinking and 3 weeks without eating. I think they were in the state of people who go on hunger strike. They must have remained in bed, half lucid. One may be more affected than the other.
On the night of April 8, they heard noise, perhaps light signals in the sky or something else coming from the search teams. I think Lisanne understands that you have to try something to stand out. They are obviously in no condition to scream or anything. So she takes out the camera which she had put to dry and which she had not tried to get it working again since. And it works again. This is possible if the device fell into water and was quickly removed from the water. In time he can works again. So she decides to use it to make flash shots towards the sky. Obviously it takes photos at the same time but the goal is the flash.
She is exhausted and at the same time held by the hope of being seen. She awkwardly directs the flash towards the ground a few times which causes her to accidentally take a photo of Kriss' hair who is probably lying sleepy next to her or her head on Lisanne's legs.
But it doesn't work, the noises and signals go away. The only hope for days has vanished. We didn't see them.

I think they end up dying of exhaustion and hunger. Not necessarily at the same time.

Subsequently, the rainy season set in, causing rivers to swell and causing flooding. Their bodies were carried away by the waves, disintegrating as they decomposed....

RQ / *Contrary to what has often been said, the bag was dirty and damp when they found it. The items they contained were also damp and the devices were unusable. The Dutch experts had difficulty using them; it was easier with SD cards.
*The fact that the young women took off their bras appears normal  considering the conditions in which they were (heat, humidity, etc.).
*The shorts again were not found dry and folded neatly on a stone. It was dirty, wet and with holes.
*There have never been 70 pin code attempts in 1 day as has been said. In fact it was the Dutch experts who determined that since the phone was put into service, there had been 70 unsuccessful pin code attempts. That is to say that since the girl had been using her cell phone, it had happened to her 70 times of making a mistake when typing your code.
*There has never been a scrap of human flesh found with bones, which seemed impossible as decomposition would have made it disappear very quickly. In fact this scrap of flesh was analyzed and it was beef.

comment.author: @mandydoddFL

comment.text: Couple notes: 112 is the emergency number virtually anywhere in the world if you're using a cell phone. You should only use convenience numbers like 911 if you're using a landline phone that does not follow this international convention. Second, and largely unanswered is how the girls managed to keep their phone running for so long off of battery. I doubt the iPhone/Galaxy phone could take hundreds of photos, make a few emergency calls, and be power cycled on and off for 8 days. Unless they had an external battery pack, which in early 2014 wasn't as prevalent as they were today, something doesn't add up. My guess is their phone remained powered on during the first day, then the perpetrator keep the phone powered on to lead investigators astray. Another thing: how come several calls to 112 lead to no answer? My understanding is that emergency numbers generally should work, even in more remote areas. It's one of the few things that actually you can somewhat count on. Unsure what the cell infrastructure was over there at that time, but it does seem bizarre that they'd try many times over a course of several days and not once did their call get connected. Taking a photo to activate the flash to see where you're going seems a bit strange, although I suppose in 2014 flashlight capability wasn't built in to all phones. However, it does seem a bit strange that again they would have the battery power to take all those photos, even activating flash and it all lasting several days. Another thing, why didn't they just wait till the following day for sunlight to descend from where they were and seek help? The most dangerous time to be moving is night time without any illumination.
comment.author: @j2simpso

comment.text: It seems we are closer than ever before to finding what actually happened. The only way to know is to first find the night location where the pictures were taken in a hope to reconstruct the most logical path taken from there back to the trail. There is a general location which is being hypothesized as the most likely, which is on one of the rivers in a large valley that is to the East of the trail. It looks like the most likely thing that happened was the girls went pretty far down the other side of the mirador, but not all the way to the monkey bridges. It's not exactly clear how far they went, because they could have also taken a long stop by one of the streams, for example. The important part is that by the time they decided to head back they no longer had enough time to make the full trail before they lost visibility on the track due to the sun going down. On April 1st, the sun would go down fully roughly around 6:40 pm, though the girls didn't have that long. The trail would be enveloped by darkness considerably earlier than that since the sun would be blocked out by the mountains at some point, and only a portion of that light would make it thru the dense canopy of the forest. Anyone that's been in a forest during sunset knows what I mean; it can still be really bright outside the treeline but as soon as you start walking deeper in it feels like the sun has completely went down. It is likely that due to this, they left the trail and ended up finding a river that starts around this point, about half-way back up to the Mirador. If they went the West on that river, the direction of the trail they came from, they would find their path blocked by a large 10 meter high waterfall, which they couldn't realistically scale. This means it is more likely that they decided to follow the river East instead of going back into the jungle and trying to retrace their steps to the trail. Eventually that river turns into a series of rapids and smaller cascading waterfalls, which they would be on the top end of. Since there was barely any water in the river on April 1st, there is a good chance they tried making their way further down so they could continue following the river. It is likely one of them got hurt at this point, probably Lisanne, whose ankle showed that it was broken in three places. They continued a while further but at a certain point stopped and set up that camp we saw in the night photos. This would be April 8th so they would both be exhausted and hungry from not eating for a week at this point. Lisanne also had an infection from an inflamed femur which suggested she had been walking for a very long time, so it is less likely that the injury occurred very early on into the trip. It's likely Kris carried Lisanne for a while but she too eventually became exhausted from the lack of food. They most likely stayed in that night location where they set up the SOS signal and the reflective surface which was the bottom of a pringles can. The flag/marker they made was most likely at first a red bag over a branch which later got torn and became what we see in the photo. Kris and Lisanne seemed to be in a small area that provided some shelter from the rain, like a little cove at the bottom of an embankment where a steep hill meets the river shore. The flag was just tall enough to stick up over a boulder if leaned against it, which is probably where they left it when they were sleeping in case searchers were walking down the river and didn't see them. No one has searched this area yet as it is pretty far away and really dangerous to cross during wet seasons due to the strong currents. It doesn't seem anyone searched that river at all in time to have saved the girls either, but a Dutch team did go down that river in 2015 only to stop at the rapids/waterfalls. Kris and Lisanne couldnt have realistically made their way back up those falls either once they got down, especially if one of them was badly injured at that point. The area the night photos were taken also must flood during the wet season which explains why their remains and belongings were carried further down the river a few months later.
comment.author: @interstellarlapisthecccp4946

But for me... it would be STRONG evidence pointing to the fact that the girls did indeed become lost and perished in the elements.

comment.text:
Super vidéo, mais selon moi l'hypothèse criminel ne repose sur pas grand chose à part la photo manquante. Pourquoi les individus responsable de leur mort iraient supprimer cette unique photo avec une manip de fou sur un PC alors qu'ils leur suffisait de détruire la carte mémoire? Je trouve ça quand même un peu tiré par les cheveux. Pareil pour la chaux, pourquoi disperser des parties du corps avec cet élément incriminant alors qu'ils suffisait d'enterrer les corps ou les brûler. Dans des zones aussi reculer c'est pas ce qu'il y a de plus compliqué. Bref cette théorie a tout du bon scénar' de film policier, mais en vrai, j'ai des doutes.

A mon avis l'explication est beaucoup plus terre à terre. Les filles se sont perdue ou se sont bléssées (du moins l'une d'entre elle), elle ont appelé les secours, mais n'ayant aucun signal elles ont économisé la batterie. Plus tard Kriss meurt, Lisanne n'ayant plus accès à son portable tante d'utiliser celui de Kriss, sans succès, faute de code pin. Puis vient l'épisode de l'appareil photo, sans doute une tentative de se faire remarquer ou alors une technique pour se repérer dans le noir. Enfin Lisanne fini par périr suite à une chute ou tout autre accident sans doute à cause de l'épuisement. 

Pour les recherche c'est assez facilement explicable tout simplement parce que c'est très, très difficile de retrouver des personnes perdues, même en France. Il suffit de regarder des reportages sur des équipes de secours ou de recherche comme la sécurité civile pour s'en convaincre. Alors au Panama, dans des zones reculés avec une forêt dense, sans réseaux, sans route... voilà quoi.

Quoi qu'il en soit ayons une pensée pour ces jeunes filles et leur famille. Ce genre d'histoire me glace le sang qu'elle soit criminelle ou accidentelle.

They never were at the mirador but they try to get there.

comment.text:
So, a couple things to note.  Scavenger animals could easily have caused the vast distances of the bones.  It could also explain the bleaching, if the bone was picked clean and left in the sun long enough.  Without more details, that's hard to say.  Am I saying with confidence that this was the case, no.   But, it is a reason they could have concluded an accidental death.  Regarding the bag, that's a tough one.  Assuming the lady that found it was telling the truth, and did not have it longer, it seems someone would have placed it where it was found.  But, they could have found it in a much different way, and only got scared when investigations were happening in their village and just didn't want to be a part of it.  Let's face it, people lie.  

All in all, it's an interesting case.  Why the picture of the back of the head?  Was it to document what happened, was the flashing being used as a light because they heard something in the wilderness that scared them?  That seems more probable to me.  But, why was a photo deleted?  Very strange and so little information to go on.  These types of cases are just difficult in general.  And since it doesn't seem that a full body was ever found, it's even more difficult to answer.  I am curious why more caves  or outcroppings of rocks were not checked in the jungles near the areas where items were found.  It's clear in the photo that they were in some sort of cave or under some sort of outcropping.  It would be interesting to retrace their steps based on their photos as best as possible.

comment.text: In the rainforest where I come from if you wander off from a main trail along a lightly used trail it is not all that uncommon to come upon a drug plantation hidden from satellite under the canopy. Often they are booby-trapped. If that happened to the girls, and then the growers/drug traffickers found them later, it would explain some of those odd photos (including that one of the hair with blood, and night photos. Also, it is not uncommon for drug gangs in parts of remote Sth America to be part of Death Cults that engage in human sacrifice in belief that it will bring prosperity. That could explain the state of the bones, and the missing photo. It's a theory. There have been some violent cult sacrifices in Sth America, including in the remote Panamanian jungle.

comment.text:
I have a theory.. The night pictures have been analyzed and shown to have all been taken close together facing the same direction for the most part.

April 8th, the day of the night photos was the first day of major rain in the area. Its also obvious that it was raining in many of the pictures, extremely heavily. What if they slept in a bad spot that washed out or they were forced off a hillside by moving water. In the fall kris was possibly injured and the girls were disoriented. The night photos were taken as a way to get some grasp of where they were and to check kris' injury. The next day they stripped off their clothes to dry them out and something unfortunate happened causing them to wash down the river, whether an accident or devious people. 

I also suspect that the bag was looted and the thief got scared when the case became more high profile and ditched it. It still doesn't make sense to me that the contents of the bag were dry and undamaged however. Perhaps the bag got foubd early on and the last time kris' phone was turned on was the person who found the bag checking the function of the electronics. 

Its pretty hard to put any theories together on this case, all the evidence is so unsatisfying. The state of the remains seems unreasonable for natural causes. comment.text: Excellent work! here is some update on the case. The plausible reconstruction indicates that those responsible include the guide's son (they can investigate him) and his band at that time. They found the girls around the road and they went in a truck (reported by witnesses) to a nearby ranch. They took photos with them at the beginning (photos deleted) and went to the ranch to drink and with the intention of drugging them to seduce them and have "luck with them." The girls resisted and the situation got out of hand, so they ended up beating them to death. In fact, when they became aware of what they had done, it was too late, they dismembered them and then used the camera to plant evidence. The bones were, in fact, subjected to a chemical treatment. The backpack was planted at the scene and the random photos were taken by the perpetrators with the aim of misleading the investigators, not by the girls. Several direct witnesses were indeed killed by this little band. The reason why it was not investigated is a mix of factors ranging from political issues (the ranch, its owner and his connections) and the ineptitude of the Prosecutor at that time (corruption). Many police officers already knew about this. The point is to make the case visible and reopen it. These people now have less power than before and letting this favorable moment pass would be to continue giving a negative message so that these people continue doing things without consequences. We trust that the people of Panama and especially of Boquete can be encouraged to report (with precautions). already through justice or at least add contributions through these social media outlets: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wiuCAUSY5DI&t=0s

comment.text:
In the end, I think they let themselves be trapped by the arrival of night.
After photo 508, I think Lisanne dropped her camera on the ground or in the water. Making it unusable. Despite everything, they continued a little on the trail and at one point they decided to go back but they saw that the light was dropping very quickly in certain portions since we are in the tropics and the sun rises at 6:00 in the morning and goes to bed at 6:00 p.m. all year round.
They are therefore on their way back but they realize that they need at least two or three hours of walking and a large part of this walk will have to take place at night. They worry because they know the places they have already passed and know that without a flashlight, in the dark of night, it is very difficult and distressing.
That’s when they try to call for help, if only to say where they are because they didn’t tell anyone in the end. They just said they were going for a walk.
But impossible to contact anyone: no network.
At that moment, they were not injured, nor pursued by anyone, just anxious at the idea of ​​returning at night. The wisest thing would have been to land somewhere in open ground and resolve to spend the night there and leave the next morning at first light. In a video, the mother of Kriss who came on the trail explains that she is absolutely sure that if one of the girls had been injured, they would have stayed on the trail and waited. The problem actually is that he There was no injury or other, only from being trapped by the time and the arrival of night, and also from not having warned anyone.

I think that by trying to retrace the path at night, she had a high chance of getting lost, falling, slipping, etc. Which at night reinforces the seriousness of the situation.
So they get lost. And the second catastrophe arrives, no one knows where they went or more precisely, no one knows that they continued beyond the Mirador, towards the North on the path. So by the time we organize the research, a lot of time will pass. And we will have to wait until April 6 for research to be done on the other side of the Mirador. That is to say that the girls got lost, that they continued to move during these 6 days, if only to try to find a place with a little network. And obviously in 6 days, without food or very little (?), without water except that of the river (risk of diarrhea that one of the girls already had not long before during the stay), without being able to make a fire. Fear, anxiety, stress, exhaustion...etc. When the search begins beyond the Mirador, the girls are already in a bad state in my opinion.

On April 8, they have been in the jungle for 7 days! It is said that you can survive 3 minutes without breathing, 3 days without drinking and 3 weeks without eating. I think they were in the state of people who go on hunger strike. They must have remained in bed, half lucid. One may be more affected than the other.
On the night of April 8, they heard noise, perhaps light signals in the sky or something else coming from the search teams. I think Lisanne understands that you have to try something to stand out. They are obviously in no condition to scream or anything. So she takes out the camera which she had put to dry and which she had not tried to get it working again since. And it works again. This is possible if the device fell into water and was quickly removed from the water. In time he can works again. So she decides to use it to make flash shots towards the sky. Obviously it takes photos at the same time but the goal is the flash.
She is exhausted and at the same time held by the hope of being seen. She awkwardly directs the flash towards the ground a few times which causes her to accidentally take a photo of Kriss' hair who is probably lying sleepy next to her or her head on Lisanne's legs.
But it doesn't work, the noises and signals go away. The only hope for days has vanished. We didn't see them.

I think they end up dying of exhaustion and hunger. Not necessarily at the same time.

Subsequently, the rainy season set in, causing rivers to swell and causing flooding. Their bodies were carried away by the waves, disintegrating as they decomposed....

RQ / *Contrary to what has often been said, the bag was dirty and damp when they found it. The items they contained were also damp and the devices were unusable. The Dutch experts had difficulty using them; it was easier with SD cards.
*The fact that the young women took off their bras appears normal  considering the conditions in which they were (heat, humidity, etc.).
*The shorts again were not found dry and folded neatly on a stone. It was dirty, wet and with holes.
*There have never been 70 pin code attempts in 1 day as has been said. In fact it was the Dutch experts who determined that since the phone was put into service, there had been 70 unsuccessful pin code attempts. That is to say that since the girl had been using her cell phone, it had happened to her 70 times of making a mistake when typing your code.
*There has never been a scrap of human flesh found with bones, which seemed impossible as decomposition would have made it disappear very quickly. In fact this scrap of flesh was analyzed and it was beef.

comment.text:
Coucou, super Horroria, merci je ne connaissais pas cette histoire. Tellement de questions sans réponses... je me demande également si l'eau retrouvée dans la bouteille était de l'eau de la rivière ou l'eau qu'elles avaient de base. On ne parle pas non plus de si oui ou non de l'ADN a été retrouvé sur le sac, short, etc. 
Et le fait qu'il y aie si peu d'ossements, ça laisse aussi tellement de possibilités (attaque d'animal, accident, os brisés). 
Je pense sincèrement que si toutes les infos n'ont pas été divulguées c'est pour de "bonnes" raisons (peur de la baisse du tourisme, photos ou messages extrêmement choquants ou sensibles, par respect envers les familles, etc). 
C'est humain de vouloir chercher "pourquoi?", on veut toujours trouver une réponse et surtout, comprendre. Mais parfois la réponse est tellement dure et cruelle, qu'on refuse de l'accepter. 
Pour ma part je pense que c'était un accident. Peut-être qu'elles ont voulu continuer d'explorer en pensant faire demi-tour plus tard, mais qu'une a glissé, ou Lisanne a eu un problème de santé avec ses chevilles, et qu'en effet elles sont restées statiques en tentant de joindre les secours. Et que le lendemain avec le tremblement de terre elles se sont définitivement perdues. 
Le fait qu'il y aie eu un noyé 3 jours après, peut être une coïncidence. Les autres morts aussi, tout comme la photo 509. Finalement on n'a même pas toutes les infos, photos, etc. 
Et le fait que le guide aie passé 2h dans leur chambre ne me choque pas. Dans les pays latins, on parle bcp, on échange longuement. Une expedition ça se prépare et ça se discute, et avec la barrière de la langue ça a aussi pu prendre du temps. Et puis qui témoigne de cette durée? Comment s'est vérifié? Il y a tellement de choses vagues dans cette histoire... 
Pour moi c'est une accumulation de conséquences déstastreuses, un accident. 
Il y a aussi la possibilité qu'une des deux filles aie une maladie mentale qui se soit déclarée suite à une chute ou autre. 
Bref, on ne saura sûrement jamais. Paix à leur âme et je compatis à l'horreur qu'elles ont dû vivre ❤ 
Je passe le 90% de mon temps seule dans la forêt, mais jamais sans mon chien de garde, qui m'a plusieurs fois protégée de situations houleuses. Il peut se passer tellement de choses... je pense fort à elles❤

You are just repeating what other youtubers have got wrong and their own assumptions, a pretty good investigation was made many years ago by someone who was actually there and had access to all the photos, and talked directly to the police and other private investigators and they came to the conclusion that at one point in the row they took a wrong turn, they got lost, crossed a bridge notorious for being dangerous(locals don't even use it) and got deep into the jungle far away from their route. apparently Kris fell and injured her head, they tried to call for help with Lisanne and Kris phone but they had no signal, the next day Lisanne made several attempts with her phone but couldn't connect, there are pictures of Kris head several actually where you can see blood, apparently Lisanne was trying to see Kris injury in the night with the flash of the camera. Il a sans doute de bonnes raisons de s'alarmer tout de suite, idem pour la personne qui accueillait les deux filles.
Une chose qui me fait douter de la thèse de la chute dans la rivière, c'est, justement, le sac à dos et son contenu intacts, notamment l'électronique.
Quand à la photo effacée il est aussi possible que ce soit la survivante qui l'ait supprimée, peut-être parce que l'image dessus était traumatisante ? Le corps de son amie ?
Sinon, par rapport aux indigènes "trop sauvages" pour savoir effacer une photo, il y a une chose à considérer, ce n'est pas parce que certains vivent en forêt que c'est le cas de tous les membres des tribus, au contraire même, pas mal de jeunes en sortent et vont se "moderniser", font des études et reviennent de temps en temps faire un bisou à maman dans la jungle.
l'esprit tribu est beaucoup plus fort que ce qu'on peut trouver dans nos sociétés actuelles, le cas où un groupe "sauvage" aurait pratiqué un rituel "x" ou "y" avec les filles, puis que l'un des leurs ait voulu restituer le sac pour une raison qui lui appartient, sans pour autant incriminer sa famille, ça colle.
Cette restitution du sac (car c'en est une) peut avoir un message de type "ne les cherchez plus", afin peut-être d'apaiser l'esprit des filles (culture animiste).
Pour variante, il existe aussi de nombreux "civilisés" qui coexistent, fréquentent les natifs, que ce soit pour des raisons humanitaires ou universitaires, on peut imaginer un anthropologue, désireux à la fois de s'intégrer à la tribu, qui efface la photo pour ne pas les incriminer et dépose le sac en vue sur un lieu de passage pour signifier que les filles ont été dans la zone à un moment et alors c'est une piste.

comment.text:
There is no doubt in my mind that there is foul play involved. There are simply too many coincidences for the "Got lost" theory to be true. 
Here are the points that stood out to me and which I still remembered, even years after I read the case:
- The pristine blue backpack. Kris had the backpack when she took selfies at the top of the trail. Assuming the photos are taken on the same day they got lost (there are theories that says otherwise), it is implausible that the backpack could be in a good condition while the girls’ bodies are wrecked. 
- The bleached bones and rolled up ball of skin. Anybody who thinks nature did this to the girl’s bodies are delusional. The question is, why a third party would process the girls’ bodies? What is it that they are trying to hide?
- Timing of the “distress calls”. To me they were never distress calls, but a third party tampering with their phones. There was an article analyzing the pattern of the calls and it certainly is not random. It is entirely probable that a third party made the calls while they took breaks at work or while at lunch time.  
- Death of taxi driver that took the girls to the entrance of the trail, and one or two other individual that were related to “The Feliciano guide” (supposedly the last person to see the girls alive). Dead bodies don’t talk. Again, what truth is being hidden here?
Of course all of these could be false for all we know, since we are ultimately relying on other's testimonies. The answer to “Who took the night photos” can be anyone’s guess. There are also all sorts of tampering during the evidence collection process that we could only give the local authorities the benefit of the doubt, since Panama is a developing country. 
But the bottom line is that it is too superficial for people to be saying that the girls simply “got lost” because the jungle is dangerous (we all know) and that they made calls (who wouldn’t?).

comment.text:
Well I don't know what to make of all the photos or the discovery and contents of backpack (among other questions) but the unfortunate events, however they came about, and the ultimate demise of the girls, were the result of two things: 
1. The girls were severly lacking in their preparation for this hike.  We know they were physically unprepared based on lack of supplies, but this shortcoming also almost certainly sheds light on fact that they were also MENTALLY unprepared and were taking the entire thing too casually (not saying girls weren't mentally strong, just not mentally prepared).  The contents of the backpack were woefully inadequate for even what was intented as a casual excursion.  This is Panama.  You are entering nature's lair, where the "rules" change and the fact that they obviously did not duly RESPECT that properly was the foremost problem.

2, Secondly, even with the ill-preparedness and lack of respect for the jungle, they would've been fine just like any other clueless tourist had they simply stayed the course, gone to the peak, made the photos and then immediatley turned back.  But like so many others, it appears that they went off course, perhaps only briefly, for that breathtaking shot of a waterfall or something and couldn't find their way back.  In this sense, ironically, the very adventurous spirt that took them to Panama in the first place was ultimately their undoing.

comment.text:
The nightly photos prove nothing. The jungle is full of sounds at night, nature comes alive and sound carries for miles. It is completely dark, a darkness that we no longer know in the West. The sounds around must have terrified them. The flash with the camera must have served to scare off wild animals, just like with an open fire. After all, wild nocturnal animals avoid light. If something around them was moving in the bushes, they might also have been hoping to see what it was in a photo. The question, which potentially deadly predators are living in that area, has never been asked. Panthers? Jaguars? If one of them had a wound or was having her periods, the smell of blood can have been enough to attract one of them. Wounded animals are always the first victims, because vulnerable. Has one of them been bitten by a deadly snake? In the jungle you are lost when that happens. 
The picture of the head was just to see what the (light) wound was. Apparently one of them had hit her head. Nothing unusual on a trip through the jungle between rocks. 
When someone found the backpack, he may have decided to keep it and its contents. After all, people are very poor there. Later, when rumors started circulating about two missing girls, the finder who had the backpack at his home may have panicked and returned the backpack to where he had found it. 
And the two bras in the backpack? A trip through the humid and hot jungle can be very unpleasant. Everything sticks to the body. This is probably why the girls during their trip took off their bra and put it away neatly

comment.text:
I do think this was a tragic accident and that the pictures were purposefully done at night as a last desperate attempt for other people to notice them. They went off the trail, got lost and Kris got seriously hurt by falling or by an animal. From there, Lisanne went to get water and looked for something edible, but not too far to stay close to her friend to tend her wounds or maybe she was too scared an animal would come again and prey on her friend.
Around 5th april Kris passed away because of the lack of medical attention. Lisanne then put the remaining stuff in the backpack and tried to at least get herself out of there. She wandered around for 3 days, maybe even collapsed and on a last desperate attempt, shot those photos with flashes for someone to notice her. I don't think the deleted photo is too strange, like it was the last one of the daytime ones, she could've just accidently shot it and just deleted it asap. Then it got corrupted and irrecoverable because some of the data was overwritten by the 90 night time photos.
But I don't know about the backpack, it should've been somewhere close to Lisanne and I don't think animals would carry it so far with nothing edible being in there.
It's just puzzling how and where the bones and the backpack were found, like Lisannes should've been somewhere far off and the backpack with her and not everything spaced out and some bones together and stuff.

Regardless of which theory is correct, it just pains me to see that if the searches at 3rd april had already manage to find them, they both probably would've been saved.

comment.text: As far as the night pictures go, it could have been because they heard someone or something in the forest. Big predatory felines are known to live in Panama and they often have a preference for weak or injured prey. I can see how they might have used the flash of the camera to illuminate the area and check the pictures for the shape of a predator or the flash of nocturnal eyes. If the camera had the ability to enhance dark photographs, this would even further explain why they were using it in this way, and taking repeated photos of the same area. If I was convinced that a big cat was stalking me and my injured friend, I would want to make damn sure that noise was NOT something with teeth. Obviously, we can't see anything other than trees and ground and dark sky in the pictures, so maybe the cat was scared off, or maybe it wasn't there to begin with.

comment.text: I find the format to be a bit disrespectful but to tell the truth it's been 11 years and we still don't have an answer to what happened. I'm happy that someone finally actually went there and recorded all the locations as well as tried to talk to as many people as they could. Staying overnight in that jungle must have been pretty scary and to tell the truth I am not as certain as everyone else seems to be that someone couldn't get lost there under such circumstances. Just a few of my thoughts on the matter; I wouldn't confidently disregard the theory that the girls went missing on the other side of El Mirador simply because one of the villagers said the picture wasn't from that side of the mountain. To be frank, there really isn't any way of him being so familiar with a 14+ hour long trail that he could rule out a specific location with any certainty. I'm guessing the phones were not geo-located since no one knows exactly where the calls were made from, but as the two journalists said, the trail on the Pianista side of the mountain is pretty heavily populated with houses and private properties. Does it seem likely that they were ambushed in an area where people are literally looking at you from their bedroom windows? Also, they started their hike around 11 and were at the mountain summit at 1 pm, so it took them two hours to go uphill; the first emergency call was made at 4:39 PM, so realistically they would have been off the trail by that time (especially since they were going downhill). Second, the little branch on the rock with red material attached to it seems to have part of trail markers that were attached to the branches of a tree. I don't know if there were multiple such markers on the trail or if only one location had them, but if you look up drone footage of the other side of the mountain there is a really tall tree with these little red flags attached to the tops of it's branches near the first monkey bridge on the trail. The bridge itself is different from the one in this video, though the drone footage was shot much later;  it seems to have been updated to be more safe since then and the flow of water was minimal. Looking at the drone footage initially it seemed hard to believe that a fall from this bridge would likely be fatal, especially since the flow of the water was minimal and one could quite easily hop over to the other side from one rock to the next. If this is the same river, however, and the heavy flow is due to it being wet season then it's easy to see how dangerous it would be falling in there.  I disagree with some of the 'experts' that such a fall would certainly be fatal or necessarily resolute in a fractured pelvis or broken neck. That certainly could happen, but it really depends on how they fell in; at what angle and if they had a chance to grab onto something before falling etc. So, finally... what do I think could have happened? This is just a theory but I feel it's plausible given the evidence. The girls thought that the trail looped around the mountain and went down the other side. Maybe they didn't check the map correctly prior to setting out, maybe someone along the way had told them something along these lines/they misunderstood, maybe the trail confused them because it seemed to turn before going down again so they thought they had turned around. Either way, they walked for nearly 4 hours in that direction which is twice what it had taken them to get up. At that point, they were probably fairly certain they had gone the wrong way. This was early April in Panama, so sunset would have been around 6 pm which wouldn't have given them much time before it was dark. I think this is when they panicked and called emergency services, but instead of turning around they kept going forward. I think they didn't make it to the monkey bridge before dark and by the time they did get there they were in enough of a panic to attempt to cross it. Did they fall? Most likely. If they had made it across, chances are they would have finally made the 14 hour long journey towards more populated areas where the villagers and natives lived. I think at least one of them survived, most likely Lisanne, though perhaps both. Lisanne broke her foot from the fall and the water most likely swept both of them down the river. They probably stayed in that area, not too far from this bridge for a while. By April 8th, whoever was taking those photos was by that bridge, in the middle of the night. I'm not quite sure how the search parties wouldn't have come across them unless they didn't search that area until after they were gone. Maybe Lisanne/Kris couldn't get back up out of the river with their injuries and kept going upriver to try to find an easier way up. Maybe their injuries were so severe they couldn't really move from where the river had swept them up. Either way, it's terrifying and still doesn't fully make sense why they weren't found if those night photos on the 8th were taken so close to the monkey bridge which is on the trail.

comment.text:
The nightly photos prove nothing. The jungle is full of sounds at night, nature comes alive and sound carries for miles. It is completely dark, a darkness that we no longer know in the West. The sounds around must have terrified them. The flash with the camera must have served to scare off wild animals, just like with an open fire. After all, wild nocturnal animals avoid light. If something around them was moving in the bushes, they might also have been hoping to see what it was in a photo. The question, which potentially deadly predators are living in that area, has never been asked. Panthers? Jaguars? If one of them had a wound or was having her periods, the smell of blood can have been enough to attract one of them. Wounded animals are always the first victims, because vulnerable. Has one of them been bitten by a deadly snake? In the jungle you are lost when that happens. 

The picture of the head was just to see what the (light) wound was. Apparently one of them had hit her head. Nothing unusual on a trip through the jungle between rocks. 

When someone found the backpack, he may have decided to keep it and its contents. After all, people are very poor there. Later, when rumors started circulating about two missing girls, the finder who had the backpack at his home may have panicked and returned the backpack to where he had found it. 

And the two bras in the backpack? A trip through the humid and hot jungle can be very unpleasant. Everything sticks to the body. This is probably why the girls during their trip took off their bra and put it away neatly

comment.text:
Something I've spoken about before with you Scarlet is the time factor of reaching that Stream location and the uncertainties of following a 'Loop' trail that might lead back to Boquete. But I just recently noted you point out on your blog that the Pianista trail here is entered "...about nine kilometers north of the Spanish language school and their host family's house."

9 km equals around 5 or so miles - a very considerable distance. They had checked Googlemaps at 10.10 that morning, almost certainly checking how to access the trail and how to get there, and so makes complete sense out of the need for the Taxi. But I imagine the ride to the Resteraunt at the head of the trail would take around 15 minutes, depending on traffic, and on foot might take a good two hours if walking. Again, depending on speed on the day.

So with this in mind it does add more weight to my suspicion that by the time they reached that stream they would have been very aware of the need to be turning back - two and a half hours to get to this point, and another two and a half hours to return to the resteraunt, would mean around 4.30pm. And then they would need to find a taxi or bus to get back home....

They knew the time as they had used their phones on the summit, so when you think on all of this it beggars belief that they would have walked on and on after the stream, as they had no idea where this path led out to, and certainly no idea if it would have transport a the end of it!

I am quite convinced that the reason the photography stopped at the stream is because they knew all this, and this was as far as they would go. They were preparing to return to the summit. But something obviously went wrong at this point...

comment.text:
I'm not saying this isn't foul play, but people don't give nature enough credit. 

1 girl breaks her leg or ass on the hike, which is the one holding the camera. The other one is far away and ahead because they're scouting a route for the injured girl to take while the other hobbled along behind. 

Eventually the pain is too much or shock sets in due to the injury and weather/wet (cold and wet overnight or from river may be hypothermia), and the one holding the camera passes out, begins going semi conscious, or dies. 

The other girl brings the body or helps the possibly semi conscious one walk. Cellphone dies, so tries to unlock other friends phone. Continues to try calling emergency services. 

7 days of all night use a flashlights batteries will die. The camera is then used to navigate using flash as the second girl continues to try to escape. This kills the battery on the camera. Unclear if she left the body of the other girl or not. The back of the head photo leads me to think she was alone and was checking for an injury back there by taking the picture. Hair is relatively clean after 7 days, especially if it gets wet. 

Final girl losing consciousness and stumbles off a bridge or slips from a rock, breaking herself and drowning.  Backpack and shorts wash up immediately, shorts either came off in the flowing river due to weightloss pass 8 days or scavengers. Digital camera was found by woman. Probably poor woman who kept it for a while for herself, which is why she had it. Free back pack full of free stuff, probably just stole it, until she saw about the missing girls on TV. At which point she turned it in. Simple petty theft of unclaimed item in the woods. Digital camera will definitely work if it was turned off and battery was dead when it got wet, then dried completely before being turned on, which is likely. 

Girls are dead. The innumerable ways a body decomposes in the wild and the bugs weather etc present too many variables. We will never know why all of the bones were found the way they were. Fish and water especially can clean a bone. Scavengers and birds particularly will carry bones great distances, hence the spread. However, if sealed in a boot, tightly laced, and leather, will keep predators out. Surprisingly a lot of animals won't fight to get meat out of boots due to smell and taste of the leather. Which is what hiking boots are made of. If the laces are tight they will eat to the ridge and leave the rest, giving the impression of a clean cut. 

 We all saw the avg monthly payment of people there. That tour guide cared because he wanted the money for the tour. He may have tried to steal some money to make up for the loss of the tour when visiting the girls room, explaining the 30 min in there. But nothing was taken anyway. Then there is a reward worth more than several months of work, of course he's scouring the woods. He knows them like the back of his hand. He's fairly confident he can find them and get the money. Which he does. 

All of this is in light detail I don't want to type it all and rife with grammatical and spelling errors sorry. Again I'm not saying it's not foul play; But an accident, naivety, greed, and more innocent petty crimes could be the issue.

comment.text:
I've heard and read several versions of this story. Including a few Dutch documentaries and reports.
I believe your representation of the facts here is rather subjective. You have made assumptions, or have copied other peoples assumptions. You also implied that the Dutch research team has a different conclusion than the panama research team, and while they kept the investigation open for longer, they reached the same conclusion in the end.

You have left out a few crucial details about the case, including their attempts at making an sos message using toilet paper, including leaving a mirror to hopefully attract attention. Implying that they were trying to be found. And implying that they tried to stay put, waiting for rescue.

A few things to note: 
The search was relatively large for the country, but the area that had to be searched was a thick jungle. Also, the search was also not well structured. The area where the girls most likely were located, and stayed put in, was only touched on 2 weeks into the search. The bones were not as weirdly scattered as you make it out to be, as especially scavengers tend to spread remains over an area. The foot is an easy example of this. New forensic research that has only recently concluded has confirmed that there are no traces on the bones that imply human interaction with them. The "bleached" bone is more accurately described as most likely sunbleached. There is little more to it.
The missing photograph was deleted, but it is entirely possible that it was deleted by the girls using the camera. There is no evidence of it being done differently. Although it is entirely possible that the photo was deleted later by someone else.

It's a sad story. But everything points to girls getting lost in an immense jungle. Sadly losing their life to the wilderness.

comment.text:
When the last photo (on the day they went hiking) was taken by them, they were already lost and had walked hours on the wrong side of the mountain.  
The trail instructions were somewhat confusing and I believe they thought they were returning when they went on the other side.  That is, they didn't realise it was an out and back trail.  
They were ill prepared for the conditions, unfamiliar with the trail, inexperienced hikers, and instead of being able to self rescue they made further errors and possibly became injured.  
The location that the backpack was found makes sense if they continued in the wrong direction and reached the cable bridge.  There was more damage to the backpack than what many channels make out.  
Disarticulation of joints is also not unusual in deaths in water.  
Even the other bones, if they were there, would not be unusual considering that locals have fallen from the bridge, or been swept away in flooding, but do not have the resources for such a large scale search.  
The camera I believe was dropped, or damaged with water, hence the malfunction and missing photo.

comment.text:
I think that your video is really interesting, well researched and well argued but in the end I don't believe that they just got lost. Mainly because of the time line and the reports of many witnesses in Boquete. They took their last April 1  photo at just before 14.00 hours. They still had more than four hours daylight in which to get back down to the village and many people confirmed having seen them there at about 15.00- 15.30 hours. The trail is a 4 km there-and-back trip and would take about three to four hours. They went a little further than the Mirador but they could still easily have got back within a couple of hours. Also the path is deeply engraved and veering from it requires a considerable and deliberate effort, as said by the mother of Kris. You'd have to really want to get lost.  
Having said that,  the night photos make it difficult to believe that they were not lost at the time when these were taken but this was one whole week after the girls had set out on the Pianista Trail. It's quite bizarre.

comment.text:
The people who make the assumption that it was not a crime - because of the subsequent pictures in which Kris looks well (though not as exuberant as before),  are men. No man has ever been in a position where he trusted someone - who suddenly turns out to be very bad - blames you for having "led him on" and you're trapped - he's bigger and stronger than you, and in this case, he is the one who can lead you back to safety. So you have to play along, Stockholm Syndrome style - pretend everything is fine. He knows you know it isn't, and he's enjoying your powerlessness that you have to pretend everything is OK, when he knows that you know your life is in his terrible hands. That is why they still had access to their useless phones for almost a week, but no more happy snaps.
They were so happy to reach the summit. Took some selfies, and now you can turn back. Then a "fellow-hiker" appeared, telling them there is a waterfall not far from here, where you can cool off and fill your waterbottles before you start the return journey. So far so normal. Perfectly common occurrence between hikers meeting at the summit.
The stranger (or maybe they had met before in the village) saw that Kris was doubtful, probably had a gut instinct there is something not right about this guy. Thus he walked with Lisanne, chatting with her, so that Kris couldn't "infect" Lisanne with her doubts. Kris was several metres ahead, as the last photos showed. When she turned back her smiles were reluctant, not a broad grin like before. Kris's cross-legged stance in one of the last pictures shows that she is actually quite pissed off with Lisanne - like crossing your arms.
When they reached the waterfall, Kris will have felt reassured that this guy was legitimately only trying to be friendly and helpful and that her unease had been unfair. So they took off their clothes, put their belongings neatly in the backpack and stood under the waterfall to cool off. Soon after that came the terrible realization that their trust had been misplaced.
Men would fight back right away, but women know (a) they are out-muscled, (b) they need this guy to lead them out of the jungle. He has the advantage over them and they have to play along, pretend everything is OK, no matter what he did to them. But at some stage they realised he would not allow them to get back alive and lay criminal charges. They realised he would not let them get out of there alive. That's when they tried to escape, in the middle of the night, while they could hear him snoring. Of course they could not outrun or outsmart this guy in the jungle that he knows so well.
