comment.text:
The nightly photos prove nothing. The jungle is full of sounds at night, nature comes alive and sound carries for miles. It is completely dark, a darkness that we no longer know in the West. The sounds around must have terrified them. The flash with the camera must have served to scare off wild animals, just like with an open fire. After all, wild nocturnal animals avoid light. If something around them was moving in the bushes, they might also have been hoping to see what it was in a photo. The question, which potentially deadly predators are living in that area, has never been asked. Panthers? Jaguars? If one of them had a wound or was having her periods, the smell of blood can have been enough to attract one of them. Wounded animals are always the first victims, because vulnerable. Has one of them been bitten by a deadly snake? In the jungle you are lost when that happens. 

The picture of the head was just to see what the (light) wound was. Apparently one of them had hit her head. Nothing unusual on a trip through the jungle between rocks. 

When someone found the backpack, he may have decided to keep it and its contents. After all, people are very poor there. Later, when rumors started circulating about two missing girls, the finder who had the backpack at his home may have panicked and returned the backpack to where he had found it. 

And the two bras in the backpack? A trip through the humid and hot jungle can be very unpleasant. Everything sticks to the body. This is probably why the girls during their trip took off their bra and put it away neatly
comment.author: @lucdevincke2055

comment.text:
The red plastic bags tied to vegetation on top of a rock. Suggest a Emergency signal for search teams, possibly for a helicopter or something like that.
So that means they were alive, at least one of them, and maybe lost or in trouble, one of them wounded or something.

Also the many "blank" photo's were maybe just for the use of the flashlight. So this also indicates they were still alive for some time, but in some kind of trouble, lost and in the dark. 
Probably in this case. They just got lost and maybe one or even both of them fell of a rock or slipped into the river or whatever, wounded.
Being in the jungle inexperienced is of course dangerous and can very easy and quickly turn into a life threatening situation. Even for an experienced person with enough equipment.

The fact that personal belongings were found including money and ID cards. Makes a (normal) crime less probable. 
All the "witnesses". Well often witnesses are not very reliable. Everywhere in the world but probably specially in relatively poor countries. For a small amount of money or a big amount people will say anything. Or maybe just be accidentally wrong on something. 

All by all, yes ufo's or aliens is always a possibility, in any situation. But i don't see this in this case. The simple logical explanation of maybe an accident and getting lost, is much more probable i think.
Followed this case before. I am also from the Netherlands. But still i picked up things in this video that i didn't knew, hear or saw before. So compliments for that.

comment.text:
Rarely have I seen such sloppy work. And this guy calls himself a scientist...

1) Absence of evidence isn't evidence of absence. This argument is used a lot, but most notably when it comes to seeing the girls. Logic 101.

2) "the bones show no damage", but in the next senctence they're 'destroyed' and 'bleached', this clearly is damage. The jungle has a huge amount of different sub-environments, some of them easily could be alkaline which can speed up bleaching. Also, there are other animals than predators in the forest that will eat human tissue...

3) You can't say anything about the photo's since you don't have the originals. We have to take them at face value until they conflict with other HARD evidence. Not flimsy witness statements (the weakest evidence there is)

4) The Pianista Puzzle has shown  to the verge of certainty that the girls made the picture. They used a 3d reconstruction. Look it up. These 2 goofballs are just speculation without ANY evidence.

5) "I don't build my own idea", yes, yes you clearly do. You think things are not likely, therefore you don't believe them.

6) After 8 days in the jungle you can't say anything about the mental state of the girls. If you don't think the photo's are logical, that's exactly what you expect. 

7) on picture 509. The picture was called 'deleted' by the NFI because  there was a picture 508 and 510 and there was root data on 509. It seemed deleted. However, it could very well be that the picture was never made but this was a malfunction. It could very well be moment of the accident: falling and water disconnecting the battery. This would also explain why the camera was off for 8 days;  it got wet and they didn't want to turn it on.

8) phone calls. Again, their argument is: " I can't imagine". This is not evidence. You don't know the mental state nor were they were. 
Also: it's not about what experts think.... It' s about what the girls thought at that moment. 

9) "what you expect". My god.... really? 

10) thumbs up? Really? Is this your 'evidence'? You are claiming the involvement of someone based on one of the most universal hand gestures in the world. 
You don't want to cast suspicion yet that exactly what you do.

11) You can't IMAGINE lost or accident can't be without foul play aka tunnel vision.

Edit: removed some spelling errors. Typing on a phone is harder than one might expect :)

comment.text:
Wait, that photo at 4:30, that's gotta be pointing upward to the sky, right? See the shape the leave of the right side shrubs take. That with what seems to be grass on the nearest edge that go out from the camera's view seems to heavily suggest this. The dark spot on the right side of the rock face is also too spread out to suggest that it's a puddle and is more likely a trickle of water which may have been clean enough to drink for natives who could worry less about local disease from the soil. There's also a tiny sapling of sorts growing on the rock face on the left about halfway up the frame with 6 distinguishable leaves growing at a 45 degree angle and the side of the leaf we can see is notably dull meaning that its growing out and facing away from the camera's view. That sort of suggests that the vegetation is so dense around this potential cliff side that the sapling prefers growing its leaves to face upward as if it isn't getting quite enough sun from the area across from the cliff face. It would likely face its leaves in the direction of its current growth if it received unimpeded sunlight from over there. It's such a silty cliff face. I wonder if it receives a lot of rain and the runoff carries a lot of soil with it which gets caught on the side.

I wonder, in an early photo, there's stones and exposed roots along what seems to be a stream, maybe that trickle off the cliff face was the start of that river. It's a thing in survival tips that if you're totally lost and you've found a stream, its worth a shot to follow the stream as towns are usually founded on the sides of water sources. The thing is that you're supposed to follow them downstream, not up, and they may have misremembered and went up or they thought it didn't matter which way.

comment.text:
The pressures on this man and his partner perhaps get overlooked, caught in the strange unreality of a childs disappearance thousands of miles away and with little communication from that country's authorities they stand there waiting, bystanders in a very personal horror story.... I do wonder whether it still has that touch of unreality about it for them, with so many key questions left unaddressed and unanswered can there be any real closure?
--------------------------------

"..Behind a Tree Trunk, almost Under it,"

You read that description, and see the photograph of the finders stood over it, and ask the obvious question - how does this boot(and its foot) get from a supposed journey down the river to being in this strange and unlikely position? Behind and almost under a tree trunk on the riverside somewhere, you might argue some animal carried it there, but is it coincidence that the tree trunk is an easily identifiable feature and would work to protect and hide the boot until a search party coming down the river thinks to walk over to this unremarkable tree trunk (or log) and inspect it.
Perhaps I can read too much into its lucky find here, but then when Hans Kremer's independently points out the strangeness of his daughters fastened shorts found while her hip-bone is found kilometres downstream you do have corroboration of your queries here. Kremers himself is clearly an astute man, very perceptive and was able to spot some of the odd elements to the findings early on.

But as i just happened to read a new entry on your blogs first page you print out an autopsy report on the few found remains which reveals the pathologists results of their inspection. 
And the report from them that Lisanne's few remains (leg bone) showed the signs of  "Root" bleaching from almost certainly being buried in a shallow grave is stunning if true, and I have no  reason to think it isn't if this report is genuine. But why is it that no one picked up on this detail in the report...? It turns the story upside down, was it suppressed perhaps, or is the case that no one picked up on this up until now? And is this result from the bone found in June, or the ones found in late August ...?

comment.text: Here's a little more food for thought: There is now revealed a photo (seems quite blurry) allegedly taken on 1 April 2014, allegedly showing the two young women swimming with two local youths in waters in the Caldera, Chiriqui which is about 40-60 minutes drive from the El Pianista trail. comment.text:
This was a great video.  I hope one day you post part 2.

In the meantime here is my theory:
The girls set off on the trail.  Somewhere along they encounter someone odd or at least two people because they were tall girls, so it had to be at least 2 or more people there..Lisanne herself was 1.84m tall and central americans are known to be very small.  Anyway the girls are uneasy.  Something happens and they begin to run...they call 112, 911..no luck.  They are captured, taken away and raped/tortured.  The police are on a frantic hunt for the girls which frightens the capturers.  So they send the girls back out half alive days later to die in the jungle.  One girl then attempts at drawing attention by taking pictures (this still confuses me as to why they wouldnt photograph themselves) but judging by the photo of Kris I believe she is dead at this point.  Now either Lisanne is trying to get into Kris' phone at this point or the capturers were trying to see what evidence was on there.  One or the other.

The capturers then realize the girls have too much evidence on them perhaps sperm finger prints etc.  So they take them back and dispose of the bodies perhaps profiting off their organs.  

They then plant bones here and there in the jungle to draw attention toward the lost in jungle theory.  They plant the backpack there as well so that they do not hold on to any evidence.

comment.text:
They we're lost, died in a cave, near the river..
The bodies had some time to start decomposition, till a flashflood dragged their remains into the river..
This weakened the joints in their bodies, causing their bones to easily separate. 
Obviously, a bone without shoes around it will decompose much faster than one in a shoe..
It's much harder for insects to help decomposition inside a shoe..
Which explains why the pelvis bone seems more "bleached" (had more sunlight and contact with soil, which contains phosphor..)
Unlike the meat in the shoe, which was protected from it and found UNDERNEATH A TREE IN SHADE!!!
It's also possible Kris died a few days before Lisanne, which would explain why the wrong PIN was used..
Sure, it's reasonable to expect Lisanne to know it, but don't forget she might have been panicked, hungry, and disoriented.. 
The skin is also easy to explain, a layer of skin, can easily dry in the sun causing it to become like leather... or jerky.. 
Obviously, from that moment it's gonna take a looooong time for it to decompose.

A few pieces of information about this case online are also wrong..
If you trace the sources, you'll see that the original sources of some claims, never even made the claim.. 
Like the backpack being in pristine condition, her father said in an interview the bag had drag marks, leaves and dirt..
Which would indicate them falling with the bag, or the bag being in the river..
It also wasn't dry.. nor found under a tree, but just at the riverbank.

The claims they called 77times in later days was claimed to be from RTL late night 1-10-2014..
But if you actually watch it, they don't say that all.. (yes i speak Dutch, and the episode is actually hard to find as well.)

And look what happens if you stich the night pictures together, then let photoshop fill in the missing parts: Hu8FOr8pVJU
Looks a lot like a cave doesn't it?

comment.text:
Those narratives that say that girls could be very bad, from a physical and psychological point of view, to make conscious use of both the camera and the phones, practically fell apart with this schematic drawing at the beginning of your video. Someone made most of the calls within the same hour span, regardless of whether it was the girls or a third party making the calls, the fact is: There was a lot of situational awareness, discipline and intentionality in cell phone use, even on the 11th! About three days after the night shots.

Note: Well observed! If Dutch women turned off their cell phones after using them, how could they make calls within the same hourly range the next day? Because there is no way to look at the time on the cell phone, because it is turned off. In one of these opportunities, the person got the same minute right and in three other opportunities he got the time wrong by only two or three minutes. There are only two alternatives left: 1- Did K&L use the camera's time as a reference? 2- Was a third party based on your own cell phone or a wristwatch?

Note: It makes no sense for them to use the sun as a reference, knowing that in those mountains the clouds can block the sunlight for a long time. It would be too much of a coincidence if the sun was not obstructed by clouds within exactly the same hour interval, for five days in a row and ten times in those eleven observed days. Just look at the photos taken at the top of the viewpoint, in a matter of minutes in the same hour interval, the sky went from sunny to cloudy (believing that there was no major tampering with the time of the photos).


Essas narrativas que dizem que as garotas podiam está muito mal, do ponto de vista físico e psicológico, para fazerem um uso consciente tanto da câmera como dos telefones, praticamente caiu por terra com esse desenho esquemático do início do seu vídeo. Alguém fez a maioria das ligações dentro do mesmo intervalo de hora, independente de ter sido as garotas ou um terceiro fazendo as ligações, o fato é: Havia muita consciência situacional, disciplina e intencionalidade no uso dos celulares, até mesmo no dia 11! Cerca de três dias após as fotos noturnas.

Obs: Bem observado! Se as holandesas desligavam os celulares após o uso, como conseguiam fazer as ligações dentro do mesmo intervalo de hora no dia seguinte? Pois não têm como olhar o horário no celular, pois ele está desligado. Em uma dessas oportunidades, a pessoa acertou até o mesmo minuto e em outras três oportunidades errou o horário apenas por dois ou três minutos. Só resta duas alternativas: 1- K&L utilizaram o horário da câmera como referencial? 2- Um terceiro se baseou em seu próprio celular ou em um relógio de pulso?

Obs: Não faz sentido elas utilizarem o sol como referencial, sabendo que naquelas montanhas as nuvens podem bloquear a luz do sol por um bom tempo. Seria muita coincidência que o sol não sofresse obstrução das nuvens exatamente dentro do mesmo intervalo de hora, por cinco dias seguidos e por dez vezes nesses onze dias observados. Basta ver as fotos tiradas no topo do mirador, em questão de minutos no mesmo intervalo de hora, o céu foi de ensolarado para nublado(acreditando que não houve uma grande adulteração do horário das fotos).

comment.text:
Personally I think the girls’ intent was to go on a mild hike and to make some memories. That was why they chose their attire (underwire bras, denim shorts etc.) the type of clothing you might want to take photos in. They were totally clueless about the trail and probably thought it was a loop that would bring them back to their starting point. That coupled with the fact that there were houses along the way etc probably made them feel overconfident. I could see them telling themselves “just a little further and the trail will bring us back around”. Eventually they realized this was not the case, tried to contact emergency services and more than likely turned around. I agree with Josh that they were smart about the way they chose to call and conserve battery. It also shows that they were in a calm state of mind and most likely not injured. I think they probably held out hope for a long time and only started feeling truly desperate during the night photos. I agree with Kendall that it was definitely an attempt to signal. 
The most confusing aspect is how were they not found with all the efforts and the area??? And I think that is why people come up with hairbrained theories. However if you’ve looked into the Missing 411 phenomena its not uncommon for searchers to not find any clues.

comment.text:
Recently here in the US an 18 year old girl ran out of gas and decided to go into the woods to find a nearby bridge (something like that).  She quickly got lost and was found 8 days later.  They stated she was delirious and completely out of her mind, so to speak.  She was so confused at the hospital that she thought she had been gone for only three days, when it was 8 (she also didn't make any type of goodbye video either).  Although rugged terrain, she was in a much more forgiving environment than a jungle.  In the West, when someone goes missing, there is an Army of available services.  Satellites, Blackhawk helicopters, those 100k dollar Norwegian tracking dogs, etc.  In a small, poor nation like Panama with its tiny GDP, you have very little other than the kindness and duty of the locals.  She was also found only 1 mile away from where her car was parked.  

This story in a word, sucks.  There are questions that will never be answered and there will always be doubt.  But nearly all experts agree, regardless of the strange circumstances, that the most probable reality is the crappiest one.  They simply died from a combined factor of exposure, hunger, mental breakdown, and possibly injury.  I myself am very surprised they will able to live so long there.  Their fitness and spirit kept them alive for at least 8 days and at least one survived for about 11.  The nighttime cold must have been unbearable.  The temperatures got as low as the 50s.  If you don't think thats cold then set your house temperature to 53 degrees, take a shower and walk around your home, you will be freezing.  Heartbreaking they didn't have so much as a poncho to bundle up in.  I've seen many people play private Detective and I guess they are well meaning.  Some people like to think they are smarter than everyone else and know better.  However, saying things like a killer uploaded the photos and then put them back in original form and photoshopped one of the girls breasts to look bigger is downright foolish and over imaginative.  The unknown must eat their families alive like Piranha and we can only offer them our sympathy.  But the jungle claimed two more victims.  If I was Panama I would not even allow tourists to hike without a guide.

comment.text:
It is pretty unanimous that they did not get lost on the short, easy hike. There are no cliffs, no way in which to get injured. In fact, one could not get lost regardless of how hard you might try. A whole team, including parents, retraced the trail, and it just isn't possible. There is literally nowhere to go except the trail itself. Not to mention, numerous people reported seeing them return. Even their photos show them going up, and then returning, as they "summit" twice. 

Rumor has it that upon returning from the hike, they were invited to go swimming with an unsavory character named Henry. Henry, the swimmer, has some odd photos on his facebook page, for example, one of two girls lying unresponsive, in identical positions, with Henry standing over the girl in the forefront, holding a large stick over her head. The family they were staying with is also rumored to be heavily involved with the gang activity in the region, from trafficking to organ harvesting. As was their guide. As was everybody they came in contact with after they got to Panama. 

You have to ask yourself, why were they misled by the school in the first place, and told that there were positions for them at the school, when there weren't?  They didn't stand a chance.

comment.text:
Firstly it's not an easy trail. To people who have hiked it before, sure, but there are plenty of areas where one could take a wrong turn and yes there are dangerous areas on it where one could fall and get seriously injured. So yeah it is quite dangerous to walk it for the first time without a map & compass, without a guide and without GPS, with half charged phones. However it likely would have been fine had they simply walked back once they reached the top. 

The disastrous decision they made was to carry on down an unknown path. Likely they were on a high and wanted to carry on exploring but that's a very dangerous thing to do considering how ill prepared they were. They clearly got lost and most likely one of them at least got injured and they carried on hiking deeper and deeper into the jungle, tragically sealing their fate. The photos on their camera prove at least one of them was alive and that the other girl was at least there with her, several days after their disappearance so the talk of foul play is nonsense. As for why they'd take the pics, it's either for light, or because they thought they heard someone nearby and wanted to get their attention or because they're utterly deranged at this point and their actions make little sense. 

People want to turn this tragedy into some spooky conspiracy murder when actually, all the evidence points to two girls getting lost and drying in the jungle. Let it rest.

comment.text:
There is no need to say; I am no expert whatsoever in any field of forensics criminology, but having followed for many years endless cases of strange (solved and unsolved) disappearances and murders, I have come to the conclusion - again following all the details of this case- That the two girls have been Killed for any given predatory reasons, And here's why;

The first thing that comes to mind is this; Why is it that NO one have take into account and take into consideration; that the many photos that were taken 'randomly' and showed only dark pictures or insignificant shots of the landscape, Were taken by someone; who after committing the crime, have then picked up the camera and have 'accidentally' while "fiddling" with it or inspecting it, have Pressed the button multiple times which resulted in those random shots !? The fact is; both girls were Savvy enough in photography not to Waste time with such Random insignificant Shorts !
The other most important question is that; both girls were familiar and keen enough to journal and record Their adventure (whether good or bad) and they were in the habit of writing and keeping a journal. So the question is; how come if they were in trouble and they were trying to reach out, how come they didn't record with their own voices their dire situation and leave a voice record of the trouble Or difficulty they got into !? 
They had enough battery power and it would've been the first thing anybody would do in such situation, which is; to write or voice record their predicament, just in case if somebody would find their phones and the camera Later ? I think this last great question should've been the center of the investigation. 
There is no doubt in my mind that those girls were killed. RIP.😢

Il est évident qu’elles ont fait une mauvaise rencontre. Contrairement à Lionel, je ne crois pas à l’épisode « dragouille » qui aurait mal tourné (qui me parait romancé et très occidental). Il s’agirait de malfaiteurs qui auraient voulu les dépouiller, les séquestrer, pourquoi pas pour une rançon. L’une des filles aurait tenté de s’échapper des jours plus tard et se serait éclairée avec le flash de l’appareil photo d’où le nombre de clichés. En actionnant frénétiquement l’appareil il est également possible qu’il s’enraye. Donc impossible de récupérer l’image. Je ne crois pas au technicien (dans la jungle panaméenne?) qui vient supprimer une photo mais ne détruit pas entièrement l’appareil. 
Elles ont dû vivre l’horreur, qu’elles trouvent le repos éternel.

comment.text: I think the two Dutch girls, instead of turning back once they reached the summit, decided to go off trail as Dr Grande mentioned, to find that waterfall. Then after hiking deeper into the jungle, couldn't find their way back. They got lost. Jungles are full of thick foliage where it's easy to get lost in. They only had a limited amount of water, quickly ran out, along with any food they may have had. They eventually succumbed to the elements after separating. The explanation for the scattered remains was due to wild animals, either that or due to natural elements, such as the weather. There are six species of wild cats, such as the jaguar and puma that live in the jungles of Panama.The explanation for how the remains decomposed can be explained by forensic science. The strange photos, they were taking weren't photos but them using the flash to see their surroundings at night. The one girl losing access to get into the phone was due to forgetting the code, because of dehydration and lack of food. These girls were very young, and were inexperienced when it came to making sound decisions when hiking out in a jungle, in an area they weren't familiar with. They were full of hubris to go hiking off trail. Tragic nonetheless that they ended up losing their lives.
comment.author: @kevinmalone3210

comment.text:
In my opinion, there is no big mystery to be solved in this case.  
I think the two people involved were not questioned properly, the taxi driver and the tour guide were the only ones who knew they were going there.
Taxi driver found dead a year after the incident, he probably knew too much
I also came across bad comments on some sites about the tour guide f, saying that he was obsessed with European women and that he went too far and touched them when they were alone.
A few years after the incident, another German tourist was attempted to be raped in the same area, and she was only able to escape with a broken bottle from people who were searching for her in the forest, supposedly for help.
According to another theory, the girls were not alone in the taxi and someone else noticed where they were going.
This theory explains why the taxi driver killed
The girls looked very happy in the photos when they started the tour, so there were 2 of them in the beginning
At a certain point they were caught by another person and driven into the forest like prey.
It probably took a while for them to be caught, but eventually they were caught and were left alone with a terrible fate.
Photos taken at night were definitely intended to deceive the authorities and everyone else.

comment.text: The two men who died from suspicious deaths has me rethinking everything I thought about this case… Somebody clearly knew something it's weird that the guy in the photo drowned… He's from Panama I'm sure he grew up around those beaches and can swim just fine
comment.author: @Ryl3925

comment.text: Unfortunately, too many clues point to foul pay. IF they had become lost, they would have tried to contact for help and/or the search would have found their trail or clues during the search. IF an accident had happened, their bodies or one of them would have been found whole. A photo is deleted exactly after they became missing, and all photos after that are weird snapshots that make little sense. Someone seems to have tried to access the phone by attempting to guess the password, which the girls themselves wouldn't have done unless in a fugue state but again, if they were indeed in some dazed condition, they would have attempted to get help or get out of the trail, which apparently never happened. Getting lost from the trail also seems very unlikely for that particular area. Additionally, IF foul play was the case, the perpetrator(s) would most likely choose the river as preferred setup to make it look like an accident, and that would seem to be the case. Then the weird involvement of that gang and the suspicious deaths surrounding it only strengthens the foul play scenario. THen also to consider, countries like Panama are well-known for kidnappings and murders of tourists, usually women and children. But as per usual, law enforcement in such countries is below par, dare I call it amateuristic and in some cases even involved. Not claiming such is the case here but indeed, the case leaves a lot to be desired. My heart goes out every day to ALL men, women and children that meet their end on this sickened Earth. And many thousands upon thousands do perish each and every day which I try to be fully aware of every second of every day. <3
comment.author: @yhsh1874

comment.text: Of all the narratives about the fact, this is the most vague and superficial of all. In addition to adding an  implausible   hypothesis of an alleged kidnapping by a local gang in the middle of the forest and still returning with the two on the same frequented trail, taking them to a nightclub!  What is missing to at least begin to evaluate something is a topographical survey showing the exact location of the photos where the two appear last. The location of all houses in the vicinity of the point in this last photo and who are its inhabitants. The exact location of the two rope bridges. The volume of water in the river in those days. The exact location where the backpack and bones were found. It is known that animals can scatter bones. I don't know if an examination was made of the heel bone that was inside the boot to find out how it was separated from the rest of the leg. And there are still many other details and testimonials missing that I don't have space to expose here.
comment.author: @mxblyxky

comment.text: Personally, I think it’s pretty clear they got killed. These girl kept a diary, took many photos and videos and you’re telling me they didn’t take a single photo or recorded a video after they got lost? Like others suggested, I find it really strange that they didn’t record a short video (or wrote at least in the iPhone’s notebook) explaining what happened to them. Especially when they were close to the end and lost all hope, you’d expect them to leave some sort of explanation for their family so they can find peace. I think this is what any of us would do in a similar situation. Also, how the backpack randomly turned up in good condition after 2 months? I also find it very strange that more remains were not found. Even if wild animals fed on them, they don’t eat the bones so you would expect more of them to show up. Where is the skull, rib cage or the femur? And on top of that you’re telling me that the 2 gang members died shortly after they disappeared and others have gone missing too? The Panamanian police is either extremely bad at their job or they learnt exactly what happened but decided to cover it up. If they ruled it as a murder, it would have driven away all the tourist from Panama for the foreseeable future which would have really hurt the country. So they were probably “instructed” to rule it as an accident. It’s really sad because these two poor girls will never get justice for what happened to them and who knows how many other victims might have been before and after them.😞

comment.text: I honestly think that someone was following them and messing with them, and I feel like they were snapping photos in the dark to try and catch something in the photos. comment.text: Killed by a jaguar. There are regional governmental conservation efforts to protect the jaguar. Any official autopsy would tend to block jaguar predation as a cause. One of the last photos taken has been forensically modified to help brighten the picture. You can see a large cat. Leaving this picture on the phone was a fortunate mistake on the part of the first agency to view the photos. Any clear pictures of a jaguar would have been erased, before it was released to the public. The girl was smart to create as much of a reflective surface as possible to temporarily flash-blind the jaguar. From the summit point, one of the young women saw how easy it would be to travel along the river all the way to the north coast, rather than turn around. The ginger girl, in one of the later pictures, was really uncomfortable with the idea of following the riverbank. A jaguar's main hunting area is the riverbank. Jaguars have one of the highest bite strengths of any animal. When a cat chews bone, it grinds it into a paste. The only bones left with mountain lion attacks tend to be the flesh they couldn’t get out of the footwear.
comment.author: @erikthedrink

comment.text:
There is significantly more odd circumstances in this case.  Their taxi driver, and the two young men they hung out with there, all died under very suspicious circumstances not long after.  There are several reports of local tribes snatching people and killing them in their jungle temples.  Not to mention the local drug cartels - why do you think they are Mexican cartels?  Every single person from the story has some shady story including the tour guide who insisted he search their room the second they weren't there to meet him (why?), and the woman coordinating their program with the local children, who told them they couldn't start as planned/scheduled, and suggested they go on the hike instead. 

 I find it incredibly difficult to believe their was no human interference involved, and lean towards them being kidnapped, killed, bones bleached, with the remains and carefully preserved belongings being planted on the trail so the Dutch would stop looking and go home.  Perhaps the girl with normal remains had died from an injury, and the other was picked up by a local tribe/cartel to be "processed".  A local tribe makes  more sense considering the phones were accessed for days, and they wouldn't have any idea what the devices were.  An additional confusion, is that the camera had one photo deleted from the sequence via a computer,, but that could be explained by the local police deleting an incriminating photo prior to letting the Dutch investigate.  They were known to protect their local tourism industry at all costs.

comment.text: I think the only scenario that makes sense is the girls were intercepted somewhere on the trail and they ran away from danger deeper in the jungle. Then both fell off a cliff and were both badly injured. Kris sustained a head injury and Lisanne broke her leg. The reason why there are long gaps between emergency calls is because they were in the same spot and were immobile. The night time photos are all takes in the same spot near the cliff face. There was and SOS sign made out a torn up paper map, there was a branch with red plastic bags used as a signal. They were using the camera flash as a signal out of desperation because at that moment Kris was dying. Later Lisanne passed away from starvation and dehydration. Then later locals who knew what happened found their bodies, and then used fertiliser to speed up the decomposition and they took the back pack which was still in good condition being sheltered by the cliff face. Then once the remains were decomposed and bones separated the locals scattered their remains in the river. There was 1 photo 509 which was deleted which might have shown who was chasing them. Then two months later the back was placed back in the jungle in a different location to the cliff face and that’s why the backpack was in such good condition.

comment.text:
Such a waste of life! Very sad ending to two lovely girls that had their whole life ahead of them.

Since watching this have been reading up and watching more about this case.

I was caught between them being "lost" then "abducted" based on everything presented, but two things stood out for me me: 1) The photo of the branches with red or orange pieces of plastic tied to them and what looks like metal coloured bubble gum wrappers on the rock, and 2) The backpack and two bras.

I don't think they were abducted at all.

The wrappers I reckon were meant to reflect the sun and all of it was to gain the attention perhaps of a plane, helicopter or someone with binoculars. The mirror too.

As for the backpack being miles away and in perfect condition means it was found weeks before and likely near the bodies - perhaps the bras were removed to be kept. No report made.

It seems there were tribe(s) living in the jungle so this could have been a tribal member that did it - like from the Ngabe Bugle. I was going to say I'm not too sure about cannibalism until I read that last year (2020) there was an incident of it with a religious sect, however, I think that is not their case in hindsight.

I think someone came across their bodies and took the bag and bras only didn't report it. And as they made local and worldwide headlines the bag was placed somewhere to be found only nowhere were they actually died and maybe the bodies were brought closer so as to also be discovered.

comment.text:
These girls never got lost.  There are vids of her parents traveling this trail and there's absolutely no way to get lost, there's only one way to go and you would have to try VERY hard to leave the trail.  There are also 6 local witnesses who saw the girls RETURN from the hike, and some saw them get into a vehicle.  
They hiked up, went a bit past the summit, got to that stream where the pics were taken, turned around, back to the top, then came back down.  Then they were picked up by someone nefarious.  They were offered a ride to go swimming with some dudes, they dropped them by their room where they changed to swimsuits (reason why bras are strangely found in backpack later)  They stopped by a pharmacy on the way to go swimming, but this footage was magically Epstein'd never to be seen again because it would ruin the "got lost" story.  Feliciano even went to their room and spent 30 minutes in there, which is when he grabbed the stuff they dropped off after their hike so it wouldn't be found and ruin the "got lost" theory as well.  Then he waited 5 hours to report them missing....  His son and son's friends were the ones that picked the girls up, eventually taking them swimming.  The girls took a pic at the hot springs and that was the deleted photo.  The guys then did their thing and the girls ended up dead....  A photo was later found on one of the boys phones after he mysteriously drowned, and it shows the two girls with the boys at the hot springs. 
Some of the remains and the shorts were found near Feliciano's property.  
  Why would they try only twice (12 min apart) to make an emergency call and then not try again at all until the next morning?. 
The backpack, shorts, and bones were all planted later.  The camera pics were re-arranged by the Panamanian authorities to make it look like they got lost, they deleted one picture completely because they couldn't explain it away.   Several shady people from the area died in mysterious ways before the case was closed.  Locally it's no secret that the "got lost" story is total BS.  The locals all know they were killed.  
Panama has a yearly tourism income of over 7 billion, they didn't want a double murder of two young women scaring tourists away.
Just search for vids of Kris's parents walking the trail.  There's absolutely NO WAY two smart girls could get lost.  It's a single, clear trail all the way up and over.  There's no way to get lost, even her parents say that over and over again.  Lining the times up with the first emergency calls, there's no slopes or cliffs or anything they could have fallen off.

My theory is that the girls became lost and injured, and eventually separated. The photo of the girl's hair : perhaps Kris fell from a height and sustained a bad head injury, possibly unconscious. It was pitch black at night, so Lisanne was trying to check the severity of the wound using the digital camera.
Eventually both of the girls would die from their injuries/exposure.
I think, after this point, some locals may have found a body/bodies and their possessions and went through a process of trying to steal the electronics and then dispose of the bodies. comment.author: @torgo_

comment.text: I think they got lost, got scared, got thirsty, low on electrolytes (a serious problem when sweating in the jungle), hungry & eventually one fell & was seriously injured (in the river drainage) - I think the uninjured girl used the camera flash to look for the other girl who fallen, as well as in a desperate attempt to signal at night. I think in their desperation, they probably had moved further than expected, so the search didn't find them. I think the injured girl either died or was in serious shape and the other moved downriver to try and get help, but she eventually died from exposure. Their bodies were probably somewhat eaten by animals and what was left was swept downriver by flash flooding (a common occurrence on that river) - people underestimate how powerful water hydrolics can be - pictures of that riverbed show a vast jumble of rocks, water carrying the bodies over those rocks could break them up. The clothing found isn't surprising - on the Colorado River, bodies of people thrown out into Lava Falls rapid are usually stripped of clothing and life jacket - so I'd actually expect that with the state of the remains. The bleached piece of pelvis is odd - but the sun can bleach bone, possibly it was stripped of flesh by the river & then exposed to harsh tropical sun. The pack is harder to explain - although I'd expect a killer to bury it in the jungle - even a few feet off the trail & it would never be found. And why would $83 be left? To a local that would be a tidy sum & taking it wouldn't implicate the killer any more than the other facts. The missing pic is weird - although if the girl was frantically using the flash at night, who knows what could happen- I thought I'd read there is a double number in the sequence, so maybe that's the issue and there isn't a missing photo in reality. The problem with reality is it isn't tidy - in so many mysteries, there's some elements that just make no sense & we have to weigh in with the preponderance of evidence. From the photos, they clearly continued beyond the summit. They were unprepared and by 4:40pm scared & tried 911 - by 7pm it was dark. A single bottle of water, no electrolytes to replace those lost to sweat and no or little food is a serious medical situation very quickly. They may have pushed forward in a desperate search for water. Eventually one fell & the tragedy unfolded.

comment.text: I keep thinking about the shoe with Lisanne’s fractured severed foot inside. Also the fact that only part of Chris‘s pelvis was found. In thinking about what could sever a foot I keep thinking about the large American crocodile. Five minutes of research tells me they can bring to bear 1 ton per square inch in bite power. They feed at night which could explain the strange flash photos if Lizanne was trying to scare one off. I also appreciate what an earlier commentor said about the possibility of tropical ants cleaning Chris’ pelvis piece off, that makes sense to me. Try this theory on for size: the women get lost quickly after leaving the main trail and try several times to reach the authorities for rescue. Chris could have removed her clothes deliberately to do something in the water, whether to reach a cleaner area to refill a water bottle, or? American crocodiles would just be making a nest and laying eggs at the end of March beginning of April in Panama. The females are said to protect the nest aggressively, though they are generally not said to be an aggressive species. What I read says that females do not meet until at least 9 1/2 feet long, that they can run 10 miles an hour on land and swim 20 miles an hour. The nest is said to be approximately 5 foot deep and 10 foot wide, filled with rotting debris, and both parents guard it hiding in holes in the bank. Lisanne could have gone to rescue Chris and both women ended up on the far side of the river away from Chris’ clothes. Let’s say Chris became unconscious or mentally incapacitated before Lisanne did, whether from lack of food or water or injury your guess is as good as mine. That would explain the later attempts to get into Chris‘ phone without the pin. The strange nighttime photographs with the flash during three hours between 1AM and 4AM on 4/8 would be an attempt to frighten nighttime predators away. I would guess that both women were eaten by either the original American crocodile(s) or their bodies were dismembered by smaller Caimen crocodiles.

comment.text: they got lost.  they probably saw a villiage in the distance and used that camera as a signaling device.  most of the strange photographs are on the exact same ledge under some heavy rain or maybe even a waterfall.  there's one photographs of kris' head, but the "obvious damage" people point out is not obvious.  if you have a bad cut on your head it will soak right through your hair.  the image is perfectly still, so that's a little awkward as everything else looks to be taken frantically.  here's my theory and it's only that, a theory, thatpicture was taken to see if there were any bugs in her hair.  they were out the wilderness and god knows what kinds of creepy crawlies are out there.  anyway, 2-3 days without water [that you can actually drink, and you'll die.  2-3 weeks.  2 mins without oxygen and you can start to lose consciousness, and 20 mins in freezing water will kill you as well.  the point is that life is actually fairly fragile.  we maintain a constant state of comfort and health due to the technology we use.  these girls got lost and they were in deep jungle in a foreign place.  they lasted around a week or maybe less.

comment.text:
So many unanswerable questions.

Could the girls have lost their bag, containing camera and phones on the April 1st; either through accident or foul play?

What evidence is there that they are alive after that point?

I think there is the phone - the pin was entered correctly without any incorrect guesses made.  However, if someone else knew the pin this becomes meaningless.  There is the photo of the back of a blonde woman’s hair... we presume this is Kris, but could it plausibly be someone else’s?

Could someone have happened upon the bag and attempted to phone it in as stolen (hence the emergency call)?

The biggest question for me at the moment is - why weren’t any more photographs of any substance taken after 1st April, especially if they had an accident or were lost.  Would this not be the first thing you would do?

comment.text:
We may not be able to hear what happened from their own mouths, but there is more than enough evidence to deduce exactly what befell these young women.

They had a week to burn and we're excited to see the country they were visiting. They took a hike with the hosts dog. They decided to go off track, likely to get those cliffside photos like they had been taking. One or both of them slipped and fell. It takes a tremendous force to snap a pelvis in half. Kris has a broken pelvis. The other young girl stayed with her friend. The photos snapped in the dark were likely out of paranoia to frighten away an animal, as they were in pitch black and afraid. They didn't snap the pictures to see because it would've just blinded them with brightness. After around day 5, Kris died from her injuries. The other girl tried relentlessly to unlock the phone but couldn't figure out the code. She was likely very dehydrated and unable to seek help on foot, assuming she wasn't also injured. They both eventually succumb. I can't imagine what it must've been like to be the family and know that if someone just would've found them sooner, they may have survived.

comment.text:
Great theory, however there is one thing that doesn't add up to me. If F is really behind all this, how do you explain the fact that, while the girls were already missing, he was not physically present in the jungle? The day after the girls went missing, he was going around the city asking for information on where the girls were, he even went to the place where they were staying. I mean, if F chased the girls for about ten days, basically from the moment they started hiking until they stopped both turning on their phone and taking photos, which is presumably the moment in which they were already dead, F would have to follow them all the days the girls wandered in the jungle, even at night when there is zero visibility, to avoid losing sight of them. It seems really unlikely to me that F, or anyone else, was in the jungle for 10 days with the girls without ever losing sight of them for a second. It's very easy to lose sight of something or someone inside a jungle, where it is full of dense vegetation, and especially where visibility is zero at night. It also seems very unlikely to me that F started following the girls on April 1, when they started hiking, then over the course of 10 days he went to other places, and at the end of those 10 days he returned to the jungle where he is incredibly managed to find the girls and kill them. There are 2 options for me: 

A) even though F may have something to do with all of this, it wasn't him who chased and killed the girls but someone else who followed them for all the 10 days they were in the jungle, without ever losing sight of them for a second. This theory it's seems very unlikely to me for numerous reasons, including the ones i listed above.

 B) F (or whoever committed the crime) killed the girls on April 1st and then staged everything else. The photos, the 911 calls, the girls' phones turning on. All things he did to make it seem like the girls were still alive, when in reality they were already dead.

Regardless of what really happened in that jungle, and despite the fact that i don't scare easily and have read about hundreds of cases of unsolved mysteries, every time i think about this case i get chills all over my body.

comment.text:
I don’t think they were particularly lost or disposed of, just stuck being injured until they perished.

The backpack being found dry is much disputed, and apparently according to police and forensics is untrue, as the phones were reported to be specially dried. The missing photo (or potentially video) was likely a temporary camera error (probably after getting wet) which would explain them not even trying the camera again until the 8th in desperation.

The night photos were taken in a gully with some water that the girls found themselves in, with Kris likely completely incapacitated in that place by then, and Lisanne taking them in a daze trying to signal upwards to rescuers, while also accidentally snapping a pic of her friend’s hair next to her, as well as the outline of a side of her own face, all until the battery died. April 11th phone activity could have been an erroneous water-induced signal turn-on that is known to happen, considering there were no other actions on it afterwards, or a last ditch attempt of Lisanne to try getting any use of it before succumbing to the environment.

Lack of texts to family could be due to them likely not having a local SIM (or one at all), so no roaming. And that’s not counting further reasons like due to insufficient credit, battery saving focused only on 911 calls, or just incomplete data accumulated. The piece of skin being Lisanne’s is also disputed, and was apparently examined to be of animal (cow) origin. The jean shorts were probably used as a pillow during the night and/or became irritating to wear; them being neatly folded instead of washing up is also likely erroneous reporting. And cleanly severed feet in shoes washing up is actually a common occurrence. Establishing Occam’s razor is not necessarily simple, but there’s still not enough concrete evidence of foul play to beat it.

One thing’s for sure though, regardless of where the thought on this case falls, the overall feeling starts with ‘what were Dutch girls doing in the wildness of Panama either way?’ and ends with ‘why were they keen for Panamanian wilderness instead of the beautiful capital of Panama City or other well-populated exotic cities in the Americas?’

comment.author: @dmwme

comment.text:
Because I somehow refuse to believe that the perfect criminal lives in the Panama Jungle, I am sticking to my theory that the two young women unfortunately died in an accident or as a result of cold and thirst. The whole manipulation of the camera, the rucksack, etc. would be too perfect for me. Why all this effort in Panama Jungle? It's so easy to make a person disappear completely here. Why even take the risk of bones, cell phones, etc. being found? And then again, it's not clear enough to be able to say for sure that the two were involved in an accident. Okay in a Hollywood crime thriller, but in real life I actually believe that solving the case is probably really as unsatisfactory and simple as you might think. If the camera hadn't been found, the scenario would be so much easier to imagine. The question is, can the camera actually be ignored because the night photos were simply taken in the course of full dehydration, disorientation or is the camera the key to the case?

Because the only argument I have that points to a crime is the fact that neither the cell phones nor the camera were used to take ANY! picture was taken that would come close to explaining the situation of the two. Imagine you wander through the forest all day like in Blair Witch Project, at some point you take a break, let yourself go into the bushes and think, hey, document it, take a picture, a short video. At some point in 10 years, you laugh about the situation. Nothing, nothing at all. Not a single picture. 

Nevertheless, there is one case that is very similar, at least in terms of the photos = Jared Negrete
Here, too, nothing seems to fit and yet it is safe to assume that he too has simply lost his way.
And if you can't prove anything anyway, you should just assume the best for the victims, that they had an accident.

comment.text: Killed by a jaguar. There are regional governmental conservation efforts to protect the jaguar. Any official autopsy would tend to block jaguar predation as a cause. One of the last photos taken has been forensically modified to help brighten the picture. You can see a large cat. Leaving this picture on the phone was a fortunate mistake on part of the first agency to view the photos. Any clear pictures of a jaguar would have been erased, before it was released to the public. The girl was smart to create as much of a reflective surface as possible to temporarily flash-blind the jaguar. From the summit point, one of the young women saw how easy it would be to travel along the river all the way to the north coast, rather than turn around. The ginger girl, in one of the later pictures, was really uncomfortable with the idea of following the riverbank. A jaguar's main hunting area is the riverbank. Jaguars have one of the highest bite strengths of any animal. When a cat chews bone, it grinds it into a paste. The only bones left with mountain lion attacks tend to be the flesh they couldn’t get out of the footwear.

comment.text: Très contente de ré-entendre parler de cette affaire. J'ai cependant des doutes sur l'hypothèse proposée. Si les éventuels criminels avaient voulu faire croire que les filles étaient perdues dans la jungle, comment auraient ils pu composer le 112 (numéro des secours en Europe) ou se décider à essayer le 911. Ils auraient à mon avis utilisé un numéro du Panama, peu probable qu'ils aient connaissance du 112. Et puis c'est quand même plus simple de faire disparaitre (ou casser) les téléphones. Pour la photo c'est vrai que c'est intriguant mais la théorie la plus simple pourrait être une erreur de manipulation lors de l'analyse de l'appareil par la police scientifique (que le laboratoire n'aurait pas voulu admettre), aux vues des autres éléments (chambre et indices contaminés) on se dit que l'on n'a pas affaire aux experts Manhattan. Je pense que la thèse officielle tient la route bien que ma curiosité me pousserait à faire une expérience comme laisser un sac à dos semblable dans une jungle avec un GPS dedans pour voir ce qu'il devient après des jours/semaines/mois. Il y a certes des choses bizarres, parfois on se dit que l'on aurait fait autrement, que par exemple on aurait enregistré un message "d'adieu" mais n'ayant pas été confrontée à cette situation (et j'espère que ça n'arrivera jamais), je ne sais pas ce que j'aurais fait. En tout cas si au moins l'une d'elles a survécu 11 jours, chapeau, elle a fait preuve de beaucoup de courage.

Et puis non quand j'ai vu qu'une lettre anonyme parvenue à l'ambassade des Pays-Bas au Canada disait  : " S'il vous plaît, n'arrêtez pas les recherches, il y a des preuves, vous avez cherché au mauvais endroit, les auteurs sont libres." Je pense donc à un crime déguisé en accident. Les jeunes, dont parle Lionel, ont effacé la photo 509 sur laquelle ils étaient vus. La suite est évidente.   Dommage que les investigations n'ont pas été poussées pour retrouver à qui appartenaient les 3 empreintes digitales retrouvées sur les portables.  Paix à leurs âmes.

He continued making calls once he got them to his ranch to make it look like they were still calling, but he didn’t know the code to the phone. The girls escaped after a week and that’s when they took all the night pictures, and why they were trying to find their way at night. That’s how they survived without having food or water with them, why there is a gap in photos, the deleted photo could’ve had him in it and he had to get rid of the evidence that he was there. Their clothes and especially their shoes did not show signs of rough wear which they should have if being worn in a jungle for a week. I’m not sure if he found them after they escaped and he killed them, or if they did just die from injuries/natural causes at that point and he found them after death and took them. Then he planted all the evidence to be found and bleached one’s bones but didn’t do the other one’s for whatever reason. This is the only theory that makes sense to me. As for those who say why would he go to all that trouble when he could just hide everything, misdirection works better. Make it look like they just got lost and died. If no evidence was found at all, no one would give up on looking for them and he was already a suspect. Planting just enough evidence to show they died out there served its purpose of throwing everyone off and shutting down the investigation.
Also, they didn’t take toilet paper with them, and probably not a mirror either, so where did it come from?

comment.text: Kris led the way off the trail and into the jungle, she wanted some impressive jungle photos for her Facebook and Lisanne, naturally the more sensible, followed reluctantly, not wanting to be boring, this was an adventure trip  after all. Well, fools rush in and just as Lisanne had decided to put her foot down and insist they return,  Kris decided on one more photo opportunity, one risk to many and took a serious fall breaking her leg. Lisanne made 911 calls from both mobiles but alas no signal. It dawned on her that there was no way her friend could be helped back up the the way they came and they were trapped where they were with night falling. Bravely the girls staggered down the mountain side for 24 hours towards the sound of running water. Exhausted they made camp at the riverbank clearing by the monkey bridge and hoped to be found by someone passing through or seen from above by a rescue helicopter. Still badly injured and passing in and out of consciousness Kris was in no position to move again. Lisanne had to make a choice, leave friend and go got help or sit tight and trust that a rescue party would reach them. The loyal friend stayed but there would be no rescue and by April 8th Kris had passed into a coma and was dying. As the night drew in the animals of the jungle picked up the scent of death and a lone Jaguar stalked the area and could not be driven off by the flashlights of Lisanne’s camera. The attack when it came was swift and decisive , Lisanne already weekend and unable to defend herself succumbed to the the jungle predator and the girls fate was complete. Maybe the search party found the aftermath of this gruesome scene eventually, maybe it went unnoticed. Maybe it was better left unsaid. RIP Dutch girls

comment.text: the dna on the backpack could just be locals/hikers who tampered with the backpack wondering what it was. it doesn’t automatically indicate foul play. also it’s possible that investigators working in the case deleted that photo themselves because it was graphic or irrelevant. i don’t think foul play/murder is completely out of the question, however i’m more likely to believe that some sort of injury made them go off the path on accident out of panic and trying to find help, and the random pictures were used for light/trying to signal for help. the attempted passcodes was probably one of the girls trying to get in the other girls’ phone while one of them was unconscious or deceased. for some reason i’m inclined to believe that one of them died early on in the hike due to injury, instead of both of them at the same time. i think the other girl probably passed a few days/weeks later due to starvation, infection or an animal attack after failing to find her way back or get any help…… this whole thing is so sad to think about. rest in peace to both of them.

It’s very hard to traverse through dense jungle even in daylight. It’s impossible at night time without any light. The night time pictures taken from the same spot look like the were taken from an elevated position, at least from some form of rock that was higher than the jungle floor. And the photos of the mirror setup show that at least one of the girls was still able of rational thinking. I think it’s more likely they were staying at the highest point they could reach for the night. They could have use the camera/flash to try and scare of wild animals. That’s would explain why they pointed the camera at the same point for multiple photos. I can only image how scary it is to be in the middle of a jungle in the dead of night. 

As for the washed up backpack and scattered bones. Even uninsured it’s very hard to walk through dense jungle without any paths or tools. Maybe they thought, that their best chance of finding people was to follow the river. Maybe they packed all of their stuff in the backpack, grabbed a log or big stick and tried to swim down the river and went down a waterfall or tried to climb down next to a waterfall and fell down.

comment.text: Killed by a jaguar. There are regional governmental conservation efforts to protect the jaguar. Any official autopsy would tend to block jaguar predation as a cause. One of the last photos taken has been forensically modified to help brighten the picture. You can see a large cat. Leaving this picture on the phone was a fortunate mistake on the part of the first agency to view the photos. Any clear pictures of a jaguar would have been erased, before it was released to the public. The girl was smart to create as much of a reflective surface as possible to temporarily flash-blind the jaguar. From the summit point, one of the young women saw how easy it would be to travel along the river all the way to the north coast, rather than turn around. The ginger girl, in one of the later pictures, was really uncomfortable with the idea of following the riverbank. A jaguar's main hunting area is the riverbank. Jaguars have one of the highest bite strengths of any animal. When a cat chews bone, it grinds it into a paste. The only bones left with mountain lion attacks tend to be the flesh they couldn’t get out of the footwear.

comment.text: On the 1st April 2014 after 2pm, by which time they had turned around to go back and were retracing their steps, someone attacked and subdued Kris Kremers and Lisanne Froon. Their phones were taken off them. About two hours later one attempted emergency call was made from each of their phones, 12 minutes apart. Had that been Kris and Lisanne,  they'd each have made multiple attempts one after the other. So it was almost certainly one man who knew there was no phone reception in the area, and was using each of their phones in turn. Or, or him untying the hands standing over each girl in turn as they tried to made the calls. What is strange is this entailed him already having formulated a long term plan to later leave the phones to be found. He then switched both phones off for 13 hours (inconceivable that Kremers and  Froon would have made one failed-to-connect call each to the emergency number, then both given up and switched off).  Next morning he switched the phones on, and again made--or more likely had the girls make--attempts to connect to the emergency number. There was only one call by Kremer's but repeated calls by Froon's phone,. On the third try by Froon's phone that morning, to his surprise and no doubt dismay,  Froon's phone did connect to a network. There were no more attempt to call the emergency number with Froon's phone,  and Froon's phone was left on all night, which ran the battery down. Next morning (3rd April), Kremers's phone made an attempt to call the emergency number that was the last one by either of the phones. Just think about that for a second; it had power and was having the correct pins entered for another 48 hours, yet there was no attempt to call the emergency or any other number by Kremers's phone*. I doubt that either girl was alive after midday of the 5th. That would explain why no PINS for Kremers's phone starting that afternoon. There was the photo on the 8th of Kremer's hair, but that could have been faked on her corpse. The activity without PINS on Kremer's phone until the 11th April was part of a charade being staged by the perpetrator. *Kremers's phone did not need PINs for an emergency call , nether did Froon's. No mystery.

I think they got lost. 
The first few days they attempted emergency calls but since they got no signal, they tried to reach higher altitudes to achieve that goal.
The night photos were taken later in the process, when they were probably being stalked by predators ( big cats) which sense when an animal is injured and dying- humans included- and were trying to scare them off with the flash, in that particular night when it came close.

I think that it is precisely the strange things in this case that make it more likely to have been simply a hike that went very wrong ...

comment.text:
I'm going to go ahead and throw my hat into the ring here.  I think that they became a little too confident after completing the hike, that they had been told wouldn't be easy, it's very possible that they took pictures of themselves at their destination (the end of the uphill trek), where there were signs visible that they shouldn't proceed without a guide.  Feeling a surge of adrenaline rushing through their systems, perhaps they decided to keep hiking past their original destination. After all, they were able to do it faster than expected, and may not have even realized that they were straying too far.  Whether or not it was arrogance, the adrenaline, or possibly even a spur of the moment longing to want their last adventure before returning to begin their work as teachers, they continued on into dangerous parts of the hike. 

Now, from here, any number of variables could come into play; maybe they were very unfortunate and they wandered to non-sturdy ground, due to the massive amount of rainfall that often occur in dense tropical forests, which may have caused one (or both) of the girls to have had a bad fall, possibly killing one of them upon impact, or, while less likely, may have caused severe blunt force trauma that either rendered one of their legs /feet completely useless, heck, maybe she landed against coarse rocks that clean cut the foot off. It'd be more likely that if such a thing were to happen, say if one of them either fell, or perhaps something, such as a rock formation shifting due to any number of things, such as landslides / flash flood(s) (you get the idea) occurred at some point, and they had to amputate the foot... There's just too many possible things that could go wrong, even if they didn't stray from the trail, as hiking (especially in foreign land) can be a very dangerous activity.  Perhaps one of the girls died, and the other, who was in shock, took a picture of her diseased companion out of fear from being accused of foul play, as well as trying to mark the area in which she died at - thinking that she would be able to find her own way out, not realizing that she may have been lost, going the wrong way, etc. which may be why she took so many pictures as well.  I don't like to theorize in this much detail, so I'll stick to the key points from here.  Just remember that this is purely theoretical, and only based off the information in this video. :)

Okay, as for the picture that was deleted and couldn't be restored - It's very possible, even likely, that the picture was in fact not intentionally deleted & wiped.  With the vast distance that it would've had to have traveled, it's fair to assume that the phone / camera could've had a corrupted file. Maybe due to all the photos already existing as well, there wasn't enough room for it to be stored in the first place, but devices like that will still try to create the appropriate format and file extension(s), followed by it being populated by the actual pixels of said picture.  If it lacks the room to fully populate the image, it would have already have pre-created a blank version of it, explaining the name / existence of the file, but it was overpopulated (past the maximum capacity to store the picture), it could easily have auto-deleted that blank formatted image file, which would lead anyone to believe that it was scrubbed cleaned after being deleted, when there wasn't anything there in the first place.  This also commonly occurs when the picture is taken and saved to it's NAND memory but is abruptly powered off.  When it's accessed again, it will either be corrupted, or just gone, making it seem as though the file in question did exist... ANYWAYS...

The rest is just impossible to speculate from the limited amount of details that are available, and honestly, I've already written a light novel with this comment in terms of length, lmao.  I think it was an accident, but regardless of what actually happened, thank God they're no longer suffering...  I pray that the family and friends of these girls are doing okay, as well.  It's really tragic, however, at the very least, there is closure in knowing that they are in fact dead, well, at least one of them has to be, and tbh, I do hope that they are both in a better place and not still out there, working for some drug cartel... I think we can all at least agree on that much.

comment.text: 5 Years later, someone has explained the photos without much room for doubt. They were signalling towards Boquette, and the branch with the red plastic bag was also a signal, to mark their campsite in case someone came across their campsite and didn't see them behind the boulders they were using for shelter. It's very likely they couldn't sleep during the night due to the drop in temps and had to sleep during the day. Honestly, this is one of the saddest stories I have encountered, second only to the Titanic. It will never leave my head, it will never leave my heart. Just like the gentlemen that sank with the ship, so did the girls set up a final camp on the 8th, knowing they will most likely never be found. Kris carrying Lisanne on her shoulders, setting up a final SOS alongside the bottom of the pringles can in case it reflects off of something. She never left her friend. They sat together on a rock sending flash signals into the sky the same way the doomed operators of the Marconi room sent S.O.S until the ships power went out. Eventually they both died. Probably Lisanne first, since she had a broken ankle and infected foot. I honestly can't imagine those final days on that embankment. I wish they were afforded the same luxury as the gentlemen that chose to go down with the ship. A fine brandy to tide over deaths cold grasp as they passed on from this world. They deserved better. They all deserved better; but since life dealt them an unbelievably shitty hand that collapsed their entire lives out of nowhere... like I said... wish they could have at least had a brandy to live out their final moments in peace.

comment.text:
I think they were abducted near the beginning of their hike. There was apparently known gang activity in the area. They took the girls and did goodness knows what with them. Everything on the phone was supposed to be confusing...done by members of the gang. The last pictures were taken when they disposed of the bodies. They took the camera back and deleted a photo...again probably just to be cocky. Then they neatly packed everything back into the backpack and placed it on a trail purposely waiting 2 months so everyone knew it was foul play. 
The backpack was in perfect condition and obviously not out in the elements for two months. Also, their remains were found with bones from 3 other people...an important point you missed Dr. G lol. I think the one picture showing the back of the one’s girls head was taken when they were both already dead. 
Places like this have gangs that the police are well aware of. Often times they don’t thoroughly investigate things in order to keep the peace. The gangs will do things like this almost like a dog would piss on a tree. Simply to mark their territory and show dominance. It’s sick but that’s my theory and the only thing that would explain everything. 
I feel absolutely terrible for these young girls and my heart absolutely bleeds for their families. Such a sad and even infuriating (since nobody will ever be brought to justice and the families will never have closure) case. I believe that these girls died simply because they were young and inexperienced and far too trusting. Not jaded enough to know never to do anything secluded without a guide in places you don’t know and have no idea about.

comment.text: The more that I look at these photos, the more they look like they are being taken from the view of someone stuck in a crevice. Using the flash as a signal or perhaps to get a view of what's above by reaching one arm up and snapping pics to then be viewed on the screen. Maybe she climbed up the side as high as was possible, only holding on with one hand while holding up the camera with the other. If she were stretching to get the camera as high as possible, it's very possible that in the midst of taking the pictures she slipped and almost lost her grip due to the rocks becoming increasingly wet from the water coming down. When I almost fall but am able to catch myself, I stop for a moment and tense up to make sure I have my balance before continuing. If her camera arm was pointing down when she caught herself while gripping the camera to keep from dropping, in that moment she froze to make sure she had her balance she could have pressed the capture button and got that picture of the top of Kris' hair. It's possible Kris couldn't climb due to injury and was either standing below or more likely leaning against the wall. It's possible she was also dead at this time but could still be leaned against the wall. It's hot during the day so she might have regularly wet her hair to cool herself a long as they were near a water source. When you are lost you eventually want to find and stay near a water source, and generally if you follow a river it will eventually bring you to a town or other civilization. Maybe following the river is how they ended up trapped in the ravine. Now let's suppose their bones were scattered due to the water washing them downstream. How did they get there from the ravine? Well, it is raining. The rain or the river rising could be causing the ravine to flood. This would cause a panic and unable to climb out Lisanne began frantically using the camera flash to either survey the scene above her or possibly signal for help. If this sudden flooding happened in the middle of the night and they couldn't see it would make sense of the odd time codes. Either they both perished before their bodies floated up and were washed out or Lisanne survived a bit longer but was injured further in the flood and passed some time after. This would explain why there were a bit of remains that were not as decomposed as the rest. Bodies in water often have their feet come detached work the foot still inside because shoes float. Minerals in the ravine could have bleached some of the bones. This makes the most sense to me as far as how they could have ended up where they were found.

comment.text:
Bonjour Lionel,
Cette histoire est aussi passionnante que triste.
Je reviens de faire cette randonnée (El Pianista) depuis Boquete. Je tenais à la faire lors de mon séjour au Panama. J’y au vu le mémorial avec la croix en l’hommage des 2 jeunes hollandaises en haut du memorial. D’ailleurs je n’ai pas vu le panneau indiquant la fin du parcours.
La théorie locale (biaisée pour ne pas effrayer les touristes) est qu’elles se sont perdues dans la jungle et l’acte criminel n’est pas évoqué. 
De mon point de vue, même avant d’arriver au mirador il y a déjà plusieurs façons de se perdre avec bcp de chemins qui se croisent.
Nous avons du rebrousser plusieurs fois notre chemin. 
Le terrain est compliqué et humide. 
Et quand on arrive au mirador, rien n’indique qu’il s’agit dudit mirador et on a très envie de continuer la randonnée. 
A mon sens, elles ont du continuer après le mirador par erreur en pensant que la randonnée n’était pas finie.
Ensuite, elles ont du inévitablement se perdre.
S’il n’y avait pas cette histoire de cette photo 509 je serais intimement convaincu qu’elles sont mortes après s’être perdues mais cet élément est très intrigant. 
Soit il s’agit d’un bug de l’appareil, soit elles se sont d’abord perdues et ont ensuite fait une mauvaise rencontre dans la jungle… en tout cas ce qui est sûr c’est que les possibilités de se perdre dans cette jungle sont infinies …
