comment.text: Dr Grande's worst ever video. These were two physically fit intelligent adults. Perhaps a chance in a million this was any kind of dual misadventure while lost. Start from the the most obvious thing: that they were a couple of strikingly attractive young women  in an isolated area without phone reception, who would have been defenceless, and thus a tempting target for predatory men. The propinquity of what was left of their bodies,  bones being fragmented into shards (especially),  and one set of remains showing signs of being chemically stripped of flesh makes it ludicrous to think the most plausible explanation is accidents and exhaustion. The sinister night photograph of the back of Kremers’ head shows blood; they were being forced by their captors  to walk into a more secluded area, the flash was for light. I strongly suspect they were followed from the town, realized it and tried to call for help but got captured and beaten, then forced  deep into the jungle possibly to some shack. The bodies were pulverised and disposed of later.  Sadly, when police are confronted with an unsolvable crime they have a powerful motive to write it off as probably not due to foul play. I'm old and over the decades have seen it repeatedly.  For example the Babes in the Wood murders (Epping Forest), and the Disappearance of Natalee Holloway, and the case of Julie Ward.

comment.text:
This case is haunting. I think the night photos were possibly them deciding to stay put, due to extreme hunger and thirst, or perhaps kremers was injured/dying, so they tried to get as high up as they could w some clearing in the sky. I think they were def using the camera for light and decided they weren't getting anywhere/never got cell service again & were just wasting energy, so perhaps they would try to stay on top of this ravine (esp. if kremers was injured or dying) and make an SOS sign w a reflective device to try to get a helicopter's attn flying above. This was their last ditch effort to try & get help 😔The bags on the twigs could've just been trash they found & decided to utilize to try to signal a helicopter as well (u would hope they'd be using binoculars). That also explains why the final cell service check was the next morning and no further pics followed, and they died soon after. The only thing that's weird about that to me is if they both died after 10 days, can't ppl survive longer w/out food/water? But then again they were hiking for 10 days straight in the jungle, so i dunno.

I don't really suspect foul play simply bc a killer could've easily made their bodies/bones & backpack/camera/phones disappear completely. Why leave any evidence to be found somewhere it's easy to hide evidence?

comment.text:
I think the non-smiling photos are simply candid shots. No setup or warning a picture was about to be taken. Nothing sinister. The subject just wasn't prepared. The deleted picture could be of an embarrassing pose. Nudity perhaps (going for a swim?). One of those candid shots. If one of the girls began to suspect they might die and the camera found later, she might take the time to delete it, not wanting that to be widely seen. Or, the more sinister motive, someone who did not want their picture taken. The loss of night vision caused by the flash is easily overcome by just shutting your eyes when you push the button. It would seem a person would learn that pretty quickly. At the least close one eye. Cover it with your hand, as well as, closing it if possible.

Also, as to using a computer to "wipe," the file as opposed to  simply "deleting" it, there is software for doing this that works right on the phone, no external computer needed. Though I don't know if it was common at that time.

comment.text:
Maybe they didn't take a photo at the 2nd small river because they were already tired and somewhat covered in mud. It is not inconceivable that they had both slipped before and begin to feel stressed. They were not clothed good for this kind of walk. They had no or very little food. They had no fresh water and probably decided not to drink from the rivers at day 1. I suspect that they walked on as quickly as possible, believing or hoping that they would end up back in civilization. Perhaps they thought that walking further was shorter than turning around the Pianista trail. It is very good possible Lisanne broke her foot at day one a few hours after they reached the top of the trail. Walking a foot can quickly lead to wedges in the bad jungle grounds. Then turning back was no longer an option for them and a walk back was very long. They were trapped by the medical problem. Of course Kris would not leave her friend alone in the jungle for the night. Perhaps they decided to seek help from houses along the paths. With a broken foot, no one can walk well, especially not very far and not fast. I think there is a good chance that they left the path after reaching the top. Maybe they feared the cows on the path, maybe they feared the men on the path. Maybe they were just curious to see some more of the jungle. They didn't know how dangerous this jungle could be. Everything indicates they left the path, lost track and got in troubles at day one. Probably they soon became lost and panicked. After walking around in stress for a few hours, Lisanne broke her foot, making it very difficult to walk on fast. So they called emergency numbers, to no avail. Then they spent the night in the jungle and in the morning they slowly continued the search for the path or following the river. They didn't take pictures anymore after the last picture of Kris. The only reason they didn't I can imagine is because the camera's and phones were too wet. They could open but no apps could be used for a few days. The night pictures: probably taken to sign to a helicopter or maybe they've (or one of them) did hear human voices. Real voices or voices due to hallucinations. Given the circumstances that is possible. They would only us the flash of the telephone in that situation if it could give them a chance to get in contact with people. Did a helicopter searched the area that time? Did any plane cross the sky at that time? What triggered them to flash the camera to sign? They were close to water at that moment. The person who used the telephone camera just flashed light in a circle to heaven. Was it a S.O.S?

Everything that dies close to the river there, ends up in that river there. But perhaps they ended up using one of the dangerous rope bridges in the end, on April 11th or 12th, if then they both were still alive... Because they had no chance to try anything else because Lisanne had probably already broken her foot bones on April 1th and developed serious bone inflammation in the following days, due to open wounds on her legs or because of the broken foot. Both women probably decided to try the dangerous bridge because it was their only chance to find people. They put all their belonging in the bag. Kris must also soon have had a hard time physically as she was also lightly dressed and insects and plants damage the body in those conditions there. One night in the Panama jungle is enough to make two young women very ill. Both got fever and ill and must have weakened very fast. Did they fell off the rope bridge due to exhaustion and Kris then broke her hip shortly before they drowned?
comment.author: @Tobealiveisnottobe

comment.text: Lisanne pronounced close to Lisahnah/Lisahneh. If you leave off the last e, it's like saying umbrell instead of umbrella. IMO Lisanne had been having premonitions against going on this trip for some time. Of course the problem with this sad case is that there is no one decisive clue defining whether it was misadventure or foul play. Except for one comment by a Spanish speaking doctor on another site stating that if the girls fell into the river their bones would have scrape marks on them from being rubbed against the rocks by the flow of the river, but they didn't. Also some say that the taxi driver said that he dropped the girls at the trail start at 3pm. But their photos show time beginning at 11am. What if the cabbie actually picked them up at 3pm but said he was dropping them off in case he was seen in the vicinity? Then abducted them?

comment.text: After watching these two videos, I've changed my mind about some things. Actually, I knew from the very beginning that they were kidnapped and killed. comment.text: Great presentation. Always stick to the facts. I've been following this case now for almost nine years. Today, 01 April 2014, marks the 10th anniversary of Kris and Lisanne's disappearance. Local witnesses testimony and the doctored photos on Lisanne's Canon camera clearly point towards the abduction and murder theory. As mentioned, the sudden appearance of the packback (with its contents in pristine condition) and bleached human bones were only a means of trying to reduce the strong local and international concerns over the girls disappearance. Funny how it was always the local guide, Feliciano, who would find these items. Finally Lisanne's father now knows what happened to the girls. However he had to sign confidential secret agreement with the Dutch Government.

Maybe the first few days they had some hope they would get through on their cell phones if they kept hiking, and then that hope slowly died as more days passed and they got hungrier and more tired. I think as u start starving and dying of thirst, u start hallucinating too, so that would make it even more scary in the jungle at night.   I think perhaps on that 7th day when they were taking the night photos, maybe they hiked up to a higher elevation to try to get a signal and they literally had no energy left at that point. They made an SOS sign w the ripped up map, put a mirror or some kind of refective surface down to try to refelect the camera flash, hoping helicopters were searching at night. I picture the blond girl injured, maybe she died first and the other girl didn't want to leave her, so maybe that was why her phone was trying to be unlocked without a pin. comment.text: The most likely explanation is that Panamanian authorities are right.  The girls made it to the summit late in the day and then unwisely continued onward for a bit.  Either they got turned around and lost (which easily happens in the forest) or one or both of them got hurt in a fall or other accident. They tried to call for help but had no phone coverage. (April 1 around 4:40 PM). They probably decided to spend the night at some point and try again in the morning. They tried again periodically through April 4 when one phone died.  They possibly moved at one or more points ending up in the Culubre River basin. (Which would have provided a water source, but was not the area being searched). By April 8th when the photos were taken one could have been dead (or sick/hurt) and the other out of her mind in a panic. She was possibly trying to signal some noise she heard etc. At least one of them survived until April 11.

comment.text: I was born on the same exact day as Lisanne Froon; September 24, 1991. It really makes me think, we went thru so many of the same world events and social/cultural phenomenon together. Any memory I have, whether it's the release of Ocarina of Time on the N64 or the original Pokemon cards; good chance she would have had her own strong memories of it as well. We probably had the same memories of 9/11... sitting in class; maybe your teacher also watched with your class live as the planes hit the towers, broadcast on one of those CRT's on those portable stands they would keep them on. We would both have much clearer memories of every September 24 up until 2013; while for the vast majority of people it either held no significance or they weren't even born yet. I believe I have a very similar personality type to her as well; shy, sensitive, but craving for adventure, always pushing for personal growth and chasing after experiences as well as just having a deep-seeded need for love and connection on a human level. We were also both similar heights; I'm 188 and a half but she was 184; damn, that's tall for a woman! We also apparently graduated Uni the same year and with the same major. The year was 2014; her degree was more specific, I just got a major in Psychology. Thanks to that I know exactly what I was doing in March, April of 2014. Our Spring semester that year ended on April 4th, we had a 'reading-week' until the 8th and started final Exams on the 9th. So while Lisanne was taking those night photos, one of her last days on this earth, I know exactly where I was; I was at home, staying up all night as well cramming for my final I had put off until the last minute. By the time I was picking up my diploma she was already gone. Somehow, it makes me happy to have that very specific memory of where I was when this happened to her. It makes me feel a lot closer to her as a result. In the end, a bit upwards of 300,000 people were probably born on September, 24, 1991. I don't know how many are still alive, but Lisanne, you will always be in my memory and I'll make it to the finish line for the both of us.

comment.text: 7:06 Its not a marker of some sort... They were attempting to use it, and wave it so planes searching for them would see it.  The photos are up are them trying to use the flash to get the planes attention. The items on the rock are the same.  Used so a search plane or helicopter would see it.  Thats why it is spread out like that.   This is also evidence that at least one of the girls was still alive 7 days later since they are still attempting to contact search parties.  As for 10:00 bone being bleached, natives from panama are not carrying bleach to try and bleach a pelvic bone.  Even the most competent drug dealer in the jungles of panama isn't going to go through the trouble to try and bleach a pelvic bone.  There has to be another conclusion to that.  GPS on the phones would show they didn't come back into town to "party".  The wrong password for Kris's phone is probably because Kris was gone and her friend was using her phone as her phone had died several days earlier.  The image at 6:28 is most likely her using the flash towards herself thinking it may highlight her to search crews, even if only for a second.  Its the same reason she took a picture of the branch with the orange bags tied to it.  She thought it may highlight it to planes.  After trying to flash the planes with no success, she thought maybe flashing it on the orange bag and rock may have a slightly higher chance of success.  Same with her flashing the white paper on the rock.  And I would bet same with Kris orange hair.  Lighting up orange hair with a flash was a signal attempt.  I would bet if flight logs could be reviewed, they would find an aircraft was visible to the girls location from 1:30-145 am.

comment.text:
I wonder if part of the reason they thought going off the trail would be fine was because growing up in one of the safest countries in the world along with what seemed to be very kind locals lulled them into a false sense of security. I also do wonder if part of the reason they went off the trail was because someone on it offered to be a guide. I imagine if the person asked not to be photographed they wouldn’t have found it odd in the moment. That or they didn’t want to have that person in their pictures. The one where one of the girls looks anxious makes me think of a situation where maybe one of the girls was getting suspicious and wanted to turn around but the other person and/or the other girl decided they would keep going. I could 100% see someone telling them that there is a cool place deeper in and that the would show them and then intentionally got them all lost and/or lead them to others who would aid in killing them.

The picture of Chris’s hair is what throws me the most. I genuinely wonder if it was taken as a trophy and she was scalped. It would make sense that the hair was dry if someone was keeping it in a backpack protected from the rain and I imagine it would have been washed before being tucked away to clean it up. It’s a gruesome theory and I do hope I’m wrong but I could shake the thought once I saw the picture.

comment.text:
Thank you for sharing this story, and for your honesty. 👍

I was in Panama back in 2003 on a Caribbean vacation with friends! It was a 10 day cruise through the Western Caribbean. 

I can say the jungle in Panama is no joke because of all the wildlife, terrain and intense humidity as well. 

All I can think, is that they were using the camera flash for vision and possibly to signal any planes flying over at night. Maybe the flash was to signal other people that had flashlights or were camping in the vast area. ?

Someone was obviously tampering with the I phone given the information you provided. 

All the other evidence of bones being located 5 miles from the trail, but the remains found near a stream were with other people's bones,.....would make more sense if you follow the "Bigfoot" stories along the Appalachian Trail or Pacific Northwest. However, if animal attack evidence is not found, it seems like there's a serious killer out their in Panama who is a possible cannibal or has some sick agenda!? 🤔 

The photo of the blonde hair may have been taken by the girl's friend or the victim, to capture evidence of being injured!? People in sketchy situations tend to not use logic and get desperate for help, especially when lost in the wilderness or a jungle. 

They are both attractive ladies, so that in itself is dangerous, "Anywhere!" People can be more dangerous than wildlife. 💯 😢

Hopefully a break in this case provides closure for the families and friends. 🙏 💔

comment.text:
"For the record: I personally do not suspect this guide to be involved in the actual disappearance of Kris and Lisanne".That, if you don't mind me saying so, is a funny way of looking at it. The connection of Kris and Lissane to the guide is that they booked him to take them on the trail they were killed on. He was in possession of information about their intention to walk that trail before they went on it. Is he supposed to have tipped someone else off who just happened to be the guys at the putative shack party who happened to know his son and invited him along. Taking the party scenario seriously, there were only two girls so why would they want a third or fourth guy for? There is not much zero evidence of Lisanne or Kris being the sort of girls open to such an invitation to party (ie consume alcohol) at a lonely spot with a gang of rough Panamanian men they hardly knew. It would be a very different thing to the brunch they attended that morning with two Dutch boys. There is the pool photo, but it was taken at a semi public spot. Kris and Lissane were not teenagers, they knew what young guys could be like. I think the shack party scenario is a calumny, but supposing they had went to such a party and stuff happened that caused them to expire.

Let's say the after the party F is called in to cover up. This is presumably not an average Monday evening for him. Yet he does not just disappear the corpses, he  immediately also begins a longer term plan to create a false impression there was no crime. So without previously having ever so much as toyed with the idea of how to mount such a deception, and experiencing tremendous shock and stress, the fully formed and  fiendishly complicated scheme popped into his head when he put his mind on the problem there and then. Moreover, while under enormous unexpected pressure over the next 24 hours, he carries out all the highly involved maneuvers required while dealing with the police and keeping up a façade that would be difficult for someone with normal human feelings. He would be a very clever man.

comment.text:
Went off route, because that just is what some pleople hyped about specifics tend to do.
Got lost as heck. And called 112. Probably remained at spot for as long as they could trying not to even divert further in hopes to be found.
Shit got tight, when they figured day is approaching its end and used the mirror (way too late) to start a fire. This would be a natural human reaction in this situation to seeing the sun approach obstacles. Additionally this was the only stuff they had around as they left with pretty much nothing. A desperate attempt at making heat, light and a means to defend.
Until this point, it is probably the most likely thing to have happend considering their equipment, diaries and level of education. Especially the powering of the phones to preserve energy seems to me as a well calculated action.
After that speculation begins.
The Night Photos were probably taken out of fear. Its the wilderness after all, whomever has seen a fullsize boar compared to an adult human will be able to understand this: if there were animal noises you would turn on the lights in europe. If you are in the wilderness and there are animal sounds YOU WILL use any means available to generate any sort of light source even if that means to take multiple shots with your camera. The pictures do show, that the only reason its showing the sky sometimes was the orientation of the phone. All Light is emitted in the same direction.
In this situation you would use light to confirm if any harm was done or is imminent.
The girls, fear induced by darkness and their surroundings which is absolutely understandable, decided to break camp at daybreak. No one is dumb enough to walk at night in such surroundings. They decided to use one phones battery before the others, which again is a smart survival action. That they did turn off the phones and only turned them on to try multiple rescue calls implies to me, that whatever happend them to die must have happend after them presumingly leaving the backpack by choice as it did only include stuff unneeded for survival which would have simply added additional weight to the shoulders of one of them both.
It is likely, from a human standpoint, that they tried to maintain direction of travel but mainly height in hopes to catch signal and went along the ridge at 8.913311933034283, -82.45466394407931. They probably followed that and made a lot of halts finding less steep terrain at 8.933576212448237, -82.44864498383144. Maybe they also took their first camp there April 1 to 2. Once they figured there is no signal to be gained the phase of realization of being lost kicks in followed by calming and the rationale to make a decision for progress. Water was probably not a limiting factor the first 1-3 days as it rained and the area provided ampt amounts of foilage to be used as rain catchers for the bottles. From here they could have made the decision to follow the flat terrain towards the NW towards 8.94815491630155, -82.46768512864843 OR towards the East in direction of 8.918629461068516, -82.4153147082269. Its programmed into people to follow slopes and draws until you find the lowest terrain feature and hopefully a river. Rivers do provide "fresh" water, occaisions of food and usually lead towards civilization when followed down stream. But both knew that they came from upstream as the continantal devide is a widely recognizable feature from the wide riverbed, once they found the river they probably realized, that they were on the wrong side of the devide and went upstream towards 8.897815180967918, -82.40558468904538. Somewhere there one or both of them probably lost their lifes heading into the right direction.
The only reason for death I can Imagine is the unfortunate case of Lisanne having a physically traumatic incident, a fall of great height of sorts.
The fact, that the check for signal maintained constant and the backpack was nearly undamaged makes a return for retrieval unlikely.
Which leaves the point, that the incident, injury or murder of both must have happend upstream into south direction.
Both are part of about 20 people that disappeared in that area over the years around 2013. Chalk and fertilizer being used to disintegrate the remains and their spreading across the riverside makes it very likely, that they and others are victims of either someone wanting to dispose of the hikers bodies quietly after finding both dead after and incident for staying undercover (most likely drug and man trafficing taking place and the fear of routes or camps being detectred when large search parties maintained) or flat out murder which would make no sense, as they had no belongings on them that would be of any major worth.
comment.author: @simonsilence

comment.text:
This seems fairly simple to me. First, the girls (being Dutch) weren't used to this sort of landscape. They went on the hike and either didn't know to turn back or they decided to purposefully continue on. There are reported smaller trails just used by locals that connect to the one they were on. I suspect they decided to continue. Then, they walked for three hours, getting lost as they started to lose the path. Then, Kris falls in some way. I suspect it was on a river bank as they were trying to follow the river bed. She has a major injury (likely the broken pelvis) and potentially a blow to the back of her head (showing her hair in the one photo and it looks like at the very bottom potentially a blow) and this is when they start calling 112 (emergency services for Dutch). This is them calling because it wouldn't be the number someone else tries in this region. Then, they try multiple times calling 112 and 911 over the next couple of days. Dense jungle prevents them from getting through. Lisa's phone dies first even though they attempt to save the batteries. Meanwhile, Kris is really hurt and in a lot of pain. The majority of calling is done by Lisa from her phone. Unfortunately, Kris dies sometime on April 3rd or 4th. Lisa's phone has no battery left after the 4th. She starts trying to use Kris's phone, but doesn't have the pin code. She tries entering multiple pins she thinks Kris might have used. Kris was badly hurt and never got to tell her the pin. Perhaps even...if she did have a head blow...wasn't fully coherent. So that is why there are multiple attempts with the wrong pin. Then I think it's likely Lisa tries to walk out after Kris dies...knowing it is her only hope. She might have even tried to walk to high ground to attempt to get a cell phone signal. At one point, she uses the camera flash for lighting and that's why we see odd pictures. Unfortunately, on April 11th, Lisa dies. She turned on Kris's iPhone and had it on for an hour attempting to find signal. She probably hoped she could make an emergency call even without the pin. But, she turns it off after an hour with 22% battery remaining. She never turns it on again, suggesting she doesn't make it another night. Likely she was either injured or died from exposure/thirst/hunger. If not, with 22% left she likely would have tried again. 

The foul play idea is ridiculous. What captors would let them keep their cell phones? And what captors would be smart enough to try 112 or 911 instead of the local emergency numbers? Also, why even bother trying to fake anything? 

They found the backpack and bones spread out because Lisa kept going...trying to find a way out. Kris had already died and she didn't know what to do.

comment.text:
extensive research, thanks for the great video and the alternate hypothesis. i'm of the mind that this was foul play as well... however, this video right here is of a man who documented the whole trail after the summit for us to see: channel "Romain C" part 2... at the 24:00 mark of that video you can see that picture 508 of Kris by the stream shows her continuing on toward the Serpent trail, and not back toward the summit as the expert local had said... not saying you are wrong with your theory, but Kris is NOT heading back in the direction from where they came in this photo. That being said, it does seem like a good place to turn around if you're hiking on this trail. a sudden change in scenery from the enclosed walls of rock and thick shrubbery from where they came.

edit: it's worth mentioning in 508 you can see Kris facing back across the stream, and behind her seems to be an incline of the trail leading up. if you watch the video, you'll see this is an illusion, as what appears to be a path behind her is not part of the trail. instead, the path continues much more horizontally to the right of her as she faces the camera.

As the trail continues past the stream, there are several places that "could" potentially cause one to get lost, but i wouldn't say it's likely. There are several forks that veer off, and appear as though they could be part of the trail if you were an unexperienced hiker and weren't paying attention. while i don't think they are pronounced enough to cause any real confusion, if you were to veer off the trail in those surroundings, it would be easy to lose your bearings. I don't think that's what happened, but it's not entirely impossible that they could have gotten lost on one of these offshoots.

comment.text: In another video, the parents of Kris Kremers took the same trail to get an idea of the terrain the young women faced months earlier. They stated that there could have been no way for the ladies to have gotten lost because thick vegetation surrounds the trail on both sides. However, I think they did not factor in the following: 1) They retraced their daughter's steps already knowing the outcome. Hindsight is always viewed with 20/20 glasses; 2) The parents had guides with them and could have never gotten lost, whereas Kris and Lisanne were unguided and unfamiliar with the area; 3) Having hiked countless trails in many countries (including tropical ones) myself, there is always the main trail but animal trails and washes that look like trails, many single-track and narrow, are always present. It would be easy for inattentive newbies talking and snapping photos to start walking along one of these by mistake; 4) Kris's parents took a day trip and brought the necessary gear and supplies, but as we know based on the calls that were made on Kris and Lisanne's phones, that the two were out there for days with insufficient food and clothing. People have commented that they could have simply walked out. Seemed like Kris had gotten injured and Lisanne could not, or did not want, to leave her. With each passing day, the lack of food and exposure to the elements would have taken a toll on them mentally and physically. Other thoughts: Why did they take night shots of seemingly random things? Jungles come alive at night. I'd be doing the same thing if there were things moving around and making sounds in the darkness. Why did they call 112 (the equivalent of 911) in the Netherlands? My guess is because it was familiar to them. They had not been in Panama for very long after all and would have known that calling their homeland's emergency agency would have been more reliable than calling the hostel where they were staying. The Dutch responders would have immediately known to contact their parents to make them aware of the situation. Of course the rest of this tragic story raises more questions than answers and has many parts, but this is just my take about one of those parts.

comment.text: I remember this incident. Poor girls but I am not convinced they met with foul play and they sure as hell weren't abducted. It was not wise for them to go off by themselves to explore that area. They should have gone in a group or at least with someone who was familiar with the terrain. They went too far out and got lost or perhaps they had even gotten hurt and weren't capable of making it back but if the situation had been handled better they could have been rescued. Very sad and those night pictures are eerie and i do think her friend was dead in that one picture and she was all alone in the pitch darkness and no doubt terrified and starving and I'm sure she figured she wasn't going to make it out of there alive either so she was just waiting to die or by some miracle be rescued. As a volcanologist, I know all about frightening situations so I can imagine what they went through and for two young woman who sadly perished while simply trying to live life to the fullest, its a terrible shame. Unfortunately what happened to them happens quite often to hikers who go off exploring areas like that.  They weren't the first ones and i hate to say but they won't be the last. At least something of them was found. Many people who go hiking in rough terrain like that seemingly vanish into thin air and no trace of them is ever found. Foul play was not the issue in this case though I'm convinced and there's absolutely no evidence to support that theory. comment.text: Killed by a jaguar. There are regional governmental conservation efforts to protect the jaguar. Any official autopsy would tend to block jaguar predation as a cause. One of the last photos taken has been forensically modified to help brighten the picture. You can see a large cat. The girl was smart to create as much of a reflective surface as possible to temporarily flash-blind the jaguar. From the summit point, one of the young women saw how easy it would be to travel along the river all the way to the north coast, rather than turn around. The girl in this picture was really uncomfortable with the idea of following the riverbank. She probably countered her friend’s proposition with “If the path was meant to go further, someone would have done it many times already, and there would be a clear path.” A jaguar's main hunting area is the riverbank. Jaguars have one of the highest bite strengths of any animal. When a cat chews bone, it grinds it into a paste. The only bones left with mountain lion attacks tend to be the flesh they couldn’t get out of the footwear.

comment.text:
This to me sounds like an accident and not a crime. Due to the following points.
The girls were so happy and excited about the trip and they seem to be really enjoying it in the early images. 
They had so much energy left at the spot were they should have ended the trip, So, they felt confident enough to continue the journey a bit more. 
Kris seems to have lost energy or started to worry. Explaining the less happy face in the later images. 
The deleted image might be them deleting a blurry photo or accidentally hitting delete.
They are now lost in the jungle, two city girls from another culture, in a different topography and weather.
The bras...it's and isolated space, they had privacy or they just weren't the mood to deal with the heat and exhaustion so, girls being girls they took it off and carefully placed it in the bag neatly folded. Or the lady who found it opened it and once realising it might not just be a lost bag, placed everything back carefully and contacted authority.
Once they found that they are lost, they tried to save battery and used the phones for emergency calls only. 
Kris definitely seems to be the one to have passed first and Lisa was the one who tried to unlock Kris's phone to keep getting help. She might not have known or noticed that she could place emergency calls from the lock screen.
The images took at night is what really make me sad and scared. In my opinion it was Lisa next to Kris's body, in the middle of a jungle, all alone in dark, probably super week,dazed, and scared. just trying to get some light cause she was scared or heard something in the bushes. We don't know how fast the shutter was pressed. They didn't turn it on before so there's a good possibility that she used it for light since the phones are dead now. Or she was just trying to signal someone thinking there would be search parties up for them by now. Or she just documented the location by randomly taking pictures in all direction.

The body parts might be the jungle dealing with their dead bodies. Wild animals and the extreme weather conditions plus their super weak and already decomposing bodies...
if the leg got caught in between rocks in a strong flowing river the weak body will be ripped clear off leaving the shoes and foot behind.


To me 95% it was an accident. But, 5%...
Why they never made another call or SMS. (They might have been certain it would be a waste of energy)
Why they didn't bother taking pictures after they were sure they are lost ( They might have been too worried or not in a mental state to do it.)
Lisa seems to have recorded some vlog type video or greetings for someone, earlier. So she is definitely the type to have recorded herself in the camera documenting her current state or last moments. But she did not do it. No images of their then current situation or her deceased friend or anything is daylight.... So the images available on the camera was her definitely trying to see something in the dark, scared. I don't see any probability of someone else ever coming into contact with them.
The bag was dry... but how long was it with that lady who found it. How strong was the sun that day. What kind of fabric it had....

Anyway this is just heartbreaking. Pls, pls, if you ever go on an adventure like this...be aware of your skills and surroundings. Be aware of all things that could go wrong and prepare accordingly.

comment.text:
This is a very good video, but it has so many instances of: "may have, may have been, maybe" (ie. may be gang affiliated, which is said mult times). These "maybes" are used so often that it is hard to see which things are just speculation, and which are truth with some real indications to what happened. And the Reddits are pretty ridiculous, especially the "....continue to kill again" entry. 

The good info: let's assume he met them and knew they wanted to hike that area; and that they left without him (was he supposed to go with them or was he taking them to his ranch?) the day prior, it's a little odd he decided to go find them at their hostel, unless he was truly concerned that they were missing from their hike. Then, he reported them missing immediately? That seems odd because why would someone on vacation immediately be considered missing, by a stranger? Big assumption, even if just trying to be helpful. 

But if he had something to do with it, why would he go search for them? And why report anything? Sure, I get the "throw the sent off by trying to help", that has happened in other cases you'd read about. Unless he is worried about physical evidence, and decided to place himself in their room so that there is a reason for him to have been there (even though it seems physical evidence against the guide are lacking, and nothing was collected by investigators). 

However, he had a reason to be there, if he 1) supposedly had an appt with them, and 2) once they are missing, if he is an "authority" on the trails, then it is proper for him to assist the search. 

One of the stranger things not discussed much, if connected, (aside from the murder of the girls) is the cab driver being killed. Would he have known something? This is the strangest story. The photos make no sense. So much of it makes no sense.

comment.text: Occam’s razor. They were 2 young girls that had zero hiking experience in the jungles of Central America. They went past the designated trail, feeling confident with their experience hiking in Northern Europe and not realizing how dangerous what they were doing was. Got lost, and did their best to preserve battery life of their devices. It only takes a day or two to become completely dehydrated and delirious. After a week, they’re not in their right mind or thinking rationally. They’re doing whatever they can to survive another minute. The final photos is them making sense of their environment/sending out a last call for help with 0 energy left. They were totally & completely depleted of energy AND possibly severely injured at this point. They also disappeared/were found in an environment where the body would naturally decompose very quickly and become “bleached” just from exposure to the elements. I think foul play is the absolute LEAST likely scenario here.

comment.text: In my opinion this is (more or less) what happened: at about 2:30PM the girls reached the 2nd (or actually 3rd as the 2nd is mostly dry) small river (NOT the cable bridge, will explain next where). This river is a bit larger than the one seen in the last day photo with Chris, and offers possibilities of taking a refreshing bath/swim. I think the girls "adventured" down this river to take a swim - that is why they put their bra, sunglasses, phones etc. in the backpack. I don't think they went very far down this river, not at all. I think their plan was to take a short swim and then start walking back to the summit and then back to Boquete. But then something happened (at around 4PM) while they were taking the swim. An accident to one of them? This is very likely. Or an assault? Also not impossible. In either cases I believe that they were not lost, they were not too far from the crossing of the path with this 3rd river. The noise of the river is very loud. I believe that the search teams would not have heard them screaming, especially if they would have walked a bit further off-track along the river. You can see this river and hear the noise here (at min: 9:20):  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O8AI3M1heAY&t=646s This is also the river reached by the girl's parents. The parents say that this river is consistent with the time of the 1st emergency call. In the blog of Romain C (https://imperfectplan.com/2021/11/21/panama-expedition-2021-complete-overview/) you can read more about river #3. The fact that the girls removed their bra and put them in the backpack is very consistent with taking a swim. The fact that the girls did not wear the bra anymore points to the possibility that this was either not possible anymore, or not at all a priority. This is in my opinion an extremely important clue. Something happens while they are taking a swim, probably either naked, or only partially naked. What happened exactly? Why none of them bothered wearing the bra's again? Yet, apparently, they made multiple attempts to call. And Chris's shorts were found, but none of her remains with the shorts. Did she take off the shirts before swimming? Very likely. But why she did not put them on again after the accident?

Bleached bone, no marks on the bones from animals or otherwise. Different level of decay. I assume they got lost at first, then they were found by cannibals. A tribe living in the jungle could explain why they had no interest in the money or electronics. They simply had no use for them. Also heavy rain ..but the picture with the blonde hair of one of the girls is dry. I can't see the injury either on that picture but it seems like there might be some blood in her hair. They were under some big rocks so one would assume there was a small cave or something that they used as shelter from the rain, explaining why her hair was dry. 

Maybe they didn't turn back because they were chased by someone. That local guide was kinda sus. This would explain why they simply didn't turn back and went back the same way they got to the point where they ended up. 

It is interesting that they didn't left a message. If I'd have my phone I would at least leave a note in it especially after so many days and little hope. Maybe it wouldn't be the first thing I think about but after so many days If there were two of us and the other person would be injured or dead I'm sure I'd take pictures of the injury or the body and what happened. All we have is pictures of rocks and vegetations and rain. Why?!

They could have been lost or chased for days then found and killed in some way. comment.author: @asodalis695

comment.text:
Yeah, blame the jungles. It doesn't make any sense at all. First of all, where are the bodies? Even if they fell from some sort of cliff you'll still have the bodies, at least the majority of the bodies would be intact. Eaten by animals? The fragments didn't show signs of that. And still, bones will be still found if the bodies were eaten by animals. Secondly, why they took off their bras and put them in the backpack? if they were lost or had an accident, they wouldn't have organized their belongings in such a neat fashion. It seems "put together" by someone. Thirdly, the trail is only a few kilometers long, and the area surrounding it isn't vastly big, plus there are trails all over and human activities are not scarce. With all the search efforts no large bodily remains nor other signs(made by them, the attempts to get help, the branch with red plastic bags, etc.). Fourthly, the missing/deleted picture from the camera. This didn't get mentioned in this video but there was one picture was deleted. Later a picture of the same day in the same area was posted on a website. It shows two girls with two guys taking a dip in the water. Although inconclusive the girls' body shaps resemble our missing girls. And the two guys in the picture both died within 2 years. Fifthly, they've only attempted to call the "emergency number" for days. This doesn't make sense. On the surface level, you'd think that's the right move but think again. After trying and trying they hadn't thought about calling someone else? If calling doesn't work wouldn't you try to send text messages? The phones with all those "112" attempts could be deliberately made to make you think they had an accident and tried to call for help, but it's just too stupid to believe.

comment.text: I don't think most of the 'theories' surrounding this case are realistic, whether it's Feliciano and his gang of roving bandits abducting the girls on the trail or the idea that they just walked nearly 6 hours north in the hopes that the trail would loop around before realizing it was about to get dark. I much rather just put myself in Lisanne's head, whom I believe was generally the one organizing their expedition, and go off of what we know about the girls actions leading up to the hike to make a logical guess about what probably actually happened. I think both Kris and Lisanne were anxious and restless after being rejected from the teaching job at the school, unsure of what they will be doing the next weeks in Boquette. They partially solved this issue by going to their host, which gave them a number of other suggestions for volunteer work. They also went to the tour guide, Feliciano, to set up a date for a hike. This is them acting responsibly and was clearly the correct way to do things. Clearly they were still feeling impatient on Tuesday; Lisanne specifically mentioned being homesick in her journal and feeling like she wasn't fit to take care of things on her own. I think that the April 1st hike started as a relatively short and relaxing way to get their mind off of things, but at some point it also became about proving to themselves how capable they are. The fact they brought barely any water and that they didn't tell anyone where they were going is actually a lot worse than people seem to make it out to be, though it would likely not have fatal consequences if they just stuck to their original plan. What do I think happened after they crossed the summit? I think they were looking for something off the trail like perhaps a waterfall or a crossing to another trail. Who knows what they read online or where they were getting their information from. It's pretty evident they didn't feel like they needed anyone else's help or input, preferring to just navigate the area on their own without telling someone their plans.  It's the only thing that really fits with the timeline and the orientation of the emergency calls. There's nearly 3 hour unaccounted for from the last photo to first emergency call and if I was doing something stupid with a high probability of getting me lost on a fairly straight forward trail in broad daylight it would be intentionally walking down an area that I'm pretty sure was the path I read about online which leads to something cool.

comment.text: I looked up that there is a side trail from the Main Pianista Trail to hidden waterfalls on Pipeline Trail, which is a quick hike from Pianista. After they had reached the Mirador, maybe thought the trail beyond would take them to the hidden waterfalls. From what I found on internet that is possible with an experienced guide on a detour trail. So they’d have to leave the main trail for a side trail. The last daytime photo of Kris standing on rock in stream looks like she was in deep thought and why she wasn’t smiling. Maybe the girls turned back up the trail and went off that main trail to a side trail thinking it would lead them to hidden waterfalls along Pipeline. Maybe it was adventurous for them to discover the hidden waterfalls going from a Pianista Route instead of just taking a Taxi to Pipeline Trail. Maybe they wanted to do both trails in one day. That could explain leaving the main trail, after the continental divide. Anything could have happened after that mistake. It’s just my opinion. My thoughts on why they would leave the trail at all.

comment.text:
11:28 That's not reddish-blonde hair. That's thin blonde hair over pinkish skin. If you look at the pictures of the girls, the one with blonde hair has thin hair, you can see it from her part-- thicker hair has more volume, and you don't usually see that much of the scalp unless it's done super neatly.

There's bloom in the shot-- look at the way the color of her hair bleeds into the background. That piece of reddened hair is just a result of camera artfacting, reflecting her skin into the hair.

Which leads me to believe this is a photo of the back of her head. It's super tangled, probably because she hadn't tied it back (they weren't expecting to be out there long.)

But the thing that raises red flags for me is that stray brown hair in the image. That's not a camera quirk, that's definitely hair. But why would her hair be angled like that? Reaching towards her friend? I have long brown hair, this really only happens if you're taking an image of something below you and your hair ends up dangling in the shot.

Then there's the way her hair is resting. You can see her forelock angled out, really all of her hair fanning out, but as you can see from the rest of the images, her hair isn't styled, it's flat. The only way I could see it appearing this way, if it really is the back of her head, is if she were laying down with her face in the dirt, and her friend (or someone else with longer brow hair,) is taking the picture while standing over her.

comment.text:
All it takes is 50 feet in the wrong direction before the jungle swallows you up. You have to make a life-or-death guess at the exact same time you realize what's happening and start to panic. I got lost like that in a Florida state forest following a false trail for 20 minutes. I miraculously picked the right direction and found an old logging/ranger road after a couple hours. But if I had gone with my first instinct, I could have easily vanished. You are either saving yourself or killing yourself, and you have no way to know which one you're doing. I still dream about it 20 years later. It's a special type of horror.

ALSO, I think the missing photo is explained by a good Samaritan. The image before the missing file is Kris's hair. I think Kris fell and injured herself badly, possibly even dying. Lisanne was trying to triage her in the dark by taking pictures. Because of her injury or otherwise grim appearance, the deleted image was shocking. As it would be traumatizing to the families, and the girls were already presumed dead, a nice person deleted it to spare them. Maybe the person who found the backpack or a government official.

comment.text: This case, not only sad like all of these are, definitely has its complexities. Scattered bones and dismemberment could have been from carrion animals, but bleached bones...According to forensic research conducted in the UK, it takes about six weeks during summer months in the UK for bones to begin to show signs of whitening and about nine weeks for bones to appear off-white. The UK isn't the jungles of Panama though, so if the bones were exposed to consistent UV rays, perhaps that process would be faster. This doesn't discredit animals from scattering the bones, but the backpack being clean and dry, their bras in the backpack, and an intentionally deleted photo that could only have been deleted by a computer rather than from the phone itself make this suspicious. Something else that doesn't sit well is that jungles are dense. You need a machete at the very least to make your way through if there isn't a path. If they were following a path and got into some difficult terrain, why not turn back? In the picture in which one of the girls looks anxious...the sun was still out. That's the most disturbing picture of all of them to me because that indicates a pivotal moment. Without a forensics team to investigate it, we'll likely never have the answers. As far as hiking alone, I'm not going to blame the victims. When there are two of you, you don't feel alone. And we don't know whether or not they were coerced to go further. My heart goes out to their loved ones.

comment.text:
There's no way they were that late starting the Pianista.  Photo analysis, both Dutch and Panamanian, put them at the Mirador around 1pm.  Even a layman like myself, can see it's midday. If they were up there at 5:30, there would have been a lot less light.   I still think the taxi driver dropped them off at around 11:30-11:45.

I believe "Frank" the shop owner is talking about two different women. I don't think either of the girls had on Lycra?  Correct me if I got that wrong.

The other confusing issue for me are the two calls made after 4pm. Why were they 12 minutes apart? If it was truly an emergency (i.e. Lisanne breaks foot, etc), why wait so long to make another call? They could not have gone far after the first call.

comment.text: You know, after all these years of longing for answers about what exactly happened during those days in the jungle you really start thinking in strange ways. What bothers me the most in this moment is that there is an answer out there; there is a sequence of events that happened in our objective reality that has the answer to everything. If only you could have been a fly on the wall that fateful day. You probably could have watched Lisanne walk into the room as Kris is sitting at the breakfast table, scrolling thru her phone and ask if she still wants to go on that trip they had talked about the previous night. You could have watched them quickly pack and get a cab... get out near the restaurant. You'd hear Lisanne order the strawberry Kist soda and Kris decide she wants orange. You'd see Kris play with the camera and probably say something funny as she takes a picture of Lisanne studying the map, looking up at her with playful derision. I wonder what it is they talked about thru the fields on the way to the forest. The fly on that day would hear them talk about what they would do in Boquete the upcoming weeks, they're life back home, they're families, they're boyfriends... you'd hear Lisanne explain to Kris what route they were taking to the summit and what they would see along the way. You'd hear them joke and complain and probably a few high pitch shreaks as one of them slipped on the trail, followed shortly by laughter. At the top you'd see Lisanne hand Kris the camera and tell her to make sure she get's a good panoramic view of the mountains behind as she makes a face and points to it. A few seconds later you'd hear Kris say something along the lines of 'me too' as she gives Lisanne the camera back and strikes a pose of her own. You'd hear them discuss going further down the trail on the other side of the mirador. That mystery which has been haunting so many people for over a decade would finally be solved once and for all. You'd see Kris's mood slowly change from happy and enthusiastic to tired and eventually worried and scared. You'd see photo 509 as it's taken. You'd see it slowly get dark, you'd see them leave the trail, get lost and call for help. You'd see them spend the first night in the jungle and the distress in their eyes when the next morning the sun comes up but they are no closer to finding the trail. You'd follow them as they wander further and further towards a river of false hope, you'd see Lisanne break her foot, you'd see them walk for days and days getting nowhere...You'd hear them slowly make their peace with death as they realize no one is coming. You'd sit idly by as they sit huddled together on a rock in the middle of a downpour, taking pictures of the darkness that surrounds them. You'd be there as they take their final breaths, and you'd finally understand with no uncertainty where they were, how they got there and why they couldn't get out. Those are the things that truthfully, I would be terrified of seeing but after all these years... I'm a fly on a leaf as I listen to Kris and Lisanne argue and try to rationalize their situation because I finally saw that fateful wrong turn, that misplaced step that after so many years finally makes it all make sense. I don't have to guess or theorize or stay up anymore reading dead end theories one after the other which all lead back to the beginning of a giant maze. In a way, I too stepped into the jungle with them after hearing their story... and just like them, I fear that I too may never leave.

comment.text: These girls weren't murdered.  What caused their demise is that they made an uninformed decision to be out there unguided and to cross the point of the continental divide and then were clearly lost and left very unprepared.  They went many a mile for days through an impossible maze.   Had to be an awful struggle.  Kris was in a bad fall that smashed her foot and was immobilized if not dead.  I think Lisann took all those night time photos at around that time/location, hoping to see Kris in the dark below and/or to mark the the spot in hope of eventual recovery.  Lisann eventually became too weak to go on and thus passed from lack of nutrition or a fall/injury.  Too bad - was close to village of Alto Romero. They, desperate to survive, didn't record notes so as to preserve battery power.  There's no shortage of freaks in this world, but they weren't killed by some freak, but by the elements.  They eventually succumbed and all that moisture accelerated decay and scattered their remains.  Water is a very powerful solvent over time and this region gets over 10 feet of rain annually.  RIP girls.

comment.text:
it started raining that night. that means that the area of the setting sun was likely obscured and they became disoriented with no reference and a maze of trails plus vision obscured in deep forest. no moon would be visible. when they went down the other side remember they had just been at the top and explored around. they knew they had to head back so headed downhill not on main trail. That is critical because on the side of a huge slope you know which way is up and down for reference but not when you are on a crest--ALL trails lead down. also with the rain starting they now were in dark and many trails would then be impassable. they were not murdered and it ESPECIALLY was not the womanizing guide. they operated camera and phone for DAYS. why did he find the bones? because he knew people get lost and they likely went down the wrong side. that is why guides and experienced hikers can often go right to a body. OF COURSE he found the bones he was an expert of the area thats why he saw them last alive. The mexicans were right--during the various monsoons the bodies got tumbled down stream and got ripped and torn apart and decomposed. 

why the bloody hair photo? they both like did DOZENS of slips and falls. she may well have wanted to see the injury with the flash.  why was the pack found "pristine". the camera card and likely the camera would not be affected especially in the case. it got blasted down and got stuck as the cannibal woman said. the rain subsides and things dry out that does not mean the pack would be all muddy at all. after drying it would be just like something drying out of the laundry. also you can WASH a calculator in the machine and let it dry out--it will work perfectly ive done it. the location of the pack out of the water proves how high the floods were. The pack would float--thus got caught up high. keep in mind an iphone--is almost waterproof for instance mine I lost in the snow and went back and got it from the slush and it was fine. remember the pack was not submerged. THEY GOT LOST FOLKS no cannibals got them at all if they did they would not have brought pack. 120% of the conditions were there for them to get injured and lost in the dark and rain.

comment.text:
They we're lost, died in a cave, near the river.. 
The bodies had some time to start decomposition (It's moist, and still warm.. perfect conditions for rapid decomposition), till a flashflood dragged their remains into the river..
This weakened the joints in their bodies, causing their bones to easily separate.  
Obviously, a bone without shoes around it will decompose much faster than one in a shoe..
It's much harder for insects to help decomposition inside a shoe..
Which explains why the pelvis bone seems more "bleached" (had more sunlight and contact with soil, which also contains phosphor..)
Unlike the meat in the shoe, which was protected from it and found UNDERNEATH A TREE IN SHADE!!!
It's also possible Kris died a few days before Lisanne, which would explain why the wrong PIN was used..
Sure, it's reasonable to expect Lisanne to know it, but don't forget she might have been panicked, hungry, and disoriented.. 
The skin is also easy to explain, a layer of skin, can easily dry in the sun causing it to become like leather... or jerky.. 
Obviously, from that moment it's gonna take a looooong time for it to decompose.

A few pieces of information about this case online are also wrong..
If you trace the sources, you'll see that the original sources of some claims, never even made the claim.. 
Like the backpack being in pristine condition, her father said in an interview the bag had drag marks, leaves and dirt..
Which would indicate them falling with the bag, or the bag being in the river..
It also wasn't dry.. nor found under a tree, but just at the riverbank.

The claims they called 77times in later days was claimed to be from RTL late night 1-10-2014..
But if you actually watch it, they don't say that all.. (yes i speak Dutch, and the episode is actually hard to find as well.)

And look what happens if you stich the night pictures together, then let photoshop fill in the missing parts: Hu8FOr8pVJU
Looks a lot like a cave doesn't it?

comment.text:
Why just ‘accident’ and ‘foul play’ theories - what about simply ‘lost’? I think that one of them may have suffered an accident and injury, which would explain the first emergency call not long after the last ‘normal’ photo, but it’s less likely that both of them would have suffered the same accident. 

While some things don’t add up and a case can be made for the foul play theory, I think on balance the most logical explanation is that they were ill-prepared, warned not to go without a guide but continued on a trail they were unfamiliar with in conditions and an environment they weren’t used to, got lost (and possibly injured) and sadly died from exposure.

I know true crime fans are predisposed to concluding that every unexplained disappearance or death must involve foul play, but some of the theories in the comments here about criminal conspiracies etc. are outlandish in my opinion. Sadly there is a lot of misinformation out there about this case, the police investigation has also been criticised and there is a language barrier which can result in mistranslation etc. which can all influence what one thinks about the case. 

What’s not up for debate is that this is a really sad tragedy and I think a learning point for anyone that if you are going into any potentially hazardous environment, to make sure you’ve got some knowledge and equipment/supplies to help keep you safe in the event anything untoward happens, and to know your limits.

comment.text: By far the most likely theory is that they got lost on the first day as they were trying to head back down the trail. They tried to call emergency services several times but were unable to get through. They continued deeper into the rain forest and at some point came to the river. They decided to follow the river thinking it would lead them to civilization. Instead, it lead them further and further away. They survived for days based on phone and camera data but at some point perished due to lack of food, exhaustion and possibly dysentery from drinking the river water. One of them probably died first and the other stayed in that area and was probably too weak to continue. I point you to the story of Amanda Eller who was lost in Hawaii for 17 days in an area significantly smaller than this. No way some gang or rapist is going to follow someone 10 miles into the rainforest to kill them. Also, a criminal wouldn't let them use their phone and camera repeatedly. The mystery photos are the result of trying to use the flash to see at night or to scare away an animal in the bushes. Lastly, the dog that was with them was very familiar with the area. When if got dark the first night, the dog peaced out and found his way home. I work in wilderness search and rescue and it is not uncommon for people to get off a trail and never find their way back, wandering for days until finally succumbing. I point you to the story of Geraldine Largay who's body was found less than two miles from the trail after getting lost.

comment.text: In another video, the parents of Kris Kremers took the same trail to get an idea of the terrain the young women faced months earlier. They stated that there could have been no way for the ladies to have gotten lost because thick vegetation surrounds the trail on both sides. However, I think they did not factor in the following: 1) They retraced their daughter's steps already knowing the outcome. Hindsight is always viewed with 20/20 glasses; 2) The parents had guides with them and could have never gotten lost, whereas Kris and Lisanne were unguided and unfamiliar with the area; 3) Having hiked countless trails in many countries (including tropical ones) myself, there is always the main trail but animal trails and washes that look like trails, many single-track and narrow, are always present. It would be easy for inattentive newbies talking and snapping photos to start walking along one of these by mistake; 4) Kris's parents took a day trip and brought the necessary gear and supplies, but as we know based on the calls that were made on Kris and Lisanne's phones, that the two were out there for days with insufficient food and clothing. People have commented that they could have simply walked out. Seemed like Kris had gotten injured and Lisanne could not, or did not want, to leave her. With each passing day, the lack of food and exposure to the elements would have taken a toll on them mentally and physically. Other thoughts: Why did they take night shots of seemingly random things? Jungles come alive at night. I'd be doing the same thing if there were things moving around and making sounds in the darkness. Why did they call 112 (the equivalent of 911) in the Netherlands? My guess is because it was familiar to them. They had not been in Panama for very long after all and would have known that calling their homeland's emergency agency would have been more reliable than calling the hostel where they were staying. The Dutch responders would have immediately known to contact their parents to make them aware of the situation. Of course the rest of this tragic story raises more questions than answers and has many parts, but this is just my take about one of those parts.

comment.text:
Si jamais c'est un accident avec concours de circonstances, ça me rappelle l'affaire du jeune homme, Simon Gautier, il était parti en voyage en Italie, il montrait des photos à ses proches etc, et du jour au lendemain, le 9 aout 2019, plus de nouvelles, et plusieurs jours plus tard, le 18 aout 2019, le corps a été retrouvé, 

Probablement rapide", la mort de Simon Gautier a été causée par la section d'une artère fémorale;
.
Selon les premiers résultats de l'autopsie réalisée sur le corps de Simon Gautier en Italie, le randonneur français est mort d'un "très grave choc hémorragique" dû à la section d'une artère fémorale.

Selon les premières conclusions de l'autopsie du corps, l'artère fémorale de la jambe gauche a été sectionnée suite à une chute.

Il souffrait de fractures ouvertes et de graves coupures"

Selon le procureur Antonio Ricci, le jeune Français de 27 ans n'a survécu que pendant environ 45 minutes.

Dans sa chute, Simon Gautier a subi des fractures aux deux jambes "avec déplacement des membres et de graves coupures". Il a apparemment eu l'artère de la jambe gauche sectionnée, selon les deux experts qui l'ont examiné, l'un nommé par le procureur Ricci et un autre désigné par le père du jeune homme.

Simon Gautier avait disparu le 9 août 2019, alors qu'il randonnait sur la côte au sud de Naples. Il a été retrouvé mort dimanche 18 août 2019, dans un ravin. 
Une enquête pour "homicide involontaire" a été ouverte ce mercredi en Italie. Elle vise à faire la lumière sur les circonstances de la mort du randonneur mais aussi sur l'organisation 
des secours après l'appel passé par Simon Gautier aux urgences italiennes. 

Mort rapidement après son appel au secours :
Selon l'enregistrement de l'appel de détresse, diffusé par des médias italiens, Simon avait expliqué être tombé d'une falaise et s'être cassé les deux jambes, mais sans pouvoir dire où il se trouvait, "au milieu de nulle part, sur la côte". Les secours avaient lancé des recherches, restées vaines pendant plusieurs jours. Le randonneur ne répondait plus à son téléphone. Selon l'autopsie, il serait en effet mort quelques minutes seulement après avoir appelé les secours. 

Ce n'est que dimanche 18 aout 2019, soit neuf jours après sa disparition, qu'un secouriste avait repéré le sac à dos du Français, aux jumelles. Son corps avait été retrouvé tout près.

Rapatriement jeudi 22 aout 2019 en France :
Une veillée de prières en hommage au jeune homme était organisée mardi soir dans une église de la commune la plus proche. Les amis de Simon Gautier, présents sur place jusqu'alors, vont quitter la région ce mercredi. Le corps du jeune homme qui vivait à Rome a été rapatrié jeudi 22 aout 2019 en France.

Si ça se trouve, c'est quelque chose de ce genre qui est arrivé à Lisanne et à Kris.

comment.text: The case is clear cut.  Two girls who were ill-prepared for the journey they put themselves on, got lost in the jungle.  Because they were ill-prepared, they likely succumbed to the mental rigors that dehydration and likely hypothermia they would have suffered at night would have taken on them.  The one fell at some point, hence the broken foot in the boot, this wouldn't have happened at the time of the fall but the girls were out in the jungle for at least 12 weeks til they were found.  When Lisanne fell, Kris after time knew she was the one stuck to go get help either before or after Lisanne was dead.  The pictures at night are to mark where Lisanne was left so that if Kris found help, they could go rescue or recover Lisanne.  Studies show bones become fully bleached after 9 weeks.  Animals would have scavenged on whatever was available of their bodies for food.  They were following a river, because usually following a river downstream leads to civilization, the bag went into the water at some point and went downriver, if it ended up on the shore, it could have been there for days in the pounding sun to dry.  All of this is a tragic accident and a lesson that when the battle is human vs nature, nature will always win.  But let's suppose you want the foul play theory.  A. would the girls have been allowed to try to call for help repeatedly over the course of several days?  B. would the backpack ever have been found?  Seriously, there was like 80 dollars in there, in an impoverished area.  It wouldn't have been taken?  Come on.  C.  Would the phones ever have been found with abductors knowing that incriminating evidence could have been on the camera.  But sure, lets say they just deleted the one photograph instead.  D. Would the bodies have even ever been found?  Logically, an abduction murder makes no sense given the facts of the case.
comment.author: @sirmang9032

comment.text:
I do believe the girls got lost and probably spent a few hours trying to find their way back before they realized they couldn't and started making the emergency calls. They most likely switched their phones off after the calls failed to go through to conserve battery power and decided on calling emergency services one time a day. Sadly, Kris may have met her end first leaving Lisanne alone which could explain the wrong pin being entered on Kris' phone. The night time pictures may have been markers for anyone who found the camera. 

I think there was shady stuff going on after they were already dead. The Government was probably covering things up to protect their tourist industry. But I don't see much evidence to imply that they were abducted. The tour guide going into their room for  30 minutes alone while the girls were missing was suspicious . But the pictures that were released don't really indicate someone was following them and their calls also don't indicate they were frantically trying to get ahold of help because they were in immediate danger from someone. As for the deleted picture, I actually believe it was the police that deleted the photo to hide something, again to protect their tourism. This is a sad case overall and I mourn for these girls and their families.

comment.text:
My best guess is that foul play was involved, but I think it is also possible that Kreemer died of natural causes. 

What makes me question that are two things - The photo of Kreemer's head, and her bleached bones. It can take 6 - 9 weeks, depending on varying factors, for bones to bleach naturally. 

I think it is possible the girls got lost, panicked, and Kreemer slipped and hit her head while searching for a high point to gain signal and call for help. 

As for what happened to Froon.. That I don't know. I doubt she would have wanted to leave her injured friend, but once Kreemer passed, she would have had to move to avoid Kreemer's remains attracting predators to her location. I think this would also explain why Kreemer's remains were so scattered - Possibly Vultures? 

From this point, Froon could have also died of natural causes - But I think it is more likely she was killed, and their backpack was taken. 

I think the key to their deaths lies with their backpack. They should have questioned the lady who found it more thoroughly - She may have known more than she was letting on, or could even have been responsible for Froon's death. 

Such a tragic story. At least we can hope they didn't die alone - They had each other in their final moments. May they rest eternally.

comment.text:
I believe they both fell from a monkey bridge, or one fell and the other rescued her and also became trapped in the ravine. And the dogs don't pass it

Experts say humans can survive thirty days without food but only three to five days without water. So I believe they drank rainwater. That's the only way they could survive 11 days.

Tropical torrential rains can be a problem at night, when temperatures drop significantly, and biological factors determine who will get sick first. This, combined with the lack of food, weakens the body. Maybe one of them must have contracted pneumonia. Maybe Kris Kremer was alive and forgot her cell phone password maybe.

Eleven days alive and with a cell phone rules out foul play.

According to the photos, after several days of torrential rain, small streams quickly become floods. I've seen it happen around here, where the water level rises rapidly, as does the current, and this swept them downstream and them drowned.

I believe the cause of their deaths was actually the delay in rescue.

comment.text: The girls were kidnapped. They most likely died very quickly (before April 7th), and the rest is just a falsification (phone logs and photos from the Canon camera). They were killed by a group—since one man could not have done it alone—who knew the trail very well and walked it often. The perpetrators had plenty of time to get rid of the bodies, to scatter the bones in different locations, and to place the backpack in a well-known spot by the river, though it had never been seen there before. They also had time to mislead the rescue teams and the police investigation. The local people were too afraid to speak about what might really have happened. The perpetrators had access to a computer, so they could manipulate the Canon camera. No one could survive 10 days in the jungle; it is simply impossible.

comment.text:
I watched many documentaries about this case a couple of years ago, I settled on the conclusion that it was definitely foul play. Recently, I read an article in the newspaper about this case and decided to do a fresh deep dive as its always  really fascinated me. I now truly believe it was a tragic accident. There is so much false information out there regarding this case. Outlandish lies. Such as the shorts being neatly folded, the bag being in perfect condition and the famous nighttime headshot photo which apprently  shows a serious head injury (it absolutely does not). 

I think people just love a sensational story. Myself included, and naturally, we look for the most exciting or scary version of a story rather than looking at the cold, hard facts. 

If you do a really good deep dive into this case I think you will also realise it was in fact nothing more then being injured and lost in a massive jungle. 

Poor girls 😢

comment.text:
The thing about 509 is that it's not the final image; it's in the middle. That adds to the mystery, because if you delete an image and take another, the camera system will overwrite that image number. So it was deleted later, after the later images were taken.

Some of the speculation is that 509  deliberatley or accidentally caught a picture of someone involved in what happened to the two women.

Additionally, a number of people involved in the case have since died, including the taxi driver who took them to the walk start and claimed local gang members wanted to know about them.

Finally, the darkness and rain photos have been since found to be mostly taken in the same space. Using clever software beyond me, some people have managed to stitch them together into a 3D image rather like a Google streetview, with rock walls on either side, with foliage above, and the big bare rocks with the women's equipment laid out on them as a kind of emergency signal.
