comment.text: I've watched this about 2 years ago and now again, and though it was cronologically one of the first vids on the case imo it is still the most thorough in terms of research. I wish Dr van der Gaat and his guys, or you, or anyone... had hiked and searched the trail in the same weather conditions and time of year the girls were lost. Just take pics at the same spots, watch out for the shadows/sun and for the rock formations - exact rock positions don't change even in a few years...   That would have answered many questions and they also would have been able to access the Culebra terrain.  The women had a sunny, dry day, seemingly only half the mountains overcast, rest blue. It is obvious in their photos that even the river rocks they climbed were dry as well as the forest floor.  I've watched several hikes of El pianista, some in part, some far beyond the Mirador, but every time those hikes seem to show completely different trails, especially after the viewing point. The vid with the parents in 2014 doesn't even remotely look like some of the other images depicted in videos. When they reach the river rocks, they conclude this is where Krist stood. It looks similar, but was it? I thought the rocks looked a tiny bit different... Why do some say it was the direction towards Boquete (back) and some say it was leading away? When the parents go further beyond the mirador and even the riverbed the trail they took indeed didn't seem to offer any chance to get lost or fall or get injured.  But it also doesn't look like what I saw in other videos at all, where the trail became quite tight, then thickly wooded, even dark. Instead they end up in another type of open meadow like the beginning of the trail. That's confusing. Were they lead another route? Now I found ratings of this trail on different web sites and more than half of the hikers (for instance on alltrails) say they needed gps or that they even got lost because there were no signs. How could they encounter this problem if there is only ONE way? Also the trail that Google maps suggests as "el pianista" (and you can walk the Ave. Buenos Aires and see its entry on google) seems to NOT be the El pianista, but the actual el Pianista trail has its entrance further up right by the restaurant, it is alleged. Then at one time I found a hiker's site that is all about the surrounding rain forest trails of Boquete. It specifically mentions that the Culebra Trail leads into the el pianista trail ! which I never saw mentioned anywhere. It also mentions at least one hidden waterfall at pianista, so hidden that even most local hikers don't know where it is. So there must be other paths on that trail, it is not ONE way - whatever that proves. As for the sculls and other remains, animals love to carry them miles away and hide them and more often than not searchers don't find sceletal remains and later they turn up. I believe they will eventually be found.
comment.author: @regineuhe6657

comment.text: A very well put together report on a fascinating (if slightly ghoulish) subject. In this case the 'guide' (well reported about on google searches he doesn't take much finding) knows an awful lot more than he has declared publicly. A person who was one of the last to see them alive, gained access to their room and possessions the following day before they were officially 'missing' and then handled evidence that turned up in the river a few kilometres from his property and many km's from their supposed last known location is more than coincidence or bad luck. Having read through Scarlet's excellent write up (foul play theory) and this one (lost in the jungle theory) it is difficult to conclude which was the more likely outcome and plenty of armchair investigators have tried... One thing i've never seen addressed or analysed in great depth though is the timings between the two emergency calls on 1st April which intrigue me- the first one at 16.39 then another just over ten min's later- if someone(s) was stalking/chasing me then it would be a frenzy of multiple call attempts in a short space of time, praying that at least one connects. The ten min delay suggests maybe the situation is not desperate and they hoped a significant change of location could work- go this way more or in that way or- logically- try to get higher up? Perhaps also, this would explain why in one case 19 hours goes by between attempts. If one girl was injured then it would've been slow progress to find a better spot but I find it inconceivable they didn't encounter other people at some point unless they were seriously off piste or... we're back to foul play and the irrefutable mystery surrounding photo #509 again aren't we?

comment.text: Vidéo très intéressante, j'aime beaucoup, continue ! Je suis pas certain de bien comprendre l'intérêt de prendre les cheveux de l'une des deux jeunes femmes en photo et de la laisser sur l'appareil ? Aussi, je n'ai peut être pas bien compris mais pourquoi composer le 911 de la part de supposés agresseurs ? En effet, même en ayant connaissance que le réseau téléphonique ne passe pas, je doute que les agresseurs savaient à coup sûr que de composer le numéro des secours étaient une idée géniale : on ne sait jamais si ca capterait et se retournerait contre eux. Et dans ce cas extrêmement grave comme celui d'une séquestration, je doute que composer ce numéro serait une bonne idée. Aussi, s'ils avaient pas prévu leur mort avant l'arrivée massive des équipes de recherche : pourquoi avoir déjà prévu le plan de composer le 911 avant que les recherches ne les inquiètent ? Enfin, je ne comprends pas pourquoi ils auraient cru que le numéro d'urgence aurait été capté par les bornes téléphoniques alors qu'il n'y avait normalement pas de réseau. Je suis profane en la matière, j'imagine comme tout le monde, et je ne savais pas qu'on pouvait capter les urgences si la région très sauvage ne recevait aucun réseau. L'idée du chewing gum pour faux repère d'une jeune femme accidentée me paraît aussi trop compliquée pour deux agresseurs lambda qui se sont rendues compte sans doute avec effroi des recherches pour retrouver les deux filles. comment.text:
First, I believe they both fell from a monkey bridge, or one fell and the other rescued her and also became trapped in the ravine.

Experts say humans can survive thirty days without food but only three to five days without water. So I believe they drank rainwater. That's the only way they could survive 11 days.

Tropical torrential rains can be a problem at night, when temperatures drop significantly, and biological factors determine who will get sick first. This, combined with the lack of food, weakens the body. Maybe one of them must have contracted pneumonia. Maybe Kris Kremer was alive and forgot her cell phone password

Eleven days alive and with a cell phone rules out foul play.

According to the photos, after several days of torrential rain, small streams quickly become floods. I've seen it happen around here, where the water level rises rapidly, as does the current, and this swept them downstream and them drowned.

I believe the cause of their deaths was actually the delay in rescue.

comment.author: @frankiefavero1666

comment.text:
This tragedy is on many people's minds because the informations do not add up. This unfortunately leads to numerous conspiracy theories and speculations. All the geographical details beyond the Pianista trail are sketchy, the mention of a Snake River (Rio Culebra) in the area is restricted to accounts of this incident. There is however a Culebra trail in the vicinity, which adds to the confusion. It is not clear if all the locations in the photos before the final flash series were identified.

The main irritation is the different state of the backpack and the remains of the bodies. It suggests that at one point the backpack got separated from the women before their bodies were reduced to the state they were in when found. This leads to the suspicion that the backpack was not immediatly given to the authorities, was held in storage and possibly changed hands more than once.

Nobody talks about the cultural gap between the tourist from Europe and the local population not connected with the tourist trade. It is very probable that locals in isolated areas fear the authorities. In this case they will not volunteer information, no matter how high a reward is promised. They will act in the way they think is least likely to get them into trouble: keep quiet, keep away. They probably do not want to answer questions and get enangled in contradictions during interviews with people much more powerful than they are. So, probably the backpack was held back for quite some time and then stealthily deposited in a location sufficiently exposed that someone will come across it. Considering the state of the contents of the backpack, I do not see any ill will here.

It think, this was a sad accident while they were alone in the wilderness. A slip, a slide, a fall, a poisioning by a plant or an animal, separation, search for the friend, possibly reunification, increasing weakness, delirium ...

Okay I just researched on some updates on the case and the dog story is believed by many to be fake - so either the family was mistaken or that they lied or maybe something just got lost in translation. Basically it's quite unlikely that the dog went with them.

Edit: Some other things that are apparently myths:
1. Kremer's head was not injured. At least the photo doesn't suggest so. 
2. Kremer's jeans were not found neatly folded. 
3. The backpack and the things in them were quite damaged. And the indigenous woman who found it didn't go to the river for weeks until then. 

There's a whole subreddit for the case. You can visit there to see more details & updates.

comment.text:
Following the life-threatening attack on Peter de Vries in July 2021, many people will have been reminded of this case, likely one of the saddest he considered.

For people who may have missed some information, the girls disappeared on a short trek in 2014 near a busy tourist village, Boquete, Panamá. They were intending to begin voluntary work in the area. Small amounts of human remains were recovered some time after they disappeared, proven to be from the girls.

Their trek was to a well-known hilltop, El Mirador Del Pianista, which took about 2 hours, starting not long after 11am and arriving at about 1pm, after a trek of about 8km. Those timings, taken from photos on a camera they had with them, were not accepted by all who reviewed the evidence, with suggestions that they may have been changed. Also, there was an assertion that the girls had earlier lost their way and only reached El Mirador Pianista at a time considerably later than the timings indicated. 

After the hilltop they continued over the other side, towards a wildlife protection zone: 
datazone.birdlife.org; Palo Seco Protection Forest.

After some time considering what happened and how evidence came to light, it occurred to me that the name, Protection Forest, might not mean the same to all. Open grassland, very likely a sign of cattle grazing, may indicate that an important consideration was protection of cattle and those who managed them.

The authorities may have been reluctant to say that the girls probably were attacked and killed by a jaguar or a puma. Wikipedia's pages for those predators show their distributions. Most likely, investigations were carried out by two or more different authorities, explaining many different sets of fingerprints found on their camera. What some called the monkey bridge, which consisted of cables across a gorge without planking, suggests that it was intended that people should not go into the protection zone, certainly not unless accompanied by trained guides.

Probably they did not walk as far as the boundary of the protection zone. Beyond the top of the hill they were in the neighbouring province where responsibility for controlling or warning about dangerous predators might have been more uncertain.

Because of the many foreign visitors in the area where the trek began there may have been a culture of hoping for the best and not wanting to give clear warnings. Apparently, reasons to be especially fearful were not known to all but an older or weaker animal, or one wounded by poachers or ranchers, might tend to overcome an instinctive fear of humans and attack in desperation.

comment.text:
Oh yeah, this case. I wish the information I have about it was more widely available, but then again, that kind of information not requiring a couple hours of research on the deep web would upset the state of our fragile society.

In short, there are things that are incomprehensible to a regular human. These things prefer to reside in, surprise, unpopulated areas.
Jungles and Central/South Americas are full of them, hence many folk supernatural tales.

The girls stumbled upon it, I imagine that they were either "entranced" by an exchange of information, or were transported, perhaps event multiple times. My theory is that when they actually figured out what they were encountering, the emergency calls began. And when this entity became bored of toying with them, it literally shattered the poor girls apart.

I bet they tried to take photos of what they were seeing, but you cant really snap a picture of a vision of lower/higher dimensions you are being shown. Those poor girls must have literally been losing their sanity.

What is not as often reported is that their bodyparts and some of their belongings were also either heavily irradiated, magnetized, or had trace amounts of highly exotic chemicals on them; this is extremely common in these cases. This case would be hushed up and swept under the rugs like all others like it, but I imagine that the remoteness of the area and immediate rescue efforts prevented that.

Stay home, kids.
Do not go alone or in small groups to deep wilderness.
Especially if the area has tales of UFO/Bigfoot/Chupacabra/vampires or whatever else cute monickers the locals came up with.

comment.text:
I just don’t understand something. If the girls were lost and trying to get help why didn’t they take a video on the camera stating what was happening? Or if it couldn’t do any video, take photos detailing where they were, what happened to Kris’s head and the terrain of their location in the daylight. I mean these are smart girls so why didn’t they document their experience with the Hope their families would see it. Often if someone is lost in the wilderness and succumbing to the elements they try to leave a legacy of some sort to speak to their families. 

If they fell off a cliff then the backpack would have gone over the edge with them into the water but it didn’t get wet apparently. And if it was at the top of the cliff it would have been exposed to all sorts of elements, rain, heat, dirt etc. But it was clean. 

Those are the sticking points for me that make an accident kind of not believable.
comment.author: @lindseyhudson1274

comment.text:
I think if the girls researched this hike and knew a waterfall was close, I can absolutely see them being at the volcano at (1:30pm I believe was the time on the pic) and saying the waterfall is so close, let’s give it a try. Knowing their time and being so intelligent talking themselves into a short cut or faster route- I’ve been there hiking it’s late/ your tired & hungry, outta water, it’s so tempting to cut out parts of the trail. It’s not fair to say they’re too smart to leave the trail. 
The deleted photo could have been a shot of partial dressed or if they’re taking pics for orientation maybe they aimed it the wrong way and deleted so they wouldn’t become confused- lots of easy explanation.   
If one girl  slipped into the river canon I could see the other following to stay together. Also old tip if lost in the forest is to follow a river, so willing climb down into, it may even look easier then in a dense jungle- just seeing the sky would be uplifting. Those girls could’ve walked that river for 2 weeks or sat and waited for rescue becoming weaker by the day. If they drank the water, water born illness could have made them extremely dehydrated. Now roll an ankle or fall or hit your head. One girl dies along the way, surviving one would continue until she couldn’t. Broken bones can be explained by large predator animals or floating down the river until it gets stuck somewhere. Surviving girl probably sat her backpack somewhere safe and dry to protect the phones and camera. Wrong pins can be explained by dehydration or trying to remember her friends PIN
The murderer theory is juicy and tantalizing but no evidence thanks to a poorly run investigation. 
The fact they tried emergency services that first day tells me they knew they were lost. A murderer isn’t gonna let them have their phones and call for help
Tragic all the way around. I’m so sorry for the girls and their family.
comment.author: @carebear5394

Pretty important thing to miss out and makes this the least informative video on this case.
